questions.text: Among the following which is considered as water borne hepatitis virus? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Hepatitis A virus

 

  • Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is considered waterborne because it is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route. 
  • Out of the five major types of hepatitis viruses, only Hepatitis A and E are transmitted via the feco-oral route. 
  • This means they can be transmitted through contaminated water and food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatitis B virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis B is not waterborne. Hepatitis B is transmitted through sexual contact, needle syringes, parenteral route, and blood (including blood products). 

 

Option C. Hepatitis C virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis C is not waterborne. It is transmitted through sexual contact, needle sharing, and blood. 

 

Option D. Hepatitis D virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis D is not waterborne. It is transmitted through sexual, parenteral (needles), and blood routes, similar to Hepatitis B and C

 

Educational Objective:

 

Public Health Classification of Water Borne Diseases

questions.text: Best level of evidence as seen in research is? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Meta-analysis

 

  • Meta-analysis represents the highest level of evidence in the evidence-based medicine (EBM) pyramid. 
  • Meta-analysis is defined in a very unique way that is “Analysis of Analyses”- Analysis of multiple studies together. 
  • It is considered the gold standard of evidence-based medicine and is the most superior epidemiological study design.
  • The concept of evidence-based medicine was introduced by D.L. Sackett, who is known as the father of evidence-based medicine. 
  • When organizing studies from the worst to the best in terms of strength of evidence, meta-analysis sits at the top of the EBM pyramid, followed by systematic reviews, randomized control trials (RCTs), cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, ecological studies, then opinion views, animal research, and finally in vitro research at the bottom.


 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: While cohort studies provide strong evidence and are higher in the EBM pyramid than case-control studies, they are still below meta-analyses and RCTs. Cohort studies follow groups of people over time to determine if exposure to certain factors leads to specific outcomes. They can establish temporality but may have issues with loss to follow-up and are time-consuming.

 

 

Option B. Case control study: These are lower in the EBM hierarchy compared to cohort studies, RCTs, systematic reviews, and meta-analyses. Case-control studies compare cases (people with a condition) with controls (people without the condition) to identify potential risk factors. They are retrospective and subject to recall bias.

 

Option C. RCT (Randomized Control Trial): Though RCTs are considered the gold standard for evaluating interventions and are high in the EBM pyramid, they are still ranked below meta-analyses and systematic reviews. RCTs randomly assign participants to treatment or control groups, minimizing selection bias, but they may not always be generalizable to all populations.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meta-analysis represents the highest level of evidence in the evidence-based medicine hierarchy, above systematic reviews, randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, and case-control studies.

questions.text: ICER is used as an Economic model in which of the following Health Management Techniques: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost effectiveness analysis

 

ICER stands for Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio. It is a measure used in cost-effectiveness analysis to compare the differences in cost between two interventions relative to the differences in their effectiveness or results. The formula for calculating ICER is:

 

ICER = (C₁ - C₀) / (E₁ - E₀)

 

Where:

 

  • C₁ and E₁ represent the cost and effectiveness of the intervention being evaluated
  • C₀ and E₀ represent the cost and effectiveness of the control or comparison intervention

 

ICER is primarily used in cost-effectiveness analysis when comparing treatment alternatives, especially when expressed in terms of quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). It helps decision-makers determine if the additional cost of a more effective intervention is worth the additional benefit gained.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost benefit analysis: This is incorrect because cost-benefit analysis expresses both costs and benefits in monetary terms, whereas ICER is used in cost-effectiveness analysis where effectiveness is measured in non-monetary outcomes (like life years gained or QALYs).

 

Option C. Systems analysis: This is incorrect because systems analysis is a problem-solving approach that involves comparing alternative cost-effective solutions in a health program. 

 

Option D. Cost accounting: This is incorrect because cost accounting deals with the basic cost structure of a health program and the allocation of resources. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

ICER (Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio) is a key economic model used in cost-effectiveness analysis to compare the relative costs and outcomes of different interventions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for defining severe acute malnutrition? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Low Height for age

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is defined by three specific criteria;

 

  • Weight for height <-3 SD (visible severe wasting)
  • Bilateral pedal edema 
  • Mid-upper arm circumference < 115 millimeters

 

Low height for age is not included in the criteria for defining SAM. Height for age is an indicator of stunting, which reflects chronic malnutrition rather than acute malnutrition. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low height for age (stunting) is an indicator of chronic malnutrition and is not a criterion for defining Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM). 

 

The three criteria for SAM are:

 

  • Weight for height <-3 SD (visible severe wasting)
  • Bilateral pedal edema 
  • Mid-upper arm circumference < 115 millimeters

 

Pem Status Indicators

 

  1. Low Wt. for Age → Under Weight → Acute on chronic PEM
  2. Low Wt. for Height → Wasting → Acute PEM
  3. Low Ht for Age → Stunting → Chronic PEM

choices.text: Rapid diagnostic test (HRP Type 2 Pf Antigen)

questions.text: Malaria diagnosis under field settings is best done by using? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Thick peripheral blood smear

 

  • The mainstay of malaria diagnosis in India is smear microscopy. Research studies have demonstrated that the sensitivity of thick smear is greater than that of thin smear. 
  • Thick smear provides sensitivity for detecting the presence of malaria, while thin smear is used for species identification, offering specificity to the test. 
  • Although PCR is the most sensitive test overall, we are considering field settings in a developing country like India, where cost is a significant factor.
  • Thick peripheral blood smear has low cost compared to rapid diagnostic kits and is therefore the best possible test for field settings in India.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thin peripheral blood smear: This is less sensitive than thick smear for detecting the presence of malaria parasites. Thin smear is primarily used for species identification once malaria has been detected. 

 

Option C. Buffy coat technique: This technique is not commonly used in field settings for malaria diagnosis. It requires more sophisticated laboratory equipment and technical expertise which may not be available in field conditions.

 

Option D. Rapid diagnostic kit (HRP Type 2 Pf Antigen): Rapid diagnostic kits based on histidine-rich protein type 2 have moderate cost compared to smear microscopy. Additionally, they can only detect Plasmodium falciparum, whereas all four subtypes of malaria are present in India. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For malaria diagnosis in field settings in developing countries like India, thick peripheral blood smear is the preferred method due to its higher sensitivity and lower cost compared to other methods.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a high risk group for HIV? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Long distance truck drivers (LDTD)

 

  • High-risk groups for HIV are populations that have both high risk and high prevalence of HIV. 
  • According to the National AIDS Control Program's epidemiological classification, high-risk groups include commercial sex workers, injecting drug users, men having sex with men, and transgenders. 
  • These groups have the highest risk of contracting and transmitting HIV due to their behaviors or circumstances.
  • Long distance truck drivers are classified as a bridge population, not a high-risk group. 
  • Bridge populations are those who contract HIV because they come in contact with the high-risk groups, and then potentially transmit it to the general population. 
  • Along with truck drivers, bridge populations include migrant laborers, partners of IDUs, clients of commercial sex workers, and populations in conflict areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV Transmission Spectrum: High-Risk Groups vs Bridge Populations vs General Populations

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented to OPD of a PHC Watery diarrhea having severe dehydration. Most likely causative agent underlying would be: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Rota virus

 

  • Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe diarrhea among young children, especially those under 5 years of age. 
  • Rotavirus primarily affects the small intestine, causing malabsorption and secretory diarrhea, which can lead to rapid dehydration. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shigella: Incorrect. Shigella invades the colonic mucosa, causing inflammation and ulceration, which results in the characteristic bloody stools with mucus. It is not the most common cause of watery diarrhea with severe dehydration in young children.

 

Option B. E.Coli O157:H7: Incorrect. E. coli O157:H7 is an enterohemorrhagic strain that primarily causes bloody diarrhea, not watery diarrhea.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Incorrect. Salmonella typically causes gastroenteritis with diarrhea, fever, vomiting and is usually accompanied by abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the most common cause of watery diarrhea with severe dehydration in young children under 5 years of age.

questions.text: Vaccine that should not be given in age above 65 years is: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Human papilloma virus vaccine

 

  • HPV vaccine is generally used for prevention of cervical cancer and other HPV infections. 
  • It is recommended to be administered at the onset of puberty, with an upper age limit of approximately 45 years of age. 
  • This makes HPV vaccine inappropriate for people over 65 years.

 

Vaccines indicated for elderly (≥60 years): Influenza vaccine, Pneumococcal vaccine, and Td (every 10 years). 

 

Other vaccines that may be indicated for the elderly include Herpes Zoster, Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Meningococcal vaccine, MMR, Varicella, and Yellow fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV (Human Papilloma Virus) vaccine has an upper age limit of approximately 45 years and is not indicated for administration in individuals above 65 years of age 

 

Vaccination For Elderly (CDC)

 

  1. Influenza 
  2. Pneumococcal 
  3. Td- every 10 years

 

If ≥ 60 yr. vaccine indicated 

 

  • Herpes Zoster 
  • Hep A, Hep B
  • Menningococcal v.
  • MMR
  • Varicella v.
  • YF v.

questions.text: In a village population, patients having diabetes and hypertension are enumerated. Then their family members are screening for diabetes and hypertension. This is a type of: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Selective screening

 

  • This is an example of selective screening, which is a type of screening applied to high-risk groups - individuals who have a higher chance of developing a particular disease. 
  • In this case, family members of patients with diabetes and hypertension are being screened because they are at higher risk of developing these conditions due to genetic predisposition and shared environmental factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass screening: This is incorrect because mass screening refers to screening applied to a large population without considering risk factors. Mass screening is conducted on a "large number of people" without specific risk targeting, like "chest x-ray in elderly for lung cancer." The given scenario is specifically targeting family members of already diagnosed patients, not the entire population.

 

Option C. Multiphasic screening: This is incorrect because multiphasic screening involves applying more than two tests to a large number of people. Multiphasic screening as where "more than 2 tests are used or applied in large number of people like annual health checkup." In the given scenario, we're only screening for two specific conditions (diabetes and hypertension) in a targeted group, not conducting multiple tests on a large population.

 

Option D. Anonymous screening: This is incorrect because refers to a type of medical testing where individuals are tested for a condition (such as HIV) without providing any personal identifying information. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are the components of Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme except: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 6 health functionaries

 

  • Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) or Intensified Iron Plus Initiative launched in 2018 uses a strategic framework called the 6x6x6 strategy. 
  • This includes 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms. 
  • The program does not include "6 health functionaries" as a component.

 

The 6x6x6 strategy includes:

 

1. 6 beneficiaries:

 

  • Children aged 6-59 months
  • Children aged 5-9 years
  • Adolescents aged 10-19 years
  • Women of reproductive age (20-49 years, non-pregnant, non-lactating)
  • Pregnant women
  • Lactating women

 

2. 6 interventions:

 

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation
  • Deworming (biannually with albendazole)
  • Behavior change communication
  • Iron fortified foods
  • Testing and treatment of anemia
  • Increasing awareness about non-nutritional causes of anemia

 

3. 6 institutional mechanisms for program implementation and monitoring

 

  • The main aim of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program is to reduce the prevalence of anemia by 3 percentage points per year among children, adolescents, and women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) between 2018-2022.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Anemia Mukt Bharat program follows a 6x6x6 strategy which includes 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms, but does not include 6 health functionaries.

 

 

IFA TABLETS [Anemia Mukt Bharat]

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for uncomplicated malaria? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Artemether

 

According to the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Program guidelines, artemisinin derivatives like artemether should never be given alone as it promotes resistance. For uncomplicated malaria treatment in India, the protocol depends on the Plasmodium species. 

 

  • For P. vivax and P. ovale, chloroquine is used along with primaquine. 
  • For P. falciparum or P. malariae, artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) is used along with primaquine.

 

In other parts of India artesunate is combined with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine and primaquine, while in northeast India, artemether is combined with lumefantrine and primaquine. Using artemether alone is explicitly prohibited by the program as it can lead to drug resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artemisinin derivatives like artemether should never be given alone for malaria treatment as they promote resistance. They must always be used in combination therapy (ACT).

Blinding, Inclusion and Exclusion, Randomization, Analysis,
Inclusion and Exclusion, Randomization, Blinding, Analysis
Inclusion and Exclusion, Blinding, Randomization, Analysis

questions.text: Among the following, mark the correct sequence of steps for a Randomized controlled trial (RCT)? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Inclusion and Exclusion, Randomization, Blinding, Analysis

 

  • The correct sequence for the steps of a Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) is first defining the inclusion and exclusion criteria, then randomization, followed by blinding, and finally analysis of results. 
  • This sequence follows the logical flow of conducting an RCT.
  • RCT protocol includes first making a protocol that defines aims, objectives, and hypothesis. 
  • Then the steps proceed as: 
    1. Defining the target population
    2. Making inclusion and exclusion criteria
    3. Randomization
    4. Blinding of intervention 
    5. Analysis of results

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of steps in conducting a Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): defining inclusion and exclusion criteria, randomization, blinding, and finally analysis.

choices.text: Universal Health Coverage aims to provide free health care services to all, regardless of the available resources in the country.
Universal Health Coverage aims to provide services despite having unregulated and fragmented healthcare delivery systems.
Universal Health Coverage prioritizes the safety of resources in a low-resource setting.
Universal Health Coverage targets primary health care delivery based on the needs of the population.

questions.text: Which of the following is the challenge faced in the operationalization of the concept of Universal Health Coverage (UHC)? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Universal Health Coverage aims to provide services despite having unregulated and fragmented healthcare delivery systems.

 

  • Universal Health Coverage faces challenges at four different levels. 
  • One of the main challenges in operationalizing UHC is related to the delivery of services due to unregulated and fragmented healthcare delivery systems.
  • This is highlighted as the "biggest challenge in operationalization" of UHC.

 

The concept of Universal Health Coverage was given by the high-level expert group committee in 2011. The challenges faced include issues at the 

 

  1. Supervision level (lack of administrative coordination within the ministry of health and family welfare)
  2. Resource creation (inadequate human resources)
  3. Financing (issues at revenue collection, pooling, and purchasing levels), 
  4. Delivery of services (due to unregulated and fragmented healthcare delivery systems)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main challenge in operationalizing Universal Health Coverage (UHC) is the delivery of services due to unregulated and fragmented healthcare delivery systems.

questions.text: All of the following viral vaccines are types of Live vaccines except: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hepatitis B vaccine

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is not a live vaccine. Hepatitis B vaccine was earlier available as a killed form, but nowadays it is available as a subunit recombinant plasma-derived or yeast-derived vaccine. This makes it a subunit vaccine, not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of vaccines

questions.text: All of the following are examples of passive immunity except: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Toxoid

 

Passive immunity refers to the transfer of ready-made antibodies from outside the body to provide immediate but temporary protection against infection. It doesn't involve the immune system actively producing antibodies.

 

Toxoid is an example of active immunity, not passive immunity. Toxoids are bacterial toxins that have been modified to destroy their harmful properties while retaining their ability to stimulate antibody production when introduced into the body. When toxoids are administered (like in tetanus or diphtheria vaccines), they stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies, which is the hallmark of active immunity. Active immunity takes time to develop but provides long-lasting protection.

 

Passive immunity involves preformed immunity from outside that is directly transferred to the body in the form of immunoglobulins or through mother-to-child transmission. Examples include immunoglobulin A (IgA), antitoxins, and monoclonal antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toxoids (like those used in tetanus and diphtheria vaccines) stimulate active immunity rather than providing passive immunity.

questions.text: Culture medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis is? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Lowenstein-Jensen medium

 

  • Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the most commonly used culture medium for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. 
  • LJ medium has been used since very old times for the culture of M. tuberculosis.
  • The NTEP (National TB Elimination Program) guidelines also recommend the use of LJ medium as one of the diagnostic methods for tuberculosis along with other methods like ZN staining, LED fluorescence microscopy, automated liquid culture (ALC) systems like BACTEC, and rapid molecular diagnostic tests like CBNAAT. 
  • LJ medium provides solid support for the growth of M. tuberculosis, which typically takes 4-8 weeks due to the slow-growing nature of the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muller Hinton agar: This is incorrect. Muller Hinton agar is mainly used for antibiotic susceptibility testing of non-fastidious bacteria, particularly for routine susceptibility testing of commonly isolated rapid-growing aerobic or facultative organisms. It is not suitable for culturing M. tuberculosis which requires special media for growth due to its slow-growing and fastidious nature.

 

Option B. Blood agar: This is incorrect. Blood agar is a general-purpose enriched medium used to isolate fastidious organisms and detect hemolytic activity. It contains mammalian blood (usually sheep or horse blood) and is not suitable for the isolation of M. tuberculosis, which requires specialized media.

 

Option C. Sabouraud's agar: This is incorrect. Sabouraud's agar is primarily used for the cultivation of fungi, dermatophytes, and yeasts. It contains peptone, dextrose, and agar with a pH of 5.6, which is favorable for fungal growth but inhibits bacterial growth. It is not suitable for the isolation of M. tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lowenstein-Jensen medium as the traditional solid culture medium used for the isolation and identification of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: All of the following are effective modalities for the prevention of spread of COVID-19 diseases except? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Ivermectin

 

  • Ivermectin has no role in the prevention or treatment of COVID-19 disease.
  • "Studies have shown Ivermectin has no role in the prevention or the treatment of COVID-19 disease." 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mask use: This is an effective preventive measure for COVID-19. N95 masks and triple layer surgical masks as helping in prevention by creating a physical barrier that blocks respiratory droplets which may contain the virus.

 

Option B. Cough etiquette: This is an effective preventive measure. Cough etiquette involves not sneezing or coughing openly but rather doing it in a handkerchief or in the elbow, which prevents the spread of respiratory droplets containing the virus.

 

Option D. Covid vaccine: Vaccines are effective in preventing COVID-19. "COVID vaccines like Covishield, Covaxin prevent COVID and reduce hospitalization and death rates." Vaccines work by training the immune system to recognize and fight the virus before exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivermectin has no proven role in the prevention or treatment of COVID-19 disease despite early speculation, while mask use, cough etiquette, and COVID-19 vaccines are proven effective preventive measures.

choices.text: NSAIDS are useful to cure the symptoms
Condoms should be used during intercourse and pregnancy should be avoided
Plasmapheresis has a role in management

questions.text: True regarding prevention of Zika virus is? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Condoms should be used during intercourse and pregnancy should be avoided

 

  • The correct statement regarding prevention of Zika virus is that condoms should be used during intercourse and pregnancy should be avoided.
  • Zika virus can be transmitted not only through the bite of Aedes mosquito but also through body fluids, especially sexual fluids. 
  • The virus is known to have teratogenic effects on fetus.
  • If a pregnant woman is infected with Zika virus, it can lead to serious complications like microcephaly, stillbirth, abortion, death of the newborn, encephalitis, and Guillain-Barre syndrome. 
  • Therefore, it is recommended that pregnancy should be avoided for at least three months after Zika virus infection. 
  • Condoms serve as a barrier method to prevent sexual transmission of the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NSAIDS are useful to cure the symptoms: This is incorrect. NSAIDs are contraindicated in Zika virus management as they increase the chances of hemorrhagic tendency. Acetyl salicylic acid and NSAIDs are not allowed according to the National Center for Disease Control of India guidelines for the management of Zika virus.

 

Option C. A good vaccine is available: This is incorrect. Currently, there is no approved vaccine available for Zika virus. 

 

Option D. Plasmapheresis has a role in management: This is incorrect. Plasmapheresis has a limited role, and that too only in cases of Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is a rare complication of Zika virus infection. It is not a standard management approach for Zika virus disease itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preventive measures for Zika virus infection, including the importance of condom use during intercourse and avoiding pregnancy due to the risk of teratogenic effects on the fetus.

questions.text: A cotton swab, pus stained, is disposed in which color of BMW management category? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Yellow category

 

  • According to the latest BMW (Biomedical Waste Management) guidelines 2017-2018, biomedical waste is categorized into four main categories based on the type of waste and its disposal method. 
  • The yellow category includes human anatomical waste, animal waste, soiled waste (which includes cotton, gauge pieces, bandages, dressings), discarded medicines, and chemical waste.
  • Cotton swabs that are stained with pus are classified as soiled waste and therefore should be disposed of in the yellow category. 
  • The yellow category waste is typically disposed of through incineration (at 1200°C) or plasma pyrolysis. 
  • In some specific cases, especially at the PHC level, deep burial may also be used for certain types of yellow category waste.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red category: Incorrect. The red category is meant for solid/contaminated (recyclable) waste including plastic and rubber items such as tubings, catheters, and cannulas. 

 

 

Option C. White category: Incorrect. The white category is specifically designated for waste sharps such as needles, surgical blades, and scalpels.

 

 

Option D. Blue category: Incorrect. The blue category is for glassware, orthopedic metallic body implants, and other items from ENT, dental, cardio-thoracic, and vascular surgery. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cotton swabs stained with pus are classified as soiled waste and should be disposed of in the yellow category of biomedical waste management.

questions.text: The Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing which of the following conditions? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute severe ulcerative colitis

 

The Truelove and Witt criteria are specifically used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis. These criteria help classify the disease into mild, moderate, or severe categories.


Another set of criteria called the Travis criteria is used to assess treatment response and predict the risk of progression to surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalitis: Incorrect because encephalitis has its own specific diagnostic criteria and severity assessment tools that focus on neurological symptoms and findings.

 

Option C. ARDS: Incorrect because ARDS is diagnosed and classified using the Berlin criteria (2012), which primarily use the P/F ratio (PaO2/FiO2) with a PEEP of at least 5 cm H2O.

 

Option D. Acute pancreatitis: Incorrect because acute pancreatitis has scoring systems for severity assessment, such as Ranson's criteria or the APACHE II score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis.

 

Truelove and Witt's Criteria for Severity of Ulcerative Colitis

questions.text: Nadas criteria include all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Raised Trop T level

 

Nadas criteria, proposed by Hungarian cardiologist Dr. Alexander Nadas in the 1950s–60s, are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease. The criteria require at least one major and two minor criteria for diagnosis. Major criteria include systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, presence of congestive heart failure, and cyanosis. Minor criteria include grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal chest X-ray, abnormal ECG, and abnormal blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nadas criteria are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease, which includes both major criteria (systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, CCF, cyanosis) and minor criteria (grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal X-ray, abnormal ECG, abnormal BP).

questions.text: Which of the following viruses spreads predominantly through water? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HAV (Hepatitis A Virus)

 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) primarily spreads through the fecal-oral route and contaminated water. It is one of the main viral pathogens that uses water as its predominant transmission route. The virus is highly stable in water and sewage, making waterborne transmission a significant public health concern, especially in areas with poor sanitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HCV (Hepatitis C Virus): Incorrect because HCV spreads predominantly through the parenteral route, particularly through needlestick injuries, blood transfusions, and surgical procedures.

 

Option C. HDV (Hepatitis D Virus): Incorrect because HDV is a dependent virus that requires the presence of HBV for its replication and transmission. It cannot spread independently through water.

 

Option D. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus): Incorrect because HBV primarily spreads through vertical transmission (mother to child) in developing countries like India. While sexual transmission is possible, it's relatively rare. It does not spread through water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A virus spreads predominantly through the fecal-oral route and contaminated water, unlike other hepatitis viruses, which have different primary modes of transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used to differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other conditions? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of diarrhea

 

Diarrhea cannot reliably differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other forms of arthritis because it can be present in multiple arthritic conditions. Diarrhea could indicate:

 

  • Reactive arthritis following gastrointestinal infection
  • Inflammatory bowel disease-associated arthritis
  • Post-viral arthritis
  • Other forms of seronegative spondyloarthropathies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enthesitis:

 

  • Enthesitis (inflammation at sites where tendons/ligaments insert into bone) is a characteristic feature of psoriatic arthritis
  • It helps differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other forms like rheumatoid arthritis

 

Option C. Dactylitis:

 

  • Dactylitis ("sausage digits") is highly characteristic of psoriatic arthritis
  • Represents inflammation of the entire digit with soft tissue swelling
  • Helps differentiate from other forms where dactylitis is uncommon

 

Option D. Nail pitting:

 

  • Nail changes are seen in 80–90% of psoriatic arthritis patients
  • Nail pitting is a characteristic finding that helps distinguish psoriatic arthritis
  • A valuable diagnostic feature when present

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enthesitis, dactylitis, and nail changes are characteristic features that help diagnose psoriatic arthritis. Diarrhea is a nonspecific symptom that can occur in multiple forms of arthritis and cannot be used as a differentiating feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered ineffective in the prevention of COVID-19? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivermectin

 

Ivermectin has been extensively studied during the COVID-19 pandemic but has not demonstrated any proven efficacy in preventing COVID-19 infection. Despite creating headlines during the pandemic period, clinical studies have not provided strong evidence that ivermectin reduces the risk of transmission or acquisition of COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mask: Wearing masks has been proven to be an effective preventive measure in reducing the transmission of COVID-19 by providing a physical barrier against respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vaccine: Vaccines serve as pre-exposure prophylaxis and have been demonstrated to be effective in preventing severe COVID-19 infection and reducing transmission.

 

Option D. Cough etiquette: Proper cough etiquette is an important preventive measure that helps reduce the spread of respiratory droplets containing the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivermectin, despite being widely discussed during the pandemic, has not been proven effective in preventing COVID-19 infection, unlike established preventive measures such as masks, vaccines, and proper cough etiquette.

questions.text: According to KDIGO staging of chronic kidney disease (CKD), what is the GFR range for stage 3b? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30–44 mL/min/1.73m²

 

Stage 3b CKD is defined by a GFR range of 30–44 mL/min/1.73m². CKD stage 3 is divided into two subcategories:

 

  • Stage 3a: GFR 45–59 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 3b: GFR 30–44 mL/min/1.73m²

 

Educational Objective:

 

GFR ranges for CKD staging:

 

  • Stage 1: >90 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 2: 60–89 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 3a: 45–59 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 3b: 30–44 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 4: 15–29 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 5: <15 mL/min/1.73m²

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports episodes of palpitations and dizziness, particularly following physical activity such as playing tennis. She has experienced these symptoms multiple times over the last two years. ECG is taken and it is shown. Based on her presentation and the accompanying ECG findings, which of the following diagnoses is most likely? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia

 

The diagnosis of Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD) is based on:

 

  1. A young patient with exertional palpitations and dizziness
  2. ECG shows characteristic epsilon waves—multiple wavelet-like appearances at the J point
  3. T-wave inversions in V1–V4 indicating RV strain/dysfunction
  4. This condition involves fibro-fatty replacement of right ventricular myocardium in the "triangle of dysplasia"

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brugada syndrome: Incorrect. It typically causes arrhythmias during rest, not exertion. ECG shows characteristic ST elevation with "coved" appearance in V1–V3, not epsilon waves.

 

Option B. Uhl anomaly: Incorrect. It involves congenital absence of right ventricular musculature, which doesn't match the ECG findings or clinical presentation.

 

Option C. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy: Incorrect. ECG would show LVH with Sokolov-Lyon criteria (S in V1 + R in V5/V6 > 35mm) and septal Q waves in lateral leads.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon waves on ECG are pathognomonic for ARVD, which typically presents in young people with exertional symptoms and can be a cause of sudden cardiac death, particularly common in Italy. The condition involves desmosomal mutations and progressive RV dysfunction.

questions.text: A scuba diver surfaces rapidly, soon experiencing joint pain, dizziness, and difficulty breathing indicating decompression sickness. Which of the following is not associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Haemodilution

 

Decompression sickness (DCS), or Caisson disease, occurs due to rapid ascent during diving, based on Henry's law. When pressure decreases rapidly, dissolved gases (particularly nitrogen) form bubbles in blood and tissues. These bubbles can cause vascular occlusions, organ damage, and various systemic manifestations including hemoconcentration—not haemodilution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulopathy: Incorrect. Coagulopathy can occur in DCS due to endothelial damage from gas bubbles, causing a DIC-like picture in 2–3% of cases.

 

Option B. Hearing loss: Incorrect. Hearing loss, though rare, is a possible manifestation of DCS due to inner ear involvement.

 

Option D. Visual loss: Incorrect. Visual disturbances and loss can occur in DCS due to bubble formation affecting the visual pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decompression sickness leads to hemoconcentration (not haemodilution) and can present with joint pain ("the bends"), neurological symptoms, coagulopathy, and sensory organ dysfunction including vision and hearing loss.

questions.text: High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA) is not caused by: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diarrhea

 

Diarrhea causes Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), not High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA). There are only three main causes of NAGMA, remembered by the mnemonic "DRS":

 

  • D: Diarrhea
  • R: RTA (Renal Tubular Acidosis – types 1, 2, and 4)
  • S: Saline administration (causing hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): Incorrect. DKA is a classic cause of HAGMA. It leads to accumulation of ketone bodies, causing high anion gap.

 

Option C. Acute renal failure: Incorrect. Renal failure causes HAGMA due to accumulation of organic acids and decreased acid excretion.

 

Option D. Inborn errors of metabolism: Incorrect. Most inborn errors of metabolism cause HAGMA through accumulation of organic acids.

 

The causes of HAGMA can be remembered using the mnemonic "GOLDMARK":

 

  • G: Glycol (ethylene glycol)
  • O: Oxoproline (paracetamol metabolite)
  • L: L-lactate
  • D: D-lactate (short bowel syndrome)
  • M: Methanol
  • A: Aspirin
  • R: Renal failure
  • K: Ketoacidosis (diabetic, alcoholic, starvation)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diarrhea causes Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), not High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with weight loss, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusion. Her HRCT shows a "tree-in-bud" pattern, indicating lung consolidation and effusion. Analysis of pleural fluid reveals high adenosine deaminase (ADA) levels with a predominance of lymphocytes. What is the most likely finding on lymph node biopsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing epithelioid granuloma

 

This is a classic presentation of tuberculosis (TB):

 

  • "Tree-in-bud" appearance on HRCT indicates endobronchial spread — a hallmark of active pulmonary TB.
  • Mediastinal lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion with lymphocyte predominance further support a tuberculous etiology.
  • High ADA (>40 U/L) in pleural fluid is a strong indicator of TB pleuritis.

 

The most characteristic lymph node biopsy finding in TB is:

 

  • Necrotizing (caseating) epithelioid granulomas
  •  Composed of epithelioid cells (from activated macrophages), Langhans giant cells, and central caseous necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal hyphae surrounded by lymphocytes:  Seen in invasive fungal infections (e.g., aspergillosis, histoplasmosis), more common in immunocompromised individuals; not typically associated with high ADA.

 

Option B. Anthracosis pigment: Black carbon pigment in lungs/lymph nodes from pollution or smoking. Not pathological in itself and doesn’t cause systemic symptoms or effusion.

 

Option D. Reactive hyperplasia: Seen in viral or nonspecific bacterial infections. No granulomas or caseation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young woman with systemic symptoms, tree-in-bud pattern, lymphocytic pleural effusion, and high ADA, TB is the most likely diagnosis. The hallmark histopathological finding is a necrotizing epithelioid granuloma.

questions.text: Which of the following groups is not considered a core risk factor group for HIV transmission? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Long-distance truck drivers

 

The core risk groups for HIV transmission are populations that primarily transmit the disease to bridge populations, who then transmit it to the general population. In endemic countries like India, addressing these core groups is crucial for reducing HIV transmission rates. The core high-risk groups include female sex workers, men who have sex with men (MSM), transgender populations, and injectable drug users.

 

Long-distance truck drivers are considered a bridge population rather than a core risk group. While they are important in the transmission chain, they act as intermediaries between core risk groups and the general population.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Female sex workers: Incorrect. This is a core risk group according to NACO 2024 data and is one of the primary populations targeted for HIV prevention.

 

Option B. IV drug abusers: Incorrect. Injectable drug users are considered a core high-risk group for HIV transmission.

 

Option C. Male having sex with male (MSM): Incorrect. MSM is a core high-risk group that requires focused intervention for HIV prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The distinction between core risk groups and bridge populations in HIV transmission:

 

Core risk groups include:

 

  1. Female sex workers
  2. Men who have sex with men (MSM)
  3. Transgender populations
  4. Injectable drug users

 

Bridge populations, like truck drivers and migrants, serve as intermediaries in disease transmission.

questions.text:
Which of the following vaccines is generally not recommended for individuals over 65 years of age? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Hepatitis B
  2. Influenza
  3. Human papillomavirus (HPV)
  4. Pneumococcal
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c only

 

HPV vaccine is not recommended for individuals over 65 years of age because it is only approved for use up to 45 years of age. The other vaccines mentioned can be safely and effectively administered to elderly individuals based on their risk factors and previous vaccination status.

 

Other Options:

 

a. Hepatitis B vaccine: This is conditionally indicated in elderly individuals who have not previously received the vaccine and have risk factors.

 

b. Influenza vaccine: This is strongly recommended annually for elderly individuals as they are at high risk for complications from influenza infection.

 

d. Pneumococcal vaccine: This is a crucial vaccine for elderly individuals. The current recommendation in India is to give PCV13 followed by PPSV23 to provide comprehensive protection against pneumococcal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The age-based restrictions for HPV vaccination (approved only up to age 45) and the core vaccines recommended for elderly individuals (pneumococcal, influenza, and conditional hepatitis B vaccination).

 

The only non-recommended vaccine in this list for those over 65 years is HPV, while pneumococcal, influenza, and hepatitis B vaccines may all be indicated based on individual risk factors and previous vaccination status.

questions.text: Which JAK inhibitor drug is recommended for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in a patient who is not responding well to TNF-alpha blockers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tofacitinib

 

Tofacitinib is a JAK (Janus Kinase) inhibitor that is specifically approved for treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in patients who have failed or are not responding to TNF-alpha blockers. It represents a different mechanism of action compared to TNF-alpha inhibitors, making it a suitable alternative for patients who have failed anti-TNF therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ustekinumab: Incorrect. While it can be used in inflammatory bowel disease, it is a combined anti-IL-12 and IL-23 blocker, not a JAK inhibitor.

 

Option B. Etanercept: Incorrect. This is an anti-TNF drug, and the question specifically asks about patients who are not responding to TNF-alpha blockers.

 

Option C. Vedolizumab: Incorrect. This is an α4β7 integrin blocker used in IBD, but not a JAK inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tofacitinib is the JAK inhibitor approved for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in patients who have failed TNF-alpha blockers. Other JAK inhibitors used in rheumatological diseases include baricitinib and upadacitinib.

choices.text: Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS
IV immunoglobulins is the first line of treatment
Areflexia in the weaker arm is a mandatory diagnostic criteria

questions.text: Regarding Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) in children, which of the following statements is false? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS

 

Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange, PEX) is a well-established and effective treatment in GBS, including in refractory or severe cases. It is considered equivalent in efficacy to IVIG and may be used in patients not responding to IVIG (controversial, and sequential administration of PEX after IVIG is not recommended, but some clinicians try on a case-by-case basis), or if IVIG is contraindicated or unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV immunoglobulins is the first line of treatment: Correct. IVIG can be used as first-line treatment, having equal efficacy to plasma exchange in GBS management.

 

Option C. Areflexia in the weaker arm is a mandatory diagnostic criteria: Correct. Areflexia in the weaker arm is a mandatory diagnostic criterion according to Brighton criteria. GBS is a demyelinating disease affecting large fibers that form the basis of reflex arcs.

 

Option D. Albumino-cytological dissociation of CSF is characterstic: Correct. It is a classic feature of GBS, with high protein in CSF but normal cell count (<10 cells). Any cell count >50 essentially rules out GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmapheresis and IVIG are effective treatment options for GBS, including refractory cases, with neither being superior to the other. Never use immunosuppression or steroids in acute GBS.

 

 

Level of diagnostic certainty in Brighton criteria for GBS

choices.text: Not associated with rise in Creatinine

questions.text: Acute graft rejection in a kidney transplant patient is indicated by: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Any rise in creatinine

 

In modern transplant medicine, acute graft rejection often presents subtly due to powerful immunosuppression regimens. The most common presentation of acute rejection in current clinical practice is an asymptomatic rise in serum creatinine. According to the definition, there should be at least a 25% increase in serum creatinine to diagnose acute rejection. However, in cases where antibody-mediated rejection (ABMR) is suspected, any rise in serum creatinine can lead to a diagnosis or at least a suspicion of acute rejection.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Creatinine raised by 5%: Incorrect because acute rejection is characterized by a rise in creatinine levels. Normal creatinine would not indicate rejection.

 

Option C. Creatinine raised by 10%: While this would also indicate rejection, the question asks for the earliest indicator, and any rise in creatinine (including 5%) should raise suspicion.

 

Option D. Not associated with rise in Creatinine: Incorrect because there is a clear association between creatinine rises and acute rejection. This is one of the most reliable indicators of rejection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute graft rejection in kidney transplant patients typically presents with asymptomatic elevation in serum creatinine. Traditional symptoms like fever and graft tenderness are less common due to current immunosuppression protocols. Any rise in creatinine should prompt consideration of acute rejection.

questions.text:
LMN lesions are associated with? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Decrease in muscle tone
  2. Spastic paralysis
  3. Babinski positivity
  4. Fasciculations
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4

 

Lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions are characterized by two features:

 

1. Decreased in muscle tone (flaccidity) – Due to interruption of the normal reflex arc

 

4. Fasciculations – Spontaneous twitching of muscle fibers due to denervation

 

Other Options:

 

2. Spastic paralysis is a characteristic of upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions

 

3. Babinski positivity sign (upgoing plantar response) is also a feature of UMN lesions

 

These features occur due to loss of inhibitory signals from upper motor neurons, which is not the case in LMN lesions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lower motor neuron lesions are characterized by:

 

  1. Decreased muscle tone (flaccidity)
  2. Fasciculations (muscle twitching)
  3. Absence of spasticity and Babinski sign (which are UMN signs)

choices.text: BP should be checked multiple times before administering anti-hypertensives
In haemorrhagic stroke, you should aggressively treat with intravenous anti-hypertensives
In haemorrhagic stroke, BP should be reduced to 160/100 mmHg with anti-hypertensives
BP should be reduced immediately to less than 140/90 mmHg in ischemic stroke

questions.text: A patient presented with altered sensorium and his BP was 220/110 mmHg. He also had one episode of vomiting and on examination has weakness in the left upper and lower limbs. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BP should be reduced immediately to less than 140/90 mmHg in ischemic stroke

 

In acute ischemic stroke, blood pressure is often elevated as a physiological response to maintain perfusion to the ischemic penumbra. Unless:

 

  • The patient is receiving thrombolysis, in which case BP should be <185/110 mmHg, or
  • The BP is severely elevated (>220/120 mmHg),

 

You should not acutely lower the blood pressure. Lowering it to <140/90 mmHg immediately is contraindicated, as it can worsen cerebral hypoperfusion and enlarge the infarct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BP should be checked multiple times before administering anti-hypertensives: Correct. Rechecking BP ensures accuracy and avoids overtreatment of transient spikes. Stroke protocols depend on consistently high values.

 

Option B. In haemorrhagic stroke, you should aggressively treat with intravenous anti-hypertensives: Correct. Rapid BP control reduces ongoing bleeding and hematoma expansion. Agents like labetalol and nicardipine are preferred.

 

Option C. In haemorrhagic stroke, BP should be reduced to 160/100 mmHg with anti-hypertensives: Correct. Target BP of <160/100 mmHg is generally accepted to balance the risk of further bleeding with maintaining cerebral perfusion. Even though it is not a specific recommendation in haemorrhagic stroke, it is acceptable.

 

Trials that are important –

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific blood pressure targets in acute stroke:

 

  • General recommendation in hypertensive emergency: Reduce BP by 25% in 1st hour, then target around 160/100 mmHg within 2–6 hours
  • Ischemic stroke with thrombolysis: <185/110 mmHg
  • Ischemic stroke without thrombolysis: <220/120 mmHg
  • Hemorrhagic Stroke: Controversial – SBP <140 mmHg (INTERACT2) vs. 140–180 mmHg (WHO 2021)

choices.text: Targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused
Perform emergent cardiac intervention if ST elevation is present in the ECG
Maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management of patients who have achieved return of spontaneous circulation following CPR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused

 

In post-resuscitation care after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), targeted temperature management (TTM) should be maintained between 33–36°C, not below 33°C. Lower temperatures increase the risk of coagulopathy, bleeding, and infections like pneumonia. For patients with high bleeding risk or coagulopathy, the target should be 36–37.5°C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target SpO₂ >94%: Initially, target SpO₂ should be >92%, and once intubated and on mechanical ventilation, the target should be >94%. Overall target range is 92–98%.

 

Option C. Perform emergent cardiac intervention if ST elevation is present in the ECG: If STEMI is identified as the cause of cardiac arrest, immediate cardiac catheterization should be performed within 2 hours as it's a reversible cause.

 

Option D. Maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg: This is the minimum MAP that should be achieved using vasopressors and IV fluids. The ideal MAP range is 80–100 mmHg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-resuscitation care after ROSC, targeted temperature management should be maintained between 33–36°C, with higher targets (36–37.5°C) for patients at risk of bleeding or coagulopathy. Temperature should never be targeted below 33°C due to increased complications.

choices.text: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high
Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high

 

Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus does not have a high association with APS-1. The association is low and not a characteristic feature of APS-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoparathyroidism is common: Hypoparathyroidism is common and is part of the classic triad of APS-1.

 

Option C. Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high: Mucocutaneous candidiasis is highly associated with APS-1. It is typically the first manifestation, appearing in infancy, and is also the most common manifestation due to underlying immunodeficiency.

 

Option D. Early onset in infancy: Early onset in infancy is characteristic of APS-1, with mucocutaneous candidiasis typically being the first manifestation to appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic triad of APS-1:

 

  1. Mucocutaneous candidiasis (most common and earliest manifestation)
  2. Hypoparathyroidism
  3. Addison's disease

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24 hr urinary total metanephrines

 

The 24-hour urinary metanephrines test is considered the gold standard and first-line test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. The test should include fractionated catecholamines for comprehensive evaluation. This test is preferred due to its high sensitivity and specificity in detecting these rare neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MIBG scan: This is a nuclear medicine imaging test that can be useful for localizing pheochromocytoma and ruling out multifocal or metastatic disease, but it's not the initial diagnostic test. It's typically performed after biochemical confirmation of the disease.

 

Option C. Plasma catecholamines: While plasma catecholamines can be measured as part of the routine testing, they are not as reliable as urinary metanephrines due to their fluctuating levels and potential for false positives.

 

Option D. MRI of the whole abdomen: This is an imaging study used for tumor localization after biochemical confirmation of pheochromocytoma. It's not appropriate as an initial diagnostic test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 24-hour urinary metanephrines test with fractionated catecholamines is the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. Plasma metanephrines can be considered in high-risk populations (such as those with a family history or genetic syndromes).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thrombosis

 

TTP is characterized by a pentad of clinical findings:

 

  1. Fever
  2. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with schistocytes/helmet cells
  3. Thrombocytopenia
  4. Renal failure
  5. Neurological involvement

 

TTP is caused by ADAMTS13 deficiency, which leads to excessive formation of platelet microthrombi in small vessels. While microvascular thrombosis occurs, macrovascular thrombosis is not a defining feature of TTP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic pentad of TTP consists of fever, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, and neurological involvement. Macrovascular thrombosis is not a defining feature of TTP, unlike in conditions such as antiphospholipid syndrome, where both macro- and microvascular thrombosis can occur.

choices.text: Pathergy test is a criterion as per the ISG diagnostic criteria
Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis
Aphthous ulcers occur similar to Crohn’s disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding Behçet's disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis

 

Behçet's disease is a chronic, multisystem vasculitis characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, ocular inflammation, skin lesions, and more. Genital ulcers in Behçet's typically occur on the scrotum in males and the vulva in females. The dorsum of the penis is rarely involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathergy test is a criterion as per the ISG diagnostic criteria: Correct. The International Study Group (ISG) includes the pathergy test (a sterile pustule at the site of needle prick) as a supportive criterion.

 

Option C. Aphthous ulcers occur similar to Crohn’s disease: Correct. The oral ulcers of Behçet’s resemble aphthous ulcers and can be clinically indistinguishable from those seen in Crohn’s disease.

 

Option D. Bilateral pan uveitis: Correct. Ocular involvement is common and may present as anterior uveitis, posterior uveitis, or pan uveitis—often bilateral and sight-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Behçet’s disease typically affects the scrotum, vulva, eyes, and oral mucosa. Ulcers on the dorsum of the penis are atypical, making option B the incorrect statement.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, and hematuria. The mother tells you that the baby also suffered from bloody diarrhea a few days back. Which is likely microorganism to be isolated from the stool sample? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. coli O157:H7

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) based on the triad of:

 

  • Hematuria
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • History of bloody diarrhea

 

E. coli O157:H7, also known as Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) or Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC), is the most common causative organism of HUS, particularly in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shigella flexneri

 

  • Incorrect because while it can cause bloody diarrhea, it is more commonly associated with reactive arthritis rather than HUS.
  • Does not typically cause the combination of hematuria and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Salmonella enteritis

 

  • Incorrect as it is primarily associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease.
  • Not typically associated with HUS.

 

Option D. Aeromonas

 

  • Incorrect as it typically causes simple diarrhea without the complications of HUS.
  • Does not produce Shiga toxin, which is responsible for HUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E. coli O157:H7 is the most common cause of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome in children, typically presenting with bloody diarrhea followed by the triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

choices.text: Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient

 

The glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) is directly proportional to GFR according to the formula. Therefore, a decrease in Kf will lead to a decrease in GFR. The filtration coefficient represents the product of the hydraulic permeability and surface area available for filtration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure will increase GFR by increasing the net filtration pressure gradient.

 

Option B. Increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. An increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure increases GFR by promoting filtration.

 

Option D. Decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure increases GFR by reducing the opposition to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) and GFR are directly proportional, meaning a decrease in Kf causes a decrease in GFR.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are typically associated with glomerular hematuria? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Brown urine
  2. Dysuria absent
  3. Crystals in urine
  4. Edema is rare
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B

 

Glomerular hematuria has specific characteristics that help differentiate it from non-glomerular causes:

 

A. Brown urine: Brown/cola-colored urine is typical of glomerular hematuria due to the presence of RBCs.

 

B. Dysuria absent: Absence of dysuria is characteristic, as there is no urinary tract inflammation or infection.

 

These findings together strongly suggest glomerular origin of hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

C. Crystals in urine: Incorrect. Crystalluria is not a feature of glomerular hematuria. Instead, findings like dysmorphic RBCs, acanthocytes, or RBC casts are characteristic.

 

D. Edema is rare: Incorrect. Edema is common in glomerular diseases, whether nephritic or nephrotic, due to:

 

  • Loss of albumin leading to decreased oncotic pressure
  • Activation of the renin-angiotensin system
  • Underlying inflammatory processes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular hematuria includes brown/cola-colored urine and absence of dysuria, while presence of edema and absence of urinary crystals are other important characteristics.

questions.text: Features of MEN2B are all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parathyroid hyperplasia

 

MEN2B syndrome is characterized by a distinct set of clinical features known as the "4 M's":

 

  1. Marfanoid body habitus
  2. Mucosal neuromas
  3. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  4. Megacolon (Hirschsprung disease)

 

Additionally, pheochromocytoma is also a feature of MEN2B. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hyperplasia is NOT a component of MEN2B syndrome, while the characteristic features include medullary thyroid carcinoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and megacolon (the 4 M's).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a stimulus for catecholamine synthesis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperglycemia

 

Hyperglycemia is not a stimulus for catecholamine synthesis. Physiologically, hyperglycemia can suppress catecholamine synthesis. While hyperglycemic emergencies may indirectly lead to increased catecholamines due to shock and osmotic diuresis, hyperglycemia itself does not directly stimulate catecholamine production. Hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia) is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release, leading to autonomic symptoms like tremors, palpitations, anxiety, and sweating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoking: Incorrect. Smoking is a known stimulus for catecholamine synthesis. Nicotine triggers the release of catecholamines from the adrenal medulla and sympathetic nerve endings.

 

Option B. Standing posture: Incorrect. Orthostatic changes require a catecholamine surge to prevent orthostatic hypotension when a person stands up. This is a normal physiological response.

 

Option D. Exercise: Incorrect. Exercise is one of the major physiological stimuli for catecholamine synthesis. Physical activity requires increased sympathetic activation and catecholamine production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia) is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release, leading to autonomic symptoms like tremors, palpitations, anxiety, and sweating. Hyperglycemia does not stimulate catecholamine synthesis.

questions.text: Match the following hormones to receptors: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

  • (1-B) Acetylcholine works through ligand-gated channels (like other neurotransmitters such as serotonin and GABA)
  • (2-A) Insulin functions via the receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) pathway, with insulin receptor substrate (IRS) as its substrate
  • (3-D) Growth hormone operates through the JAK-STAT pathway (non-receptor tyrosine kinase pathway)
  • (4-C) Thyroxine, being lipid-soluble, acts through nuclear receptors

 

Educational Objective:

 

The distinct receptor mechanisms for different hormone classes:

 

  • Acetylcholine → Ligand-gated channels
  • Insulin → Tyrosine kinase pathway
  • Growth hormone → JAK-STAT pathway
  • Thyroxine → Nuclear receptors

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of NAME syndrome? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ebstein's anomaly

 

NAME syndrome is now recognized as part of the Carney complex, which falls under Multiple Endocrine Other Organ Neoplasia (MEON). The NAME acronym stands for:

 

  • N: Nevi (blue nevi – skin manifestation)
  • A: Atrial myxoma
  • M: Myxoid neurofibroma
  • E: Ephelides (freckles)

 

Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


NAME syndrome (now part of Carney complex) consists of Nevi (blue), Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibroma, and Ephelides (freckles). Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

choices.text: Making a fist with forearm exercise
Tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible
Should be collected in sitting position & better to avoid prolonged immobilization
Sample should be analyzed within 15–30 min of collection

questions.text: Which of the following should be prevented when collecting a blood sample for serum calcium? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Making a fist with forearm exercise

 

Making a fist and performing forearm exercises during blood collection for calcium measurement should be prevented, as it can cause muscle ischemia and erroneously increase the calcium value in the sample. This is a practical consideration during blood collection when lab personnel often ask patients to make a fist and perform repetitive movements to better visualize veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible: The tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible to avoid erroneously high calcium values. In some cases, for repeat calcium or PTH measurements, it's recommended to avoid tourniquet use altogether.

 

Option C. Should be collected in sitting position & better to avoid prolonged immobilization: Collecting samples in sitting position and avoiding prolonged immobilization is recommended, as standing can increase serum calcium levels. Prolonged sitting/immobilization can also affect values due to bone lysis.

 

Option D. Sample should be analyzed within 15–30 min of collection: Samples should ideally be analyzed within 15–30 minutes of collection. If delay is anticipated, the sample should be kept on ice (good for 2 hours) or centrifuged to obtain plasma/serum (stable at room temperature for 8 hours).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Making a fist and performing forearm exercises during blood collection for calcium measurement should be avoided, as it can falsely elevate calcium levels through muscle ischemia.

choices.text: Decreased action of LPL and increased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL and increased action of HSL
Decreased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL

questions.text: In a patient with diabetes mellitus, the synthesis of TG and VLDL is increased from the liver. What is the cause of the same? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased action of LPL and increased action of HSL

 

In diabetes mellitus, insulin deficiency or resistance leads to two important enzymatic changes:

 

  1. Decreased activity of Lipoprotein Lipase (LPL) – This enzyme normally converts triglycerides in blood to free fatty acids for storage in adipose tissue
  2. Increased activity of Hormone Sensitive Lipase (HSL) – This promotes release of stored triglycerides as free fatty acids from adipose tissue

 

These changes result in:

 

  • Increased triglycerides in blood due to decreased LPL activity
  • Increased lipolysis and ketosis due to increased HSL activity
  • Overall increase in circulating free fatty acids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased action of LPL and increased action of HSL: Insulin resistance/deficiency decreases LPL activity

 

Option C. Decreased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL: HSL activity is increased, not decreased in diabetes

 

Option D. Increased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL: This would increase TG clearance and decrease lipolysis, opposite to what occurs in diabetes

 

Educational Objective:

 

In diabetes mellitus, decreased LPL and increased HSL activities lead to increased triglycerides and VLDL synthesis in the liver, contributing to diabetic dyslipidemia.

questions.text: A patient presents with uveitis and sacroiliitis. What is most likely associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA B27

 

The presentation of uveitis along with sacroiliitis is a classic manifestation of seronegative spondyloarthropathy, which is strongly associated with HLA-B27. These conditions are characterized by:

 

  • Inflammatory back pain
  • Early morning stiffness lasting more than one hour
  • Pain and stiffness that improve with exercise and worsen with rest
  • Anterior uveitis as the most common extra-articular manifestation
  • Sacroiliitis
  • Peripheral arthritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B8: Incorrect. Associated with good prognosis in sarcoidosis, not spondyloarthropathy

 

Option C. HLA B5: Incorrect. Associated with Behçet's disease

 

Option D. HLA B51: Incorrect. Also associated with Behçet's disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B27 is strongly associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies, particularly when patients present with the combination of uveitis and sacroiliitis.

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent Raynaud’s phenomenon. She also complained of thickening of skin in the hands and difficulty in swallowing. What is the diagnosis and immunofluorescence pattern shown? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-centromere pattern; Systemic sclerosis

 

The combination of Raynaud's phenomenon, skin thickening limited to hands (acral areas), and difficulty swallowing points to limited systemic sclerosis (formerly called CREST syndrome). The immunofluorescence image shows a characteristic centromeric pattern with discrete speckles corresponding to centromeres in dividing cells. Anti-centromere antibodies are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, making this pattern diagnostic in this clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nuclear pattern; SLE: Incorrect. The pattern shown is centromeric, not nuclear.

 

Option B. Homogeneous pattern; SLE: Incorrect. Homogeneous patterns are produced by anti-histone and anti-dsDNA antibodies, seen in SLE or drug-induced lupus.

 

Option C. Speckled pattern; Systemic sclerosis: Incorrect. While speckled patterns can be seen in systemic sclerosis (particularly with anti-Scl-70 antibodies in diffuse disease), the image shows a centromeric pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-centromere antibodies producing a centromeric immunofluorescence pattern are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, particularly when presenting with Raynaud's phenomenon and acral skin thickening.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complained of bilateral lower limb numbness. He has a history of low BP and gastrectomy done for gastric cancer a year back. On examination, Romberg test is positive and there is loss of proprioception in both lower limbs. Which of the following deficiency can cause this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

This patient's presentation strongly suggests Vitamin B12 deficiency for several reasons:

 

  1. History of gastrectomy – Loss of stomach leads to loss of intrinsic factor, essential for B12 absorption
  2. Neurological symptoms – Bilateral lower limb numbness
  3. Positive Romberg test and loss of proprioception indicate posterior column involvement, which is characteristic of subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord seen in B12 deficiency
  4. The combination of gastrectomy and neurological symptoms is classic for B12 deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B6 deficiency: While it can cause peripheral neuropathy, it doesn't typically cause posterior column signs

 

Option C. Thiamine deficiency: Primarily causes Wernicke's encephalopathy and cardiovascular symptoms; doesn't typically present with proprioception loss; more commonly seen in alcoholics

 

Option D. Folic acid deficiency: Primarily causes hematological manifestations; does not cause neurological symptoms like B12 deficiency

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrectomy leads to B12 deficiency due to loss of intrinsic factor, and B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, presenting with posterior column signs (proprioception loss and positive Romberg test).

questions.text: All are hereditary causes of thrombosis except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria)

 

PNH is an acquired stem cell disorder, not a hereditary condition. It occurs due to a somatic mutation in the PIG-A gene that produces GPI (glycosyl phosphatidylinositol) anchors. This defect affects proteins CD55 and CD59 (also known as DAF and MIRL respectively), which are important complement regulatory proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein C deficiency: Hereditary cause of thrombosis; Protein C is a natural anticoagulant

 

Option C. Factor V Leiden mutation: Most common inherited cause of thrombophilia

 

Option D. Antithrombin III deficiency: Inherited condition increasing thrombotic risk

 

Educational Objective:

 

PNH is an acquired (not hereditary) stem cell disorder caused by somatic mutations in the PIG-A gene. Protein C deficiency, Factor V Leiden mutation, and Antithrombin III deficiency are hereditary causes of thrombophilia.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of inherited Thrombophilia? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia. This genetic mutation makes Factor V resistant to inactivation by activated Protein C, leading to increased thrombotic risk. It is an autosomal dominant disorder and is particularly common in individuals of European descent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein C deficiency: Less common than Factor V Leiden; leads to increased thrombotic risk

 

Option B. Prothrombin deficiency: A rare inherited coagulation disorder that typically causes bleeding

 

Option D. Antithrombin III deficiency: Relatively rare inherited thrombophilic condition

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia.

questions.text:
In haemolytic anaemia, which of the following is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Urobilinogen is high
  2. Serum conjugated bilirubin is elevated
  3. Serum transaminases are increased
  4. Indirect van den Bergh reaction is positive
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

In haemolytic anaemia, there is increased destruction of red blood cells leading to elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. This results in:

 

1. Urobilinogen is high: Increased urobilinogen in urine due to normal enterohepatic circulation

 

4. Indirect van den Bergh reaction is positive: Positive indirect van den Bergh reaction due to elevated unconjugated bilirubin

 

These findings are characteristic of haemolytic anaemia and help differentiate it from other causes of jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Serum conjugated bilirubin is elevated: Incorrect, as conjugated bilirubin elevation is typically seen in obstructive jaundice or hepatic diseases, not in haemolytic anaemia

 

3. Serum transaminases are increased: Incorrect, as elevated transaminases indicate liver cell damage, which is not a feature of haemolytic anaemia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haemolytic anaemia is characterized by:

 

  • Increased urobilinogen in urine
  • Elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin
  • Positive indirect van den Bergh reaction
  • Normal enterohepatic circulation

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with celiac disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11

 

Celiac disease is associated with specific HLA types – DQ2 (present in 95% of cases) and DQ8. HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11 are not associated with celiac disease. The genetic predisposition to celiac disease is strongly linked to these specific HLA markers, which are essential for disease development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modified Marsh classification: Correct. Used for diagnosing celiac disease via endoscopic biopsies and to monitor improvement on a gluten-free diet.

 

Option B. IgA transglutaminase positivity: Correct. Anti-tissue transglutaminase IgA (anti-tTG IgA) is the most reliable serologic test.

 

Option C. IgG antigliadin positivity: Correct. Although less specific, it is useful especially in IgA-deficient patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is genetically associated with HLA-DQ2 (95% of cases) and HLA-DQ8, not HLA-DQ6 and HLA-DQ11.

questions.text: Which mutation is seen in sickle cell disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glu → Val (6)

 

Sickle cell disease is caused by a specific point mutation at position 6 of the β-globin chain, where glutamic acid (Glu) is replaced by valine (Val).
