This single amino acid substitution leads to the formation of abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS), which polymerizes under deoxygenated conditions, causing red blood cells to become sickle-shaped.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation at position 6 of the β-globin chain, where glutamic acid (Glu) is replaced by valine (Val).

choices.text: Aspiration pneumonia – Upper segment of right lower lobe

questions.text: A 46-year-old diabetic presented with fever, malaise, and cough. His chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial infiltrates – Mycoplasma

 

The chest X-ray shows bilateral patchy infiltrates, particularly in the lower lobes. This pattern is characteristic of atypical pneumonia, specifically Mycoplasma pneumonia. In Mycoplasma infections, infiltrates tend to be interstitial and patchy, not dense consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lobar infiltrates – Pyogenic pneumonia: Incorrect. Pyogenic pneumonia typically shows dense consolidation with air bronchograms in a lobar distribution

 

Option B. Hilar infiltrates – Malignancy: Incorrect. Hilar regions appear normal. Malignancy typically presents with hilar masses or lymphadenopathy

 

Option D. Aspiration pneumonia – Upper segment of right lower lobe: Incorrect. Although aspiration pneumonia often affects this segment, this patient shows no risk factors for aspiration and has bilateral infiltrates

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral patchy interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray, along with fever, malaise, and cough, are characteristic of atypical pneumonia, particularly Mycoplasma pneumonia.

questions.text: What is the normal arteriovenous ratio at the optic disc? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2:3

 

Explanation: 


The normal arteriovenous (AV) ratio at the optic disc is 2:3. This ratio represents the normal relationship between arteriole and venule caliber at the optic disc. The artery appears lighter in color and has a thicker wall, while the vein appears darker and has a thinner wall. This ratio is important in assessing various ocular conditions, particularly hypertensive retinopathy.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. 2:5: This is incorrect as it suggests arterioles are too narrow compared to venules. This ratio would indicate pathological narrowing of arterioles.

 

Option C. 1:5: This is incorrect and would represent a severely abnormal ratio suggesting significant arteriolar narrowing, which might be seen in advanced hypertensive retinopathy.

 

Option D. 1:3: While this ratio is seen in hypertensive retinopathy, it is not the normal AV ratio. In hypertensive retinopathy, there is narrowing of arterioles leading to a reduction in the AV ratio from 2:3 to 1:3.

 

Educational Objective: 


The normal arteriovenous ratio at the optic disc is 2:3, which serves as a baseline for evaluating vascular changes in various retinal conditions, particularly hypertensive retinopathy.

choices.text: Both iris details and pupil margins are seen.
Both iris details and pupil margins are not seen.

questions.text: In the case of macular corneal opacity, which of the following is true? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pupil margins are seen

 

Explanation: 


In macular corneal opacity, the iris details are not visible through the opacity, but the pupil margin can be easily seen. This is a key distinguishing feature of macular opacity compared to other types of corneal opacities. Macular opacity involves significant stromal injury but affects less than half the depth of the stroma. The opacity is easily visible but allows some visualization of deeper structures like pupillary margins.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Iris details are seen: This is incorrect. In macular opacity, the texture and details of the iris are obscured by the opacity.

 

Option C. Both iris details and pupil margins are seen: This is incorrect and better describes nebular opacity, which is the mildest form where both iris details and pupil margins are visible.

 

Option D. Both iris details and pupil margins are not seen: This is incorrect and describes leucomatous opacity, which is the densest form where neither iris details nor pupil margins are visible.

 

Educational Objective: 


Macular corneal opacity, pupil margins are visible while iris details cannot be seen - this is a key diagnostic feature that helps differentiate it from other types of corneal opacities.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child who was born premature at 34 weeks POG weighing 1400 gms presents with leukocoria. On CT, intraocular calcification is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Explanation:

 

While the history of prematurity (34 weeks) and low birth weight (1400g) might suggest ROP, the presence of intraocular calcification on CT scan is pathognomonic for retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood, and it is the only condition among the given options that shows intraocular calcification. This calcification can be detected on CT scan, though CT is generally avoided due to radiation exposure risks. The preferred imaging modalities are ultrasound B-scan and contrast-enhanced MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ROP (Retinopathy of Prematurity): While the premature birth and low birth weight are risk factors for ROP, it does not present with intraocular calcification. ROP occurs in newborns <34 weeks or <2.0 kg birth weight and presents with abnormal vessel development.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This presents as leukocoria but does not show intraocular calcification. It is an opacity of the natural lens that is present at birth.

 

Option D. Coat's Disease: While this can present with leukocoria, it is characterized by retinal telangiectasia and exudation without calcification. It typically affects young males and is usually unilateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraocular calcification seen on imaging in a child with leukocoria is pathognomonic for retinoblastoma, regardless of other clinical factors like prematurity.

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral sudden onset painless vision loss. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic retinopathy

 

Explanation:

 

Bilateral sudden onset painless vision loss is most commonly associated with diabetic retinopathy, particularly in cases of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) leading to vitreous hemorrhage.

 

  • Diabetic retinopathy can cause vitreous hemorrhage, which results in sudden, painless vision loss.
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is characterized by neovascularization, which can rupture and cause bilateral involvement due to systemic nature of diabetes.
  • Unlike other causes of vision loss, diabetic retinopathy progresses asymptomatically until a significant event like hemorrhage or tractional retinal detachment occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iridocyclitis: Incorrect. Iridocyclitis (anterior uveitis) causes painful vision loss with redness, photophobia, and keratic precipitates, which are absent in this case.

 

Option C. Acute Congestive Glaucoma: Incorrect. This condition presents with sudden onset painful vision loss, red eye, halos around lights, and raised intraocular pressure. The presence of pain distinguishes it from diabetic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Keratoconus: Incorrect. Keratoconus leads to progressive rather than sudden vision loss and is not typically bilateral at onset. It causes irregular astigmatism but does not cause complete vision loss suddenly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral sudden painless vision loss is most commonly due to diabetic retinopathy, particularly proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) with vitreous hemorrhage.



Diminished Vision Classification

choices.text: 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 3 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer
1 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 2 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 3 – Ganglion Cell Layer, 4 – Inner Plexiform Layer
1 – Ganglion Cell Layer, 2 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 3 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 4 – Outer Nuclear Layer
1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 3 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer

questions.text: Arrange the following layers of the retina in the correct order from the outermost to the innermost layer. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 3 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer

 

Explanation:


The correct sequence of retinal layers from outermost to innermost is RPE, outer nuclear layer, inner plexiform layer, and ganglion cell layer. The RPE is the outermost layer of the retina, followed by the outer nuclear layer which contains photoreceptor cell bodies. The inner plexiform layer contains synapses between bipolar, amacrine, and ganglion cells, while the ganglion cell layer, containing ganglion cell bodies, is closest to the vitreous.

 

Educational Objective: 


Anatomical sequence of retinal layers from outermost to innermost: 

 

Retinal Pigment Epithelium → Outer Nuclear Layer → Inner Plexiform Layer → Ganglion Cell Layer.

questions.text: Pterygium can lead to which of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Astigmatism

 

Explanation: 


Pterygium can lead to astigmatism because the fibrous growth on the cornea tends to flatten the cornea in the horizontal meridian. This creates an irregular corneal surface, specifically causing with-the-rule astigmatism. The pterygium grows along the horizontal axis, making it flatter, which results in the vertical axis becoming comparatively steeper, leading to astigmatism. This condition may cause visual disturbance, especially if it grows across the pupil.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Eye Pain: This is incorrect. Pterygium is typically painless. Patients may experience foreign body sensation, but actual pain is not a characteristic feature.

 

Option C. Macular edema: This is incorrect. Pterygium is a surface growth that affects the anterior segment of the eye and does not cause macular edema, which is a condition affecting the posterior segment.

 

Option D. Purulent Discharge: This is incorrect. Pterygium is a non-inflammatory condition and does not cause purulent discharge. While there might be mild irritation and tearing, purulent discharge is not associated with pterygium.

 

Educational Objective:


Pterygium can cause with-the-rule astigmatism by flattening the cornea in the horizontal meridian.

questions.text: Which is the investigation of choice for Best disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Electrooculogram (EOG)

 

Explanation: 


Electrooculogram (EOG) is the investigation of choice for Best disease. EOG is the only condition where best disease has significant diagnostic value, and Best disease is the only condition where EOG is of primary diagnostic significance. In Best disease, the Arden ratio (peak to trough ratio) in EOG is abnormal (<1.5) while ERG remains normal in early stages. EOG measures the standing potential between the front and back of the eye and is particularly sensitive to RPE function, which is primarily affected in Best disease.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Electroretinogram (ERG):This is incorrect because ERG is typically normal in Best disease, especially in early stages. ERG measures the electrical response of the retina to light stimulation and primarily tests photoreceptor function.

 

Option C. Multifocal electro retinogram: This is incorrect because mfERG, while useful for evaluating macular function, is not the primary diagnostic test for Best disease. It provides topographic measurement of retinal electrophysiological activity in the central retina.

 

Option D. Visual Evoked potential: This is incorrect because VEP tests the integrity of the entire visual pathway from retina to occipital cortex and is not specific for Best disease. It records the electrical activity in the visual cortex in response to visual stimuli.

 

Educational Objective: 


Electrooculogram (EOG) is the investigation of choice for Best disease, with an abnormal Arden ratio (<1.5) being diagnostic while ERG remains normal in early stages.

questions.text: In case of a chemical injury to the eye, what is the immediate first step in the management? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Copious irrigation with saline

 

Explanation: 


In chemical injury to the eye, copious irrigation with saline is the immediate first step in management. The primary goal is to remove the offending agent as quickly as possible to minimize tissue damage. Irrigation should be started immediately using whatever solution is available (saline, Ringer's lactate, balanced salt solution, or even plain water). It's crucial not to use neutralizing solutions (like acid for alkali or vice versa) as this can generate heat and cause additional damage.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Check visual acuity: This is incorrect as checking visual acuity would delay the urgent need to remove the causative chemical agent. Visual acuity can be checked after initial irrigation.

 

Option B. Take history: This is incorrect. While history is important, it should not delay immediate irrigation. Basic history (type of chemical) can be taken while performing irrigation.

 

Option C. Intraocular pressure measurement: This is incorrect. IOP measurement has no role in immediate management of chemical injury and could potentially cause more harm if done before thorough irrigation.

 

Educational Objective: 


Immediate copious irrigation with saline or any available appropriate solution is the first step in managing chemical injury to the eye, taking precedence over all other examinations or investigations.

questions.text: Which of the following is typically seen in diabetic retinopathy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tractional retinal detachment

 

Explanation:


Tractional retinal detachment (TRD) is a characteristic complication of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). In PDR, new vessels proliferate and are accompanied by fibrous tissue formation. When this fibrous tissue contracts, it pulls on the retina, leading to tractional retinal detachment. This typically occurs as a late complication of PDR, following vitreous hemorrhage and fibrovascular proliferation.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Myopic refractive error: This is incorrect. Myopic refractive error is not associated with diabetic retinopathy. It is a refractive condition where light focuses in front of the retina rather than on it.

 

Option C. Posterior staphyloma: This is incorrect. Posterior staphyloma is typically associated with high myopia, not diabetic retinopathy. It represents an outward bulging of the posterior pole of the eye.

 

Option D. Retinoschisis: This is incorrect. Retinoschisis, which is a splitting of the retinal layers, is not a characteristic feature of diabetic retinopathy. It is commonly seen in degenerative conditions and as a congenital condition.

 

Educational Objective: 


Tractional retinal detachment is a characteristic complication of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, caused by the contraction of fibrovascular tissue that develops with neovascularization.

questions.text: In fluorescein angiography, how do microaneurysms typically appear? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperfluorescent dots

 

Explanation: 


In fluorescein angiography (FFA), microaneurysms appear as hyperfluorescent dots. Microaneurysms are focal saccular dilatations of capillary walls where pericytes are absent, typically located in the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer. When fluorescein dye is injected, these microaneurysms fill with the dye and appear as bright, well-defined hyperfluorescent dots, particularly visible at the edge of areas of capillary non-perfusion.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hypofluorescent spots: This is incorrect. Hypofluorescent spots are typically seen in areas of blockage (like hemorrhages) or capillary dropout, not microaneurysms.

 

Option C. Fluorescent leakage: This is incorrect. While microaneurysms may eventually leak, their characteristic initial appearance is as discrete hyperfluorescent dots, not diffuse leakage.

 

Option D. Dark shadows: This is incorrect. Dark shadows or blocking defects are typically seen with hemorrhages or pigmented lesions, not microaneurysms.

 

Educational Objective: 


Microaneurysms appear as hyperfluorescent dots on fluorescein angiography, serving as an important diagnostic feature in conditions like diabetic retinopathy.

choices.text: Maintain Anterior Chamber during capsulorrhexis and IOL insertion
Can be left in eye at end of surgery
SF6 and Perfluorocarbons are commonly used viscoelastics

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding viscoelastic substances used in cataract surgery? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maintain Anterior Chamber during capsulorrhexis and IOL insertion

 

Explanation: 


Viscoelastic substances, also called ophthalmic visco-surgical devices (OVDs), are used to maintain the anterior chamber shape and volume during cataract surgery, particularly during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion. These gel-like materials protect intraocular tissues during surgical procedures and help maintain space in the anterior chamber, making surgical maneuvers safer and easier.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Can be left in eye at end of surgery: This is incorrect. Viscoelastic must be thoroughly removed at the end of surgery as retained viscoelastic can cause post-operative rise in intraocular pressure.

 

Option C Damages Corneal Epithelium: This is incorrect. Rather than causing damage, viscoelastic substances protect the corneal endothelium from surgical trauma and phacoemulsification energy.

 

Option D. SF6 and perfluorocarbon are commonly used viscoelastics: This is incorrect. These are vitreous substitutes used in vitreoretinal surgery, not viscoelastic substances used in cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective: 


Viscoelastic substances are essential in cataract surgery for maintaining anterior chamber form and protecting intraocular structures, particularly during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion, and must be removed at the end of surgery.

questions.text: Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve results in which of the following clinical manifestations? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of extension at finger

 

The posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) is the deep branch of the radial nerve that supplies most of the extensor muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm. When injured, it affects the extension of fingers because it directly supplies the extensor digitorum, which is responsible for finger extension. However, it does not supply three specific muscles of the posterior compartment: anconeus, brachioradialis, and extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRB) - these are supplied by the main radial nerve before it divides. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of supination: Incorrect because supination is performed by both the supinator muscle (supplied by PIN) and the biceps brachii (supplied by musculocutaneous nerve). Even with PIN injury, the biceps can still perform supination, especially in the semiflexed elbow position.

 

Option C. Loss of extension of wrist: Incorrect because some wrist extension is preserved due to the function of extensor carpi radialis longus, which is supplied by the radial nerve proper and not the posterior interosseous branch.

 

Option D. Wrist drop: Incorrect because complete wrist drop requires injury to the main radial nerve. In PIN injury, the extensor carpi radialis longus is spared, allowing some wrist extension to be maintained.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior interosseous nerve (deep branch of radial nerve) supplies all posterior compartment muscles except anconeus, brachioradialis, and extensor carpi radialis longus. Its injury results in finger extension loss while preserving partial wrist extension.

questions.text: In the provided lateral view of the skull, the region indicated by the arrow overlies which of the following intracranial structures? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stem of lateral sulcus

 

The marked structure in the image is the pterion, which is an H-shaped area on the lateral side of the skull where four bones meet (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid). The central part of the pterion is called the Sylvian point. Deep to the pterion lies the stem of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) of the brain. The pterion is a clinically important landmark because the middle meningeal artery runs directly beneath it, and injury to this area can cause extradural hemorrhage, which appears as a biconvex opacity on radiological imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ICA Siphon: Incorrect because the internal carotid artery (ICA) siphon is located deeper in the skull, within the cavernous sinus, not directly beneath the pterion.

 

Option C. Wernicke's area: Incorrect because Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus (area 22) of the dominant hemisphere, not directly deep to the pterion.

 

Option D. Pineal gland: Incorrect because the pineal gland is located at the center of the brain in the epithalamus, not related to the pterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H-shaped area on the lateral skull where four bones meet (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid), and it overlies the stem of the lateral sulcus and middle meningeal artery.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derivatives of NCC (Neural crest cells), except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinal pigment membrane

 

The retinal pigment membrane (or retinal pigment epithelium, RPE) develops from the ectoderm of the optic cup, which is an outgrowth of the developing brain, and not from neural crest cells. The neural retina and RPE both develop from the neuroectoderm of the optic vesicle, making them extensions of the central nervous system rather than neural crest derivatives.
 

Neural crest cells (NCCs):

  • Ciliary muscles
  • Melanocytes

  • Ciliary ganglion

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciliary muscles: The ciliary muscles develop from neural crest cells that contribute to the development of structures in the eye.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: Melanocytes throughout the body, including those in the skin and iris, are derived from neural crest cells that migrate from the neural tube during embryonic development.

 

Option D. Ciliary ganglion: The ciliary ganglion, a parasympathetic ganglion associated with the eye, is derived from neural crest cells. Neural crest cells give rise to all parasympathetic ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural crest cells give rise to diverse structures including melanocytes, parasympathetic ganglia (including ciliary ganglion), and components of the eye (like ciliary muscles), but the retinal pigment epithelium develops from the optic cup neuroectoderm.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac structures is derived from neural crest cells? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conotruncal Septum

 

Neural crest cells (NCCs) contribute to the development of the conotruncal septum in the heart. The conotruncal septum is also known as the spiral septum and is crucial for the proper division of the truncus arteriosus into the aorta and pulmonary trunk. NCCs migrate from the neural tube to contribute to the formation of this septum. Abnormalities in neural crest cell migration can lead to conotruncal defects such as Tetralogy of Fallot, Truncus Arteriosus, and Transposition of Great Vessels.



Mnemonic: PEADS  doing DISCO in front of MMM":

P - Parasympathetic ganglion

E - Enteric plexus

A - ANS ganglion

D - Dorsal root ganglion

S - Schwann cell

D - Dentine tissue

S - Sclera

C - Choroid, Conotruncal septum

O - Connective tissue of glands

M - Melanocyte

M - Mesenchymal bone of head & face

M – Meninges

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AV Cushion: Incorrect because the atrioventricular (AV) cushions are primarily derived from the endocardium via epithelial-to-mesenchymal transformation, not from neural crest cells.

 

Option B. Septum primum: Incorrect because the septum primum, which forms part of the interatrial septum, is derived from the dorsal mesocardium and not from neural crest cells.

 

Option C. SA node: Incorrect because the sinoatrial (SA) node, the heart's primary pacemaker, develops from cardiogenic mesoderm, not from neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural crest cells contribute to the development of the conotruncal septum (spiral septum) in the heart, and abnormalities in neural crest cell migration can lead to various congenital heart defects.

questions.text: A patient complains of difficulty chewing, with food accumulating between the cheeks and teeth. Weakness of which muscle is most likely responsible for this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buccinator

 

The buccinator muscle, known as the "whistling muscle," is responsible for keeping food between the teeth and preventing it from accumulating in the vestibule (space between teeth and cheeks) during mastication. It helps press the cheek against the teeth, facilitating the proper movement of food in the oral cavity. When it is weak or paralyzed, as can occur in facial nerve (VII) palsy, food gets trapped between the teeth and cheeks because the muscle cannot properly position the food for chewing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orbicularis oris: Incorrect because this muscle forms the sphincter of the mouth and is responsible for closing and rounding the lips, not for manipulating food during chewing.

 

Option C. Zygomaticus major: Incorrect because this is the "smiling muscle" that draws the angle of the mouth upward and laterally, not involved in keeping food between the teeth during chewing.

 

Option D. Levator labi superioris: Incorrect because this muscle elevates the upper lip and is not primarily involved in keeping food between teeth during mastication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The buccinator muscle, innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII), is essential for keeping food between the teeth during mastication, and its weakness results in food accumulation between cheeks and teeth.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve passes through the structure indicated by the arrow in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV

 

The marked structure in the image is the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV), which is the thinnest cranial nerve. It is located in the area near the midbrain, passing around the lateral side of the brainstem before entering the cavernous sinus. The trochlear nerve is unique among cranial nerves as it emerges from the dorsal surface of the brainstem (posterior aspect) and is the only cranial nerve that completely decussates before innervating its target structure, the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is the thinnest cranial nerve, emerges from the dorsal midbrain, completely decussates, and supplies only the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye.

questions.text: All of the following nerves are transmitted through the superior orbital fissure except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) II

 

The optic nerve (cranial nerve II) does not pass through the superior orbital fissure. Instead, it enters the orbit through a separate opening called the optic canal, along with the ophthalmic artery. The superior orbital fissure transmits structures that supply the eyeball and surrounding tissues, but the optic nerve has its dedicated canal due to its embryological development and functional importance.

 

"LFT" 

 

  • L for Lacrimal nerve
  • F for Frontal nerve
  • T for Trochlear nerve (CN IV)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. III: Incorrect because the oculomotor nerve (CN III) passes through the superior orbital fissure within the common tendinous ring. Its superior and inferior divisions enter the orbit through this fissure.

 

Option C. IV: Incorrect because the trochlear nerve (CN IV) passes through the lateral part of the superior orbital fissure, outside the common tendinous ring, along with the lacrimal and frontal nerves.

 

Option D. VI: Incorrect because the abducent nerve (CN VI) passes through the superior orbital fissure within the common tendinous ring, as part of the mnemonic "SONIA" (Superior division of oculomotor, Nasociliary, Inferior division of oculomotor, Abducent).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior orbital fissure transmits cranial nerves III, IV, VI, V1 (including lacrimal, frontal, and nasociliary branches), and associated vessels, while the optic nerve (CN II) passes through the separate optic canal.

questions.text: Identify the type of gland indicated by the arrow in the given histological image. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Holocrine

 

The image shows a sebaceous gland, which is the classic example of a holocrine gland. In holocrine glands, the entire secretory cell disintegrates and becomes part of the secretion. The characteristic appearance of sebaceous glands in histological sections shows empty-looking cells with white spaces because the lipid contents (sebum) are dissolved during the preparation of the slide with organic solvents like acetone and alcohol. This gives sebaceous glands their distinctive "empty" appearance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Merocrine: Incorrect because merocrine glands (also called eccrine glands) release their secretions through exocytosis without cell damage. Examples include sweat glands of the palms and soles. They would appear as coiled tubular structures without the empty cell appearance.

 

Option B. Ecrine: Incorrect because ecrine is another term for merocrine glands, which release their secretions through exocytosis without cell damage, unlike the holocrine pattern seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sebaceous glands are holocrine glands where the entire cell disintegrates to form the secretion, and they appear as "empty" structures in histological sections because their lipid contents are dissolved during slide preparation.

questions.text: During oogenesis, primary follicles are physiologically arrested at which stage of prophase I? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diplotene

 

Primary follicles containing primary oocytes are arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I of meiosis. This arrest occurs before a female is born and remains until puberty. The mnemonic "PPD" can help remember this: Primary oocyte, Prophase I, Diplotene stage. After puberty, under hormonal influence during each menstrual cycle, selected primary oocytes resume meiosis, complete the first meiotic division to form secondary oocytes, and then arrest again at metaphase II until fertilization occurs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leptotene: Incorrect because leptotene is an earlier stage of prophase I where chromosomes begin to condense and become visible. Primary oocytes progress beyond this stage before arresting.

 

Option B. Zygotene: Incorrect because zygotene is the stage where homologous chromosomes begin to pair up (synapsis). Primary oocytes progress beyond this stage before arresting.

 

Option C. Pachytene: Incorrect because pachytene is the stage where crossing over (genetic recombination) occurs between homologous chromosomes. Primary oocytes progress beyond this stage before arresting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary oocytes remain arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I of meiosis from before birth until puberty, resuming meiosis only when stimulated by hormones during the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: During walking, which muscle on the opposite side stabilizes the pelvis when one leg is lifted off the ground? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gluteus medius

 

During walking, when one leg is suspended (swing phase), the pelvis tends to drop on the unsupported side due to gravity. The gluteus medius muscle on the stance side (supporting leg) contracts to prevent this drop, stabilizing the pelvis and maintaining level hips during walking. This action allows for a smooth, efficient gait. When the gluteus medius is weak or paralyzed, the pelvis drops on the unsupported side when walking, resulting in a positive Trendelenburg sign and a characteristic lurching gait.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gluteus maximus: Incorrect because the gluteus maximus is primarily responsible for hip extension, which helps in activities like climbing stairs or rising from a seated position. It doesn't significantly contribute to lateral stability of the pelvis during walking.

 

Option C. Tensor Fascia Lata: While the tensor fascia lata does assist in stabilization of the pelvis, it plays a secondary role to the gluteus medius, which is the primary muscle responsible for pelvic stability during walking because of its size and positioning.

 

Option D. Quadriceps femoris: Incorrect because the quadriceps femoris is responsible for knee extension and is known as the "footballer's muscle" or "kicking muscle." It does not contribute significantly to pelvic stability during the walking cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus medius muscle on the stance leg stabilizes the pelvis during walking, preventing the pelvis from dropping on the suspended leg side (Trendelenburg sign when dysfunctional).

questions.text: The first wave of migrating epiblast cells during gastrulation gives rise to which germ layer? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoderm

 

The first migration of epiblast cells leads to the formation of endoderm. During early embryonic development, cells from the epiblast migrate and form the hypoblast, which becomes the endoderm. This is the first germ cell layer to form in the embryo. The formation of germ layers occurs in sequence: endoderm forms first, followed by mesoderm, and finally ectoderm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ectoderm: Incorrect because ectoderm is the last of the three primary germ layers to form. The remaining cells of the epiblast that don't migrate become the ectoderm after the formation of endoderm and mesoderm.

 

Option C. Mesoderm: Incorrect because mesoderm is the second germ cell layer to form, not the first. It develops when epiblast cells migrate through the primitive streak and form a new layer between the endoderm and the remaining epiblast (which becomes ectoderm).

 

Option D. Notochord: Incorrect because the notochord is derived from specialized mesodermal cells at the primitive node. It forms after the initial germ layer formation and is not the direct result of the first epiblast migration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of germ layer formation during gastrulation is: endoderm (first), mesoderm (second), and ectoderm (third), with the first migration of epiblast cells forming the endoderm.

questions.text: Identify the embryonic structure marked in the given image. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Notochord

 

The marked structure in the image is the notochord, which is a rod-like structure that forms along the midline of the developing embryo. The notochord is derived from the primitive node and extends cranially from the primitive streak. It serves as an embryonic axis, providing structural support and playing a crucial role in the induction of the neural tube formation. Later in development, the notochord largely disappears, but its remnants persist as the nucleus pulposus within the intervertebral discs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primitive streak: Incorrect because the primitive streak appears as a linear structure at the caudal end of the embryo and is the site where epiblast cells migrate to form mesoderm and endoderm. It defines the cranio-caudal axis but is not the central rod-like structure shown in the image.

 

Option C. Neural groove: Incorrect because the neural groove is the midline depression that forms as the neural plate folds inward during neurulation. It is wider and more superficial than the notochord and eventually closes to form the neural tube.

 

Option D. Neural crest cells: Incorrect because neural crest cells are populations of cells that form at the lateral edges of the neural plate and migrate throughout the embryo to form various structures. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The notochord is a midline rod-like structure that induces formation of the neural tube, defines the embryonic axis, and later forms the nucleus pulposus of intervertebral discs.

questions.text: A patient had complaints of ureteric colic. Examination was normal. What is the best imaging to diagnose? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NCCT KUB


Non-contrast computed tomography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (NCCT KUB) is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing ureteric colic. Around 90% of ureteric or renal stones are radio-opaque and appear hyperdense on CT, allowing even small stones to be detected effectively. NCCT KUB is highly sensitive and specific for urinary calculi.

 

MRI is not typically used for urinary calculi due to poor visualization of stones. Ureteroscopy is an invasive procedure, generally performed for treatment rather than diagnosis. CECT (contrast-enhanced CT) is used primarily for detecting renal masses, infections, or inflammatory conditions, not for detecting stones, as stones appear hyperdense without contrast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: Not indicated for urinary calculus diagnosis. MRI is less effective in visualizing stone composition and location compared to CT.

 

Option B. Uretroscopy: An invasive procedure used for treatment, not diagnosis. It is not recommended as a primary diagnostic tool for stone detection.

 

Option D. CECT KUB (Contrast Enhanced CT): Typically used when suspecting renal masses, inflammatory pathologies, or neoplastic conditions. For stone diagnosis, contrast is unnecessary because stones are already hyper-dense and clearly visible on non-contrast scans.

 

Educational Objective: 


NCCT KUB is the best imaging modality for diagnosing ureteric colic and detecting renal calculi due to its high sensitivity for hyperdense stones.

questions.text: Identify the artery marked with blue arrow in the image. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superficial temporal artery


The given image is from an MR angiography study showing vascular structures. The superficial temporal artery (STA) is a terminal branch of the external carotid artery (ECA) and runs laterally along the temples. It is a prominent artery that can be easily visualized in imaging. The superficial temporal artery is a direct continuation of the external carotid and is one of its terminal branches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior auricular artery: A smaller branch of the external carotid artery, located behind the ear, making it unlikely to be the identified artery.

 

Option B. Middle meningeal artery: A branch of the maxillary artery, which runs intracranially and supplies the meninges; not a direct division of the external carotid seen superficially.

 

Option D. Occipital artery: A branch of the external carotid artery that supplies the posterior scalp; it is not a lateral terminal branch like the STA.

 

Educational Objective: 


The superficial temporal artery is a terminal branch of the external carotid artery, supplying the temporal region and easily identifiable in MR angiography studies.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with persistent bad breath and a history of dysphagia lasting 7 months. Barium swallow is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zenker’s Diverticulum

 

Explanation:


Zenker’s diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum occurring at Killian’s dehiscence, a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles. It presents with dysphagia, halitosis, regurgitation of undigested food, and chronic symptoms. A barium swallow study confirms the diagnosis by revealing a posterior outpouching in the pharyngoesophageal region.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal Neoplasia: Typically presents with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and sometimes hematemesis.

 

Option B. Achalasia: Characterized by dysphagia to both solids and liquids, with a ‘bird-beak’ appearance on barium swallow.

 

Option D. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Causes intermittent chest pain and dysphagia with a ‘corkscrew’ appearance on imaging.

 

 

Educational Objective: 


Zenker’s diverticulum is a pharyngoesophageal pouch presenting with dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation. Diagnosis is confirmed with a barium swallow study.

choices.text: Aspiration - Super segments of lower lobe involved

questions.text: Incorrect about chest X-ray infiltrate is: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interstitial infiltrate - pyogenic

 

Explanation:


Pyogenic (bacterial) pneumonia typically presents with lobar consolidation rather than interstitial infiltrates. Interstitial infiltrates are more characteristic of atypical pneumonia caused by organisms such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, viruses, or Legionella species.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspiration - Super segments of lower lobe involved : Can involve both upper and lower lung segments depending on patient positioning.

 

 

Option C. Lymphadenopathy - TB, fungal, or malignancy: Seen in tuberculosis, fungal infections, and malignancies.

 

Option D. Interstitial infiltrate - Atypical pneumonia: Typically associated with viral, atypical bacterial, or chronic lung diseases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyogenic pneumonia presents with lobar consolidation, whereas interstitial infiltrates are seen in atypical pneumonia and viral infections.

questions.text: Marshall’s triad of abrasion, bruise & punctate laceration is seen in which phase of bomb blast injury? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary

 

Marshall's triad is the most characteristic feature of secondary blast injury. It consists of multiple small abrasions, contusions, and punctate lacerations all over the body caused by fragments of bombs or flying debris. These injuries occur due to fragments and pieces being propelled by the blast. Secondary blast injuries account for most fatalities in bomb blast incidents.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Primary: Incorrect. Primary blast injury is caused by high-pressure waves affecting hollow organs. In air blast, it primarily affects the tympanic membrane, followed by lungs and GIT. In underwater blast, GIT is the main target.

 

Option C. Tertiary: Incorrect. Tertiary blast injury occurs when the victim is thrown away by blast wind (not wave). It's characterized by blunt trauma from impact with solid objects.

 

Option D. Quaternary: Incorrect. Quaternary blast injury, also called miscellaneous blast injury, includes all injuries not covered in the first three phases such as flash burns, respiratory injuries from gases, and psychiatric issues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Marshall's triad (multiple small abrasions, contusions, and punctate lacerations) is characteristic of secondary blast injury caused by flying debris and bomb fragments.

 

Bomb Blast Injuries

questions.text: A boy who went to the school consumed some unknown substance & came to the emergency with pulmonary oedema. On examination silver nitrate breath test is positive. What is the antidote for the substance consumed? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MgSO4

 

The silver nitrate breath test is used to detect aluminum phosphide poisoning. When silver nitrate reacts with aluminum phosphide, it forms silver phosphide which appears black in color. This is diagnostic of aluminum phosphide poisoning. Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is used as the treatment of choice as it helps stabilize cardiac cells and reduces arrhythmias, though aluminum phosphide poisoning is extremely toxic with no highly effective antidote.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Prussian blue: Incorrect. Prussian blue (potassium ferric ferrocyanate) is the antidote for thallium poisoning, not aluminum phosphide poisoning.

 

Option C. Physostigmine: Incorrect. Physostigmine is the antidote for anticholinergic poisoning like atropine and datura poisoning, not aluminum phosphide.

 

Option D. Atropine: Incorrect. Atropine is the antidote for cholinergic poisoning like organophosphates and carbamates, not aluminum phosphide.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is used as treatment for aluminum phosphide poisoning, which can be detected using the silver nitrate breath test.

questions.text: Methylene blue is used as an antidote for? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nitrites

 

Methylene blue is used as an antidote for methemoglobinemia, which can be caused by nitrites and other compounds. In methemoglobinemia, Fe2+ in hemoglobin is converted to Fe3+ (methemoglobin), which has decreased oxygen-carrying capacity. Methylene blue acts as an electron donor, converting Fe3+ back to Fe2+, thus restoring normal oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin. Nitrites and nitrate-containing drugs are common causes of methemoglobinemia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Phosphorus: Incorrect. Phosphorus poisoning is treated with copper sulfate (historically) and potassium permanganate, not methylene blue.

 

Option B. Aluminum phosphide: Incorrect. Aluminum phosphide poisoning is treated with magnesium sulfate to stabilize cardiac cells and prevent arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Mercury: Incorrect. Mercury poisoning is treated with chelating agents like dimercaprol (BAL), DMPS, or succimer (DMSA).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Methylene blue is the antidote for methemoglobinemia, commonly caused by nitrites, as it converts methemoglobin (Fe3+) back to normal hemoglobin (Fe2+).

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about heat exhaustion? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of thermoregulatory mechanism

 

Heat exhaustion does not involve loss of thermoregulatory mechanism - this is actually a characteristic of heat stroke. In heat exhaustion, body temperature is elevated but thermoregulation is still functioning. Typically, heat exhaustion presents with body temperature around 38-39°C (<104°F), along with sweating, hypotension, and mild mental status changes. The thermoregulatory system remains intact and continues attempting to cool the body through mechanisms like sweating.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Orthostatic hypotension is seen: Correct. Orthostatic hypotension begins appearing in heat syncope and continues through heat exhaustion.

 

Option C. Altered consciousness is seen: Correct. Mild alterations in consciousness can occur in heat exhaustion, though severe mental dysfunction is more characteristic of heat stroke.

 

Option D. Core body temp is <105°F: Correct. In heat exhaustion, body temperature remains below 104°F (40°C). Temperatures above this level are more indicative of heat stroke.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Heat exhaustion presents with profuse sweating, hypotension, and altered consciousness, but the thermoregulatory mechanism remains intact. Loss of thermoregulation occurs in heat stroke.

questions.text: This powder is used in treatment of which poisoning? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphorus

 

The blue-colored powder referred to is copper sulfate (blue vitriol), which was historically used to treat phosphorus poisoning. Copper sulfate reacts with phosphorus to form cupric phosphide, which is non-toxic. While copper sulfate is no longer commonly used as an antidote due to its own toxicity, it remains a historically important treatment. The antidotes for phosphorus poisoning include KMnO4 (potassium permanganate) and CuSO4 (copper sulfate).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Arsenic: Incorrect. Arsenic poisoning is treated with chelating agents like DMPS (Dimercapto propanesulfonic acid), Dimercaprol (BAL), or Succimer (DMSA). Copper sulfate is not used in arsenic poisoning treatment.

 

Option C. Mercury: Incorrect. Mercury poisoning is treated with chelating agents like Dimercaprol, DMPS, or Succimer. Copper sulfate has no role in mercury poisoning treatment.

 

Option D. Lead: Incorrect. Lead poisoning is primarily treated with Dimercaprol + CaNa2EDTA, DMPS, or Succimer. Copper sulfate is not used in lead poisoning treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copper Sulphate (blue vitriol) was historically used to treat phosphorus poisoning but is no longer recommended due to its own toxicity. The current antidotes for phosphorus poisoning include KMnO₄ (Potassium Permanganate) and Copper Sulphate, although clinical use has largely been discontinued​.

questions.text: Which among the following is not included in the severe acute malnutrition definition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Height for age

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Height for age

 

Not included in SAM

  • This reflects chronic malnutrition or stunting, which is a result of long-term nutritional deficiency.
  • It does not indicate acute status and is therefore not a criterion for SAM.
  • So, this is the correct answer to the question.

 

Other Option

 

Option A) weight for height 

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is diagnosed when any one of the following criteria is present:

  1. Weight-for-height/length < -3 SD (Z-score) of the WHO growth standard.
  2. Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 cm (for children aged 6–59 months).
  3. Bilateral pedal edema (nutritional edema) of nutritional origin.

 

Height-for-age is not part of the SAM definition.

 

It is an indicator of chronic malnutrition (stunting), not acute malnutrition.

 

Option C) MUAC <11.5 cm

 

Included in SAM

  • MUAC (Mid-Upper Arm Circumference) is a quick, field-friendly indicator used especially in children aged 6–59 months.
  • A value of <11.5 cm is diagnostic of SAM.
  • Reflects muscle wasting and fat loss.

 

Option D) Pedal oedema

 

Included in SAM

  • Bilateral pitting pedal edema, also called nutritional edema, is a sign of kwashiorkor, a form of SAM.
  • Even if weight-for-height or MUAC is normal, the presence of edema alone qualifies for SAM diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Height for age reflects chronic malnutrition (stunting), while SAM is defined by weight for height < -3 SD, MUAC < 11.5 cm, or the presence of bilateral edema

questions.text: All are seen in Cystic fibrosis except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Biliary atresia

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by dysfunction of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene, which leads to impaired chloride ion transport across cell membranes. This results in thick, viscous secretions in multiple organ systems. The hallmark finding is abnormally high sweat chloride levels (>60 mEq/L). In CF, secretions become thick and sticky, causing obstruction in various organs including the respiratory tract, pancreas, and intestines.

 

The manifestations of CF include:

 

  • Respiratory issues (recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, nasal polyps)
  • Gastrointestinal problems (meconium ileus, pancreatic insufficiency with steatorrhea, malabsorption)
  • Nutritional issues (failure to thrive, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies)
  • Bleeding diathesis (due to vitamin K malabsorption as it's fat-soluble)

 

Biliary atresia is not associated with cystic fibrosis - they are two distinct conditions affecting different systems.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Biliary atresia is not a manifestation of cystic fibrosis, while meconium ileus, nasal polyps, and bleeding diathesis (due to vitamin K deficiency) are common findings in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Clinical features:

 

1. Respiratory system 

 

  • Repeated URTI 
  • Chronic cough 
  • Sputum 
  • Bronchiectasis 
  • Atelectasis
  • Nasal polyp 
  • H. influenza, S. aureus are the first organisms recovered from lung secretions  
  • Mortality in cystic fibrosis is due to Burkholderia 

 

2. Genitourinary 

 

  • Azoospermia 
  • Infertility 

 

Cong. B/I absence/obliteration of vas deferens 

 

3. Intestinal 

 

  • Meconium ileus is most common disorder at birth 
  • Distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS)
  • Rectal prolapse 

 

If sweat chlorides are normal, go for nasal transmembrane potential difference

 

4. Pancreatic 

 

  • Pancreatic: exocrine insufficiency-will lead to foul smelling stool 
  • Chronic pancreatitis

 

5. Hepatic:

 

  • Focal biliary cirrhosis 
  • Prolonged neonatal jaundice 

 

6. Nutritional:

 

  • Failure to thrive 
  • Hypoproteinemia + edema
  • Fat soluble vitamin def.

 

Salt loss syndrome: 

 

Acute salt depletion + chronic metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Most common organism for croup? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Influenza virus

 

Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is an acute viral infection primarily affecting the larynx and trachea in children. The most common causative organism is the parainfluenza virus (particularly types 1 and 2), followed by influenza viruses. 

 

Laryngotracheobronchitis (CROUP)

 

  • Viral infection of glottis & subglottic region 
  • Caused by parainfluenza virus 
  • Symptoms: hoarse voice, coryza, mild tachypnea 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae: This is a bacterial organism that can cause epiglottitis and other respiratory infections. It is not a common cause of croup.


 

Option B. Streptococcus: This bacterial organism (particularly group A streptococcus) commonly causes pharyngitis ("strep throat") but is not a typical cause of croup.

 

Option D. Diphtheria: Caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, this bacterial infection can affect the respiratory tract but typically produces a pseudomembrane in the throat rather than the classic croup symptoms. Diphtheria has become rare in countries with routine immunization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral pathogens, particularly parainfluenza virus and influenza virus, as the most common causative agents of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) in children.

questions.text: A child who can make a cross, tell stories make tower of 6 cubes and goes to toilet alone, what is the age of the child: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 years

 

Child development follows predictable patterns across various domains including fine motor, gross motor, social, language, and self-care skills. The developmental milestones of the child's age:

 

  1. Making a cross: This is a fine motor skill typically achieved around 4 years of age. A cross has four components, making it more complex than simpler shapes like circles (3 years) or vertical lines (2 years).
  2. Telling stories/poems: This language and cognitive skill emerges around 4 years of age when children develop more complex narrative abilities and can recount events in sequence.
  3. Making a tower of 6 cubes: Fine motor skills for stacking develop progressively. By 2 years, children can typically build a tower of 6 cubes (using the formula age × 3 = number of cubes).
  4. Going to toilet alone: Complete toilet independence, including managing clothing and hygiene without assistance, is typically achieved by 4 years of age.

 

While some of these skills (like building a tower of 6 cubes) may be achieved earlier, the combination of all these milestones, particularly making a cross and independent toileting, points to a 4-year-old child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: At this age, children are developing basic motor skills like walking, may say a few words, and are nowhere near toilet independence. They cannot make crosses, tell stories, or build tall towers.

 

Option B. 2 years: Children at this age can typically build a tower of 6 cubes, but cannot yet draw crosses, tell coherent stories, or manage toileting independently.

 

Option C. 3 years: Three-year-olds may be developing toilet skills but typically still need some assistance. They can usually draw circles but not yet crosses, and their storytelling abilities are still developing.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The developmental milestones of a 4-year-old child, including the ability to draw a cross, tell stories, build a tower of 6 cubes, and achieve complete toilet independence.

questions.text: A 2 yr old child presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, hematuria. The mother tells you that the baby also suffered from diarrhea a few days back. Which is the most common organism for likely cause? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. Coli 0157:H7

 

The clinical presentation describes classic features of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), characterized by the triad of:

 

  • Hemolytic anemia 
  • Thrombocytopenia  
  • Acute kidney injury 

 

The most common causative organism for typical or diarrhea-associated HUS is Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC), particularly serotype O157:H7. This toxin damages endothelial cells, leading to platelet activation, microthrombi formation, and end-organ damage, particularly affecting the kidneys.

 

HUS is one of the most common causes of acute kidney injury in young children. Management focuses on supportive care, including careful fluid management, treatment of hypertension, and renal replacement therapy if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: While Salmonella can cause gastroenteritis and bacteremia, it is not typically associated with HUS. Salmonella infections commonly present with fever, diarrhea, and abdominal pain but do not typically progress to the triad of HUS.

 

Option C. Shigella: Although Shigella dysenteriae type 1 can produce Shiga toxin and cause HUS, it is much less common than E. coli O157:H7 as a cause of HUS, particularly in developed countries.

 

Option D. Yersinia: Yersinia enterocolitica can cause gastroenteritis but is not a common cause of HUS. It typically causes fever, diarrhea, and right lower quadrant pain that can mimic appendicitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The clinical presentation of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) following diarrheal illness and identify E. coli O157:H7 as the most common causative organism.

questions.text:
Which among the following is false about breast milk jaundice: (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Breast feeding should be completely stopped
  2. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  3. Phototherapy is required to treat most cases
  4. Bilirubin levels are usually more than 10 mg/dL at 3-4 weeks
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a and c

 

Breast milk jaundice is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs in breastfed infants typically beginning after the first week of life and can persist for several weeks. It is caused by certain components in breast milk (3-alpha-20-beta-diol and beta-glucuronidase) that inhibit the conjugation and excretion of bilirubin.

 

a. "Breast feeding should be completely stopped" - This is FALSE. Current guidelines do not recommend stopping breastfeeding for breast milk jaundice. Despite the jaundice being associated with breast milk, the benefits of breastfeeding outweigh the risks of the typically benign and self-limiting jaundice.

 

c. "Phototherapy is required to treat most cases" - This is also FALSE. Most cases of breast milk jaundice are mild and resolve spontaneously without phototherapy. Phototherapy is only required in cases where bilirubin levels reach potentially concerning levels.

 

Correct Statements:

 

b. "Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia" - This statement is TRUE. Breast milk jaundice is characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia because the components in breast milk affect the conjugation and excretion of bilirubin in the liver.

 

d. "Bilirubin levels are usually more than 10 mg/dL at 3-4 weeks" - This statement is TRUE. Breast milk jaundice typically presents with bilirubin levels that can persist above 10 mg/dL during the first 3-4 weeks of life, unlike physiological jaundice which resolves earlier.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Breast milk jaundice does not require stopping breastfeeding and most cases do not require phototherapy, despite causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia with levels that may exceed 10 mg/dL at 3-4 weeks of age.

choices.text: Compression to ventilation ratio should be 30:2 with 2 rescuers
Chest compression depth should be one-third of A-P diameter of chest
Injection Adenosine 0.01 ml/kg IV or IO (1:10,000)

questions.text: All of the following are incorrect about resuscitation of a critically sick child, except? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chest compression depth should be one-third of A-P diameter of chest

 

In pediatric advanced life support and resuscitation, the chest compression depth for pediatric patients should be one-third of the anterior-posterior (A-P) diameter of the chest. This ensures adequate cardiac output without causing injury to internal structures. For children, this typically translates to approximately 5 cm (2 inches) or about one-third of the chest diameter, which allows for effective cardiac compression while minimizing the risk of trauma to underlying organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preferred route of adrenaline intraosseous: This statement is incorrect. While the intraosseous (IO) route is a valuable alternative when intravenous access cannot be established quickly, the preferred route for adrenaline administration is intravenous (IV). The drug has a very short half-life and is most effective when administered through a central or large peripheral vein, followed by a saline flush. 

 

Option B. Compression to ventilation ratio should be 30:2 with 2 rescuers: This statement is incorrect for pediatric resuscitation. In children, with 2 rescuers, the recommended compression to ventilation ratio is 15:2. The 30:2 ratio is used either for adult resuscitation or for single-rescuer pediatric resuscitation.

 

Option D. Injection Adenosine 0.01 ml/kg IV or IO (1:10,000): This statement is incorrect regarding the dosing of adenosine. The correct dose of adenosine for children is 0.1 mg/kg (maximum first dose 6 mg) with subsequent doses of 0.2 mg/kg (maximum 12 mg). 

 

Educational Objective: 


Chest compression depth for pediatric resuscitation as one-third of the anterior-posterior diameter of the chest, while recognizing incorrect statements about medication routes and compression-to-ventilation ratios.

choices.text: No Complete absence of edema by day 20
Weight gain less than 5 gm/kg/day for 3 consecutive days

questions.text: Treatment non-responsive Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) includes all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No complete absence of edema by day 20

 

Non-responsive SAM refers to cases where the child does not show expected improvement despite standard treatment protocols. The standard criteria for non-responsive SAM include:

 

In a responsive case of SAM with edema, the edema should begin to reduce by day 4 and should completely resolve by day 10 (not day 20 as stated in option C). Therefore, stating that "no complete absence of edema by day 20" as a criterion for non-responsive SAM is incorrect, as edema should be gone well before day 20 even in responsive cases.

 

The correct timeline for edema resolution is:

 

  • Beginning of reduction by day 4
  • Complete resolution by day 10

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Appetite not increased by day 4: This is a valid criterion for non-responsive SAM. Typically, appetite should begin to improve by day 4 of treatment. If this doesn't occur, it indicates a non-responsive case that may require additional interventions.

 

Option B. No edema reduction by day 4: This is a valid criterion for non-responsive SAM. In responsive cases of SAM with edema, reduction should begin by day 4.

 

Option D. Weight gain less than 5 gm/kg/day for 3 consecutive days: This is also a valid criterion for non-responsive SAM. The expected weight gain in responsive SAM treatment is at least 5 gm/kg/day. Failure to achieve this indicates poor response to treatment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SAM with edema, complete resolution of edema should occur by day 10 of treatment, not day 20, and identify the correct criteria for non-responsive SAM including lack of appetite improvement by day 4, no edema reduction by day 4, and insufficient weight gain.

choices.text: Biliary atresia is the most common cause of neonatal cholestasis
Kasai procedure should be done within 90 days
HIDA scan is used for diagnosis
Can be differentiated from other differential diagnoses by biopsy

questions.text: All of the following are true about neonatal cholestasis, except? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kasai procedure should be done within 90 days

 

Neonatal cholestasis is defined as conjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs in the newborn period, typically presenting with jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine. Biliary atresia is indeed the most common cause of surgically correctable neonatal cholestasis, accounting for approximately 25-30% of cases.

 

The statement about the Kasai procedure (portoenterostomy) is incorrect. The Kasai procedure should be performed within 60 days of life, not 90 days. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biliary atresia is the most common cause of neonatal cholestasis: This statement is true. Biliary atresia is the most common identifiable cause of neonatal cholestasis, accounting for approximately 25-30% of cases. It is characterized by progressive obliteration of extrahepatic bile ducts.

 

Option C. HIDA scan is used for diagnosis: This statement is true. Hepatobiliary scintigraphy using technetium-99m-labeled iminodiacetic acid derivatives (HIDA scan) is a valuable diagnostic tool for neonatal cholestasis. It helps distinguish biliary atresia from other causes by demonstrating the absence of radiotracer excretion into the intestine in biliary atresia.

 

Option D. Can be differentiated from other differential diagnoses by biopsy: This statement is true. Liver biopsy remains a cornerstone in the diagnostic evaluation of neonatal cholestasis. Histopathological findings such as bile duct proliferation, portal tract fibrosis, and giant cell transformation can help differentiate biliary atresia from other causes of neonatal cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Kasai procedure (portoenterostomy) for biliary atresia should be performed within 60 days of life, not 90 days, as earlier intervention is associated with better outcomes.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

1. Delirium Tremens (A-3): Benzodiazepines like oxazepam are the first-line treatment for delirium tremens, along with thiamine supplementation. 

 

2. Opioid Overdose (B-4): Naloxone is the specific antidote for opioid overdose. It acts as an opioid antagonist and can rapidly reverse respiratory depression caused by opioids.

 

3. Alcohol Dependence (C-2): Acamprosate is used in alcohol dependence to maintain abstinence by modulating glutamatergic neurotransmission. It reduces craving for alcohol.

 

4. Smoking Cessation (D-1): Varenicline is the most effective medication for smoking cessation. It reduces cravings and withdrawal symptoms by acting as a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

questions.text: What causes maximum hearing loss? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ossicular discontinuity with intact TM

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (around 50 dB) because:

 

  • Sound waves can only travel through the ossicular chain when it is intact
  • When there's a break in the ossicular chain, sound transmission is completely interrupted
  • With intact TM, there's no alternative pathway for sound to reach the inner ear
  • The sound waves get dampened at the point of discontinuity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis media with effusion

 

  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss (30-35 dB)
  • Middle ear filled with serous fluid still allows some sound transmission
  • Common in children with adenoid hypertrophy blocking Eustachian tube

 

Option B. Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

 

  • Represents early otosclerosis
  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss as stapes can still move partially
  • Less severe than complete ossicular discontinuity

 

Option D. Malleus-incus disruption with TM disruption

 

  • Causes around 40 dB hearing loss
  • Less severe than option C because sound waves can reach round window directly through the perforation
  • Provides an alternative pathway for sound transmission

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (50 dB) because sound waves have no alternative pathway to reach the inner ear.

questions.text: Carhart notch is seen in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Otosclerosis

 

Carhart's notch is a characteristic audiometric finding in otosclerosis where there is a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz (2 kHz) on pure tone audiometry. In otosclerosis, there is irregular spongy bone deposition in the anterior part of footplate and adjacent oval window (fissula ante fenestram), which impedes sound conduction and causes conductive hearing loss. When plotting an audiogram, the bone conduction curve shows this specific notch or dip at 2000 Hz, while the air conduction curve remains affected throughout, showing the conductive hearing loss pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sudden SNHL: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss shows a sudden drop in both air and bone conduction curves across all frequencies without any specific notch pattern at 2000 Hz.

 

Option C. Meniere's disease: In Meniere's disease, the audiogram typically shows a low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with an up-sloping curve. There is no specific notch at 2000 Hz.

 

 

Option D. Acoustic neuroma: Acoustic neuroma typically shows a trough-shaped or cookie-bite audiogram pattern affecting the middle frequencies, but does not show the specific Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carhart's notch is a characteristic dip at 2000 Hz on the bone conduction curve in pure tone audiometry, specifically seen in otosclerosis.

 

Important points to remember on otoselerosis:

 

  • Most common site - Fissula ante fenestrum
  • Most common type- Stapedial
  • Other 2 type -Cochlear, Histologic
  • Clinical presentation - Hearing impairment
  • Paracusis willisii (hears better in noisy surroundngs)
  • Otoscopy - Intract tympanic membrane
  • Schwarts sign - Seen in active lesions only, reddish hue seen on promontory through intact TM
  • Tunning fork tests - Rinne negative, Weber to poorer ear → conductive loss
  • Pure tone audiometry -Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve (Carhart's notch)
  • Treatment of choice - Surgery (Stapedotomy > Stapedectomy)
  • Other treatments - NaF, Hearing aid for those not fit for surgery.

questions.text: Identify the PTA. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixed

 

The audiogram shows characteristics of mixed hearing loss where both conductive and sensorineural components are present:

 

  • There is an air-bone gap (separation between air and bone conduction curves) indicating a conductive component
  • The bone conduction curve is below normal (>25 dB) indicating sensorineural component
  • The air conduction shows even greater hearing loss (50-70 dB)
  • Both curves are below normal range but maintain a gap between them

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CHL (Conductive Hearing Loss): In pure conductive hearing loss, bone conduction would be normal (within 25 dB) with only air conduction being affected, creating an air-bone gap. Here bone conduction is also affected.

 

Option B. SNHL (Sensorineural Hearing Loss): In pure SNHL, both air and bone conduction curves would be affected but would be close together without significant gap. Here there is a clear air-bone gap.

 

Option D. None: The audiogram clearly shows pathological findings and cannot be considered normal where both curves would be within 25 dB with no gap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mixed hearing loss, the audiogram shows both bone conduction below normal (SNHL component) and an air-bone gap (conductive component), indicating pathology in both inner ear and middle/outer ear.

 

  • Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap(AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not
  • If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part.
  • If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.

questions.text: Which of the following has the worst prognosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Partial Bilateral Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) Palsy

Explanation for Correct Answer:

Partial Bilateral RLN palsy involves selective paralysis of only the abductor fibers (as per Semon’s Law), while the adductor fibers remain intact. This results in both vocal cords being pulled medially into the median position, due to the unopposed action of the intact adductors and the cricothyroid muscle (innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).

In this median position, the glottic airway is severely compromised, leading to inspiratory stridor, dyspnea, and often acute airway obstruction, despite the voice being relatively preserved.

This situation is life-threatening and usually requires an emergency tracheostomy, making it the worst prognosis among all types.

Explanation for Other Options:

A. Partial Unilateral RLN Palsy

  • Only abductor fibers are affected on one side.
  • The affected vocal cord moves to median position, but the contralateral healthy cord compensates.
  • Voice may be mildly hoarse, but airway is adequate.
  • Good prognosis.

C. Complete Unilateral RLN Palsy

  • Both abductor and adductor fibers are lost on one side.
  • Cord lies in paramedian position (due to passive pull of cricothyroid).
  • Other side compensates for both voice and airway.
  • Moderate prognosis.

D. Complete Bilateral RLN Palsy

  • Both cords lie in paramedian position (both abduction and adduction lost).
  • Airway is compromised but slightly better than in partial bilateral palsy.
  • Often needs tracheostomy, but not as acute as partial bilateral.
  • Serious but not worst prognosis

Semon’s Law:

In progressive organic lesions of the RLN, abductor fibers (posterior cricoarytenoid) are more vulnerable and affected first, while adductor fibers are more resistant. Hence, early (partial) palsy affects only abduction, leading to dangerous median cord positioning.

Comparison Table:

Educational Objective:

Partial bilateral RLN palsy carries the worst prognosis due to medial cord positioning from intact adductors and SLN action, causing life-threatening airway obstruction despite relatively preserved voice.

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image below. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet fracture

 

The image shows a Chevallet fracture pattern. Chevallet fracture is a type of maxillofacial fracture that commonly occurs due to trauma. This type of fracture typically affects the lower jaw (mandible) and is characterized by a specific pattern of breakage along the jawline, often due to a direct impact. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jarjaway fracture: Also known as J-type fracture, has a different fracture line pattern than what was shown in the image.

 

Option C. C-shaped fracture: Has a curved fracture line resembling the letter C, which is different from the pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the first investigation in newborn for audiological assessment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) OAE (Otoacoustic Emissions)

 

OAE is the first choice for newborn hearing screening because:

 

  • It is a simple, quick, and non-invasive test
  • Can be done with a portable device
  • Involves placing a probe in the infant's ear that sends sound stimulus and captures emissions from outer hair cells
  • If result is "pass", indicates normal hearing
  • If result is "refer", then BERA is done as the next step
  • Tests the integrity of outer hair cells in the cochlea
  • Can be performed while baby is sleeping or quiet

Other Options:

 

Option A. BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry): Though essential for newborn screening, it is more complex and time-consuming than OAE. It is used as a second-line test if OAE results are abnormal.

Option B. PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry): Not suitable for newborns as it requires active participation and response from the subject, which newborns cannot provide.

 

Option D. Impedance: Not appropriate as first-line screening in newborns as it primarily tests middle ear function and requires some cooperation from the subject.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OAE is the first-line screening test for newborn hearing assessment due to its simplicity, speed, and non-invasive nature.

 

Newborn screening of hearing:

 

  • Here we test otoacoustic emissions (OAE) and brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA).
  • Outer hair cells in cochlea emit these very low intensity sounds (OAE) & they can be collected by a microphone kept in EAC.
  • Normal OAE means cochlear hair cells are functioning normally and cochlea is normally functioning.
  • BERA tests the integrity of auditory nerve (auditory pathway from cochlea to brain). It is an objective test.
    • Here we give a sound stimulus and check the electrical potentials that arise along the auditory pathway from cochlear nerve to brain.
    • Wave V is most prominent in BERA that corresponds to lateral lemniscus.
    • It is a non-invasive procedure. It is also an objective test (whereas PTA is a subjective test = result depends on the responses given by patient/subject).
  • Normal BERA means the cochlear nerve is intact and conducting sound impulses from cochlea to brain.
  • So, normal OAE and BERA will indicate an almost normal hearing pathway, hence used in newborn screening.
  • BERA is also used to check malingerers (people those who pretend deaf).

questions.text: What is the procedure being done in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stapedotomy

 

The image shows a stapedotomy procedure where:

 

  • The stapes suprastructure has been removed
  • A piston prosthesis is being inserted between the long process of incus and stapes footplate
  • A small fenestration is made in the footplate to connect middle ear with inner ear
