  • This is the treatment of choice for otosclerosis where the stapes footplate is fixed in the oval window
  • The prosthesis restores the ossicular chain continuity and sound transmission

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This involves repairing the tympanic membrane perforation using temporalis fascia or tragal perichondrium graft. The image shows intervention at the level of stapes, not tympanic membrane.

 

Option C. Ossiculoplasty: While this involves reconstruction of ossicular chain, it specifically refers to reconstruction of malleus and incus using either autologous or prosthetic materials (TORP/PORP). The image shows specific intervention at stapes level.

 

Option D. Mastoidectomy: This involves drilling the mastoid bone behind the ear to remove diseased tissue/bone. The image shows middle ear surgery focused on stapes, not mastoid surgery.

 

Educational Objective:


Stapedotomy is the surgical procedure of choice for otosclerosis, involving removal of fixed stapes suprastructure and placement of a piston prosthesis to restore sound transmission.

questions.text: Which opening is present posterior to the marked structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eustachian tube

 

The marked structure appears to be the inferior turbinate, and:

 

  • The Eustachian tube opening is located 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate
  • This represents the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube
  • It connects the middle ear with the nasopharynx
  • The opening appears as a vertical slit on the lateral wall of the nasopharynx
  • Forms an elevation called torus tubarius

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Onodi cell: This is a posterior ethmoid cell that extends superolateral to sphenoid sinus and is closely related to optic nerve. It is not located posterior to inferior turbinate.

Option C. Sphenopalatine foramen: This opening is located posterior to the middle turbinate (not inferior turbinate), about 1 cm behind its posterior end.

Option D. Sphenoid sinus: Opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above and posterior to superior turbinate, not inferior turbinate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Eustachian tube opening is located 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate on the lateral wall of nasopharynx.

questions.text: Identify the audiogram. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Noise-induced hearing loss

 

The audiogram shows:

 

  • Both air and bone conduction curves are close together (no air-bone gap)
  • Normal hearing at lower frequencies (250 Hz, 500 Hz, 1000 Hz, 2000 Hz)
  • Sharp characteristic dip at 4000 Hz (4 kHz)
  • Bilateral involvement (shown in both red color for right ear and blue color for left ear)
  • This pattern is typically seen in factory workers exposed to loud noises

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: Shows conductive hearing loss with Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz (2 kHz), not 4000 Hz. Also has significant air-bone gap which is absent here.

Option C. Meniere's disease: Shows sensorineural hearing loss with up-sloping curve affecting low frequencies. Does not show characteristic dip at 4000 Hz.

Option D. Acoustic neuroma: Shows a banana-shaped or trough pattern affecting middle frequencies, with poor speech discrimination. Does not show isolated 4000 Hz dip.

Educational Objective: 

 

Noise-induced hearing loss has a characteristic audiometric pattern with a sharp dip at 4000 Hz, typically bilateral and symmetrical.

 

  • Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve - Otosclerosis
  • Dip at 4000Hz - Noise induced hearing loss
  • Cookie bite audiogram - Congenital hearing loss mostly
  • Trough shaped audiogram - Acoustic neuroma
  • Up-sloping curve with SNHL - Meniere's disease (low frequencies involved)
  • Down-sloping curve with SNHL - Presycusis (high frequency loss) {Presbycusis - age induced hearing loss. Treatment: hearing aid}.
  • High frequency audiometry is used for detecting ototoxicity.

questions.text: Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Before 34 weeks

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia that develops before 34 weeks of gestation. 

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia:

 

  • Indicates potentially higher severity
  • Is associated with conditions like antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
  • Can be prevented by administering low-dose aspirin

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia occurring before 34 weeks of gestation, while late-onset pre-eclampsia occurs after 34 weeks.

choices.text: Head rotated by 1/8th of a circle
Head rotating due to untwisting of the neck
The shoulder undergoing rotation by 1/8th of circle
The movement by which the head is born

questions.text: What is restitution? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head rotating due to untwisting of the neck

 

Restitution is one of the cardinal movements of labor that occurs after the delivery of the fetal head. During internal rotation, the fetal neck gets twisted by 45 degrees (for example, in Left Occipital Anterior position). Once the head is delivered and free from the bony confines of the pelvis, it naturally untwists to align with the fetal body. This untwisting movement of the head is called restitution.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head rotated by 1/8th of a circle: Incorrect. Restitution isn't defined by the degree of rotation (though a 45-degree rotation is approximately 1/8th of a circle). Rather, restitution specifically refers to the untwisting mechanism and its purpose.

 

Option C. The shoulder undergoing rotation by 1/8th of circle: Incorrect. Shoulder rotation occurs after restitution and is part of a different cardinal step called external rotation. During external rotation, the shoulders enter the pelvis and undergo internal rotation, which manifests as the head rotating externally.

 

Option D. The movement by which the head is born: Incorrect. This describes extension, which is the movement that occurs when the head is being delivered, before restitution takes place.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Restitution is the untwisting movement of the fetal head that occurs after delivery of the head, correcting the twist that occurred during internal rotation.

questions.text:
A couple has been attempting to conceive for the past two years with unprotected intercourse yet without success, the husband's semen analysis was ordered and results are as follows: 

 

  • Volume: 2ml
  • Viability: 75%
  • Sperm count: 40 million per ejaculate

 

The wife’s HSG report shows no abnormalities. What percentage of infertile women have unexplained infertility? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15%

 

In cases of infertility, the distribution of causes follows a specific pattern:

 

  • Female factor infertility: 40%
  • Male factor infertility: 30%
  • Combined male and female factors: 15%
  • Unexplained infertility: 15%

 

Unexplained infertility is diagnosed when:

 

  • Standard fertility tests are normal
  • No obvious cause is identified despite thorough evaluation
  • Tests showing normal results include: 
    • Ovulation tests
    • Tubal patency (HSG)
    • Uterine cavity evaluation
    • Semen analysis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Unexplained infertility accounts for 15% of all infertility cases, while female factor accounts for 40%, male factor for 30%, and combined factors for 15%.

questions.text: Which step is not included in active management of third stage of labor (AMTSL)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bimanual compression

 

Active Management of Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) consists of three basic components as defined by WHO in the early 2000s:

 

  1. Administration of oxytocics (primarily oxytocin)
  2. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT)
  3. Uterine massage (now termed as postpartum vigilance)

 

An additional component that has been recently added is delayed cord clamping, though this is primarily for preventing neonatal anemia rather than preventing postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine massage: Uterine massage is a core component of AMTSL. While the terminology has evolved to "postpartum vigilance," it remains an essential step where the uterus is checked and massaged if not well contracted.

 

Option C. CCT (Controlled Cord Traction): CCT is one of the three basic steps of AMTSL.

 

Option D. Administration of oxytocics: Administration of oxytocics, particularly oxytocin, is the first and crucial step of AMTSL.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bimanual compression is a treatment method for atonic postpartum hemorrhage, not a preventive measure in AMTSL. The three basic components of AMTSL are: administration of oxytocics, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage/postpartum vigilance.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea presents to the outpatient department with complaints of an inability to pass urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, a bluish hue is observed in the vagina. What is the most likely cause of her condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate Hymen

 

The features in this case pointing to imperforate hymen are:

 

  • Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain (cryptomenorrhea)
  • Urinary retention
  • Bluish hue/bulge in vagina
  • Adolescent age group

 

The bluish hue is pathognomonic of imperforate hymen as the collected menstrual blood (hematocolpos) is visible through the thin hymenal membrane.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: While it can present similarly like imperforate hymen, a transverse vaginal septum is thicker and would not show the characteristic bluish hue. An MRI would be needed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome: This condition involves absence of uterus. There would be no menstrual blood collection and thus no cyclical pain or bluish hue, as there is no uterus to generate menstrual flow.

 

Option D. OHVIRA syndrome: This presents with normal menstruation as there is only partial obstruction of vagina (hemivagina) and uterine didelphys. Patients typically have gradually worsening dysmenorrhea and may develop endometriosis. It is associated with ipsilateral renal agenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imperforate hymen presents with primary amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, and urinary retention in adolescent girls. The pathognomonic finding is a bluish bulge in the vagina due to collected menstrual blood (hematocolpos).

questions.text: A 24-year-old athlete woman presents the gyne clinic with complaints of secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. She has a history of low body weight and occasional dieting to maintain her physique with a current BMI of 17.5. Laboratory investigations reveal the following hormone levels LH=0.3, FSH=2, Prolactin=20ng, TSH: 1.2, BMI: 17.5. She likely to suffer from? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

 

The features in this case point to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

 

  • Low FSH and LH levels (FSH=2, LH=0.3) - normal values are usually between 2-10
  • Athletic female with low BMI (17.5)
  • History of dieting and low body weight This condition is typically seen in athletes and women with low BMI, where reduced body fat leads to decreased production of gonadotropins (LH and FSH) by the pituitary gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary ovarian insufficiency: Incorrect because this condition presents with high FSH and LH values due to lack of negative feedback from the ovaries.

 

Option C. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism: Incorrect because this presents with high, not low, gonadotropin levels.

 

Option D. Normogonadotropic normogonadism: Incorrect because the patient has low, not normal, gonadotropin levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in female athletes is characterized by:

 

  • Low FSH and LH levels (<2)
  • Associated with low BMI and excessive exercise
  • Common cause of secondary amenorrhea in athletes

questions.text: Shortest anterior posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obstetric conjugate

 

The obstetric conjugate is the shortest anterior-posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet through which the baby passes during delivery. It extends from the sacral promontory to a point on the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis. This is the clinically significant diameter as it represents the actual space available for fetal descent.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Anatomical conjugate (also called true conjugate): This extends from the sacral promontory to the upper border of pubic symphysis. While it is a pelvic measurement, it has no clinical significance.

 

Option B. Diagonal conjugate: This is measured during pelvic examination from the sacral promontory to the lower border of pubic symphysis. When 1.5 cm is subtracted from the diagonal conjugate, we get the obstetric conjugate.

 

 Option D. True conjugate: This is the same as the anatomical conjugate, extending from the sacral promontory to the upper border of pubic symphysis. It has no clinical significance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The obstetric conjugate is the shortest and most clinically significant anterior-posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet, measuring from the sacral promontory to the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis. The diagonal conjugate can be measured clinically, and subtracting 1.5 cm from it gives the obstetric conjugate.

choices.text: Abdominal pain or discomfort is the commonest presentation for ectopic in 90%
Oral methotrexate is the choice of medical management in patient with shock
Ectopic pregnancy is increased in patient with history of PID
Patient will have reduced levels of progesterone but is not diagnostic

questions.text: A 26-year woman with six weeks of amenorrhea presents with sharp lower abdominal pain, light vaginal spotting and a bp of 90/ 60 mmHg.  pelvic exam reveals right adnexal tenderness. Choose the incorrect statement about this condition. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral methotrexate is the choice of medical management in patient with shock

 

The clinical scenario describes a classic presentation of ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the triad of amenorrhea, pain, and vaginal bleeding, along with signs of shock (BP 90/60 mmHg) and adnexal tenderness. The statement about oral methotrexate is incorrect because:

 

  1. Methotrexate is given as an intramuscular injection, not orally
  2. Medical management is contraindicated in patients with shock; they require immediate surgical intervention
  3. Hemodynamic instability is an absolute contraindication to medical management

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Abdominal pain or discomfort is the commonest presentation for ectopic in 90%: Pain is indeed the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy, occurring in approximately 90% of cases. The clinical triad includes pain, amenorrhea, and vaginal bleeding.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy is increased in patient with history of PID: PID increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy by causing salpingitis, which reduces tubal motility and can lead to implantation within the fallopian tube.

 

Option D. Patient will have reduced levels of progesterone but is not diagnostic: While progesterone levels are typically lower in ectopic pregnancy compared to normal intrauterine pregnancy, this finding is not diagnostic and is not used for clinical decision-making.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Medical management with methotrexate is contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy with hemodynamic instability (shock); such cases require immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: An HPE image of the endometrium is shown. The hormone responsible for this is secreted by? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corpus luteum 

 

The image shows secretory phase endometrium, characterized by tortuous glands rather than straight tubular glands seen in proliferative phase. The secretory changes in the endometrium are caused by progesterone, which is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum during the post-ovulatory (luteal) phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary follicle: This structure produces estrogen, not progesterone, and is present in the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle. It does not cause secretory changes in the endometrium.

 

Option C. Granulosa cells: While these cells are important components of follicles and contribute to hormone production, they primarily produce estrogen as part of the developing follicle, not the progesterone responsible for secretory changes.

 

Option D. Theca interna: These cells work with granulosa cells to produce estrogen during the follicular phase. They are not responsible for progesterone production that causes secretory endometrial changes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Secretory changes in the endometrium are caused by progesterone, which is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Which is not an indication of instrumental vaginal delivery? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CPD (Cephalopelvic Disproportion)

 

CPD is not an indication for instrumental delivery because when there is a disproportion between the fetal head and maternal pelvis, attempting instrumental delivery would be dangerous and ineffective. In cases of CPD, cesarean section is the appropriate mode of delivery as attempting to force the baby through an inadequate pelvis could cause trauma to both mother and baby.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal distress: It is a valid indication for instrumental delivery. When there is fetal distress in the second stage of labor, expedited delivery via forceps or vacuum can help prevent adverse fetal outcomes.

 

Option C. Maternal exhaustion: It is a valid indication for instrumental delivery. When the mother is too exhausted to effectively push, instrumental delivery can assist in the birth process.

 

Option D. Prolonged 2nd stage labour: It is a valid indication for instrumental delivery. When the second stage is prolonged (without CPD), instrumental delivery can help achieve vaginal birth and prevent complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CPD is an absolute contraindication for instrumental vaginal delivery and requires cesarean section, while fetal distress, maternal exhaustion, and prolonged second stage (without CPD) are valid indications for instrumental delivery.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presented with malodorous vaginal discharge and whiff test positive. What is the likely cause? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacterial vaginosis

 

The important finding in this case is the positive whiff test, which is a specific diagnostic criterion for bacterial vaginosis (BV). The whiff test, also known as the KOH test, produces a characteristic fishy or ammonia-like odor when potassium hydroxide is added to the vaginal discharge. This is one of the Amsel criteria used to diagnose BV.

 

BV diagnosis requires three out of four Amsel criteria:

 

  1. Homogeneous gray-white discharge adhering to vaginal walls
  2. Positive whiff test
  3. Vaginal pH > 4.5 (alkaline)
  4. Presence of clue cells on microscopy (vaginal epithelial cells studded with bacteria)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Candidiasis: Incorrect because candidal infections typically present with thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge and do not have a positive whiff test. The discharge is usually odorless.

 

Option C. Trichomoniasis: Incorrect because while trichomoniasis can cause malodorous discharge, it typically presents with frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and does not give a positive whiff test.

 

Option D. Neisseria: Incorrect because Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection typically presents with purulent discharge and does not give a positive whiff test. The discharge is often yellow-green and may be accompanied by cervical inflammation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A positive whiff test is a key diagnostic criterion for bacterial vaginosis as part of the Amsel criteria, where 3 out of 4 criteria must be present for diagnosis.

choices.text: Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation
All preterm babies irrespective of birth weight
Vigorous term and preterm babies not requiring resuscitation
All term babies irrespective of birth weight

questions.text: When is delayed cord clamping done? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vigorous term and preterm babies not requiring resuscitation

 

According to WHO guidelines, delayed cord clamping should be performed in all vigorous term and preterm babies who do not require resuscitation. This practice has been incorporated into the active management of third stage of labor (AMTSL) protocol. The primary benefit is the prevention of neonatal anemia, with particular effectiveness in preterm infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation: Incorrect because it excludes preterm babies, who benefit more from delayed cord clamping

 

Option B. All preterm babies irrespective of birth weight: Incorrect because it includes preterm babies requiring resuscitation, which is a contraindication for delayed cord clamping

 

Option D. All term babies irrespective of birth weight: Incorrect because it includes babies requiring resuscitation, which is a contraindication for delayed cord clamping

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delayed cord clamping should be performed in all vigorous term and preterm babies not requiring resuscitation, with the only contraindication being the need for immediate resuscitation in an asphyxiated baby.

questions.text: A 16 weeks pregnant woman planned for Anomaly scan. Following the scan, the patient was advised to take a Quadruple test. Which is not part of the Quadruple test? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dimeric Inhibin B

 

The quadruple test is a second-trimester screening test performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy. The correct components of the quadruple test are:

 

  1. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  2. Beta hCG
  3. Inhibin A (not B)
  4. Unconjugated estriol

 

In pregnancies with Down syndrome:

 

  • Beta hCG and Inhibin A levels are elevated
  • AFP and unconjugated estriol levels are decreased

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The quadruple test consists of four specific markers: AFP, beta hCG, Inhibin A (not B), and unconjugated estriol. Dimeric Inhibin B is not a component of this test.

questions.text: Mitochondria of spermatozoa form the: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle piece


The mitochondria of spermatozoa are specifically located in the middle piece of the sperm. The middle piece contains numerous mitochondria arranged in a helical pattern around the axoneme. These mitochondria are essential for providing the energy required for sperm motility through ATP production.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Head sheath: Incorrect because the head contains the nucleus and acrosome, not mitochondria 

 

Option B. Connecting part: Incorrect as it's just a transitional region 

 

Option D. Tail: Incorrect as the tail (principal piece and end piece) contains the axoneme and outer dense fibers but no mitochondria

 

Educational Objective: 


The mitochondria of spermatozoa are specifically located in the middle piece, providing energy for sperm motility.

choices.text: Increase SBP and DBP at 6 weeks

questions.text: Physiological changes in pregnancy include all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in SBP and DBP at 6 weeks

 

During pregnancy, blood pressure decreases throughout pregnancy, with the maximum fall occurring in the second trimester. This is a normal physiological adaptation. An increase in blood pressure (either systolic or diastolic) is not a normal physiological change and could indicate a pathological condition like preeclampsia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fasting Hypoglycemia and Postprandial Hyperglycemia: This is incorrect as this is a normal physiological change in pregnancy. Pregnant women experience fasting hypoglycemia and postprandial hyperglycemia as part of normal pregnancy adaptation.

 

Option C. Increase in RBC mass: This is incorrect as this is a normal physiological change. During pregnancy, there is an increase in RBC mass, although the increase in plasma volume is proportionally greater, leading to physiological anemia.

 

Option D. Peripheral Insulin Resistance: This is incorrect as this is a normal physiological change. Pregnancy is characterized by increased peripheral insulin resistance, which puts women at higher risk of developing gestational diabetes mellitus.

 

Educational Objective: 


Blood pressure normally decreases during pregnancy, with maximum fall in the second trimester. Any increase in blood pressure during pregnancy is abnormal and requires evaluation.

choices.text: Pap smear + HPV DNA every 5 yearly

questions.text: Dr. Savita is posted in a low-resource hospital setting. She explains to a patient about risk factors of cervical cancer, including HPV. Which of the following would be appropriate for cervical cancer screening? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pap smear alone every 3 yearly

 

In a low-resource hospital setting, Pap smear alone every 3 years is the most appropriate screening method for cervical cancer. The screening should begin at age 21 years (some guidelines recommend 25 years). While HPV testing has become the method of choice in many updated guidelines, in resource-limited settings, Pap smear remains the primary screening tool due to its cost-effectiveness and established infrastructure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pap smear alone every 5 yearly: Incorrect because the recommended interval for Pap smear screening is 3 years, not 5 years. Five-yearly screening is appropriate for HPV testing or co-testing.

 

Option B. Pap smear + HPV DNA every 5 yearly: Incorrect because while co-testing is an acceptable method, it increases costs and is not the method of choice in low-resource settings. This option would unnecessarily increase the financial burden.

 

Option D. Pap smear in high-risk individuals: Incorrect because cervical cancer screening should be done in all eligible women, not just high-risk individuals. Universal screening is essential for effective prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In low-resource settings, cervical cancer screening should be done using Pap smear alone every 3 years, starting from age 21 years.

questions.text: A 24-year-old P1L1 woman presented with acute abdominal pain. She has a H/O RHD and recently went for mitral valve replacement and is currently on warfarin therapy. On examination, there is a 14-week size abdominal pelvic mass and on USG, a 6 × 8 cm unilocular cyst with reticular appearance is seen. What is the next best step in management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical exploration

 

In this case, surgical exploration is the best next step because:

 

  • The patient has a large (6×8 cm) symptomatic ovarian cyst with reticular appearance suggesting hemorrhage
  • The hemorrhagic nature is likely due to warfarin therapy
  • Due to the large size and symptoms (acute abdominal pain), conservative management is not appropriate
  • However, before surgery: 
    • Anticoagulation needs to be stopped
    • INR needs to be corrected (may require vitamin K)
    • Patient may need bridging with heparin
    • Surgery should be performed only after coagulation parameters are normalized

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. MRI:

 

  • Not necessary as USG has already provided clear visualization of the cyst
  • Won't add significant diagnostic value given the clear hemorrhagic appearance on USG

 

Option C. Follow up:

 

  • Not appropriate for a large (6*8 cm) symptomatic cyst
  • Conservative management is suitable for smaller, asymptomatic cysts
  • Risk of continued hemorrhage due to anticoagulation

 

Option D. Measure Ca-125:

 

  • Not indicated as the imaging characteristics suggest a benign hemorrhagic cyst
  • Patient is young and USG findings are not suspicious for malignancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large hemorrhagic ovarian cysts in patients on anticoagulation require surgical management after correcting coagulation parameters.

questions.text: The primary oocyte is arrested in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prophase

 

In oogenesis, the primary oocyte is arrested in prophase of meiosis I. specifically the diplotene stage. This arrest occurs before birth and continues until puberty. The primary oocytes are formed when primordial germ cells undergo mitosis. These primary oocytes then enter meiosis I but get arrested in prophase I. This arrested state continues until puberty, when hormonal changes trigger the resumption of meiosis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pachytene: This is incorrect. While pachytene is a sub-stage of prophase I, the question asks for the main phase of arrest, which is prophase.

 

Option C. Leptotene: This is incorrect. Like pachytene, leptotene is also a sub-stage of prophase I, not the main phase where arrest occurs.

 

Option D: Metaphase: The secondary oocyte arrests in metaphase 2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary oocytes are arrested in prophase of meiosis I from fetal life until puberty. This arrest is a crucial event in female reproductive development and understanding of oogenesis.

questions.text: Breast cancer of size 6 x 8 cm with dimpling with invasion of Pectoralis Major and ipsilateral matted axillary nodes belongs to what TNM stage? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T3N2M0

 

  • Tumor size > 5 cm = T3
  • Skin dimpling does not affect T stage (common misconception)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major does not affect T stage
  • Only skin ulceration, peau d'orange, or satellite nodules make it T4b
  • Ipsilateral matted axillary nodes = N2
  • No mention of distant metastasis = M0


Other Options: 

 

Option B. T4bN1M0:

 

  • Skin dimpling alone does not make it T4b
  • N1 represents mobile nodes, while the question mentions matted nodes (N2)
     

Option C. T4aN2M0:

 

  • T4a represents chest wall invasion (not including pectoralis major)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major alone does not make it T4a
     

Option D. T2N2M1:

 

  • T2 is for tumors 2-5 cm, this tumor is > 5 cm

  • No evidence of distant metastasis (M1)

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skin dimpling and pectoralis major invasion do not affect T stage in breast cancer TNM staging
  • T3 stage is for tumors > 5 cm
  • Matted axillary nodes represent N2 disease

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of prior neck radiation for lymphoma is diagnosed with 2 x 3 cm papillary thyroid cancer. No lymph node enlargement is present. What is the treatment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total thyroidectomy

 

Explanation: 

 

Total thyroidectomy is now the preferred approach only for those differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) at higher risk for recurrence:

  • Tumor at least  4 cm 
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension 
  • Evidence of metastatic disease 
  • Radiation-induced DTC (mentioned in the history) 
  • Familial non-medullary thyroid cancer 
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemithyroidectomy:

 

  • History of radiation is a high-risk feature requiring total thyroidectomy
  • Hemithyroidectomy is reserved for low-risk, small unifocal tumors without risk factors

 

Option C. Hemithyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • MRND is not indicated without clinical lymphadenopathy
  • MRND is mainly done for medullary thyroid cancer
  • Hemithyroidectomy is inadequate given the radiation history

 

Option D. Total Thyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • No lymph node involvement noted
  • For papillary thyroid cancer without lymphadenopathy, central compartment (level VI) clearance may be done, but not MRND

 

Educational Objective: 

 

History of radiation exposure is an absolute indication for total thyroidectomy in differentiated thyroid cancer, regardless of tumor size.

questions.text: Which of these is not a component/adjunct of the primary survey in trauma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CECT

 

Primary survey adjuncts include:

 

  • Chest X-ray
  • Pelvic X-ray
  • eFAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma)
  • ECG
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Arterial blood gas
  • Urinary catheter
  • Nasogastric tube
  • CECT is part of secondary survey, performed only in hemodynamically stable patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray:

 

  • Essential adjunct to primary survey
  • Quickly identifies life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax

 

Option B. Pelvic X-ray:

 

  • Important adjunct in primary survey
  • Identifies pelvic fractures which can cause major hemorrhage
  • Guides immediate management decisions

 

Option C. Extended FAST :

 

  • Critical bedside tool in primary survey
  • Rapidly identifies free fluid in abdomen/chest
  • Particularly valuable in unstable patients

 

Educational Objective: 

 

CECT is not a component of primary survey - it belongs to secondary survey and is performed only in hemodynamically stable patients.

choices.text: Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids
Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray
Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT
Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery

questions.text: A patient with a history of chest trauma with breathlessness on examination is found to have systolic BP of 90 mmHg, SpO2 of 85%, GCS 8/15, absent breath sounds. What is the next step? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids

 

Following ATLS principles (A, B, C, D):

 

  • GCS 8/15 ("GCS below 8, intubate") indicates need for immediate airway protection
  • SpO2 85% with absent breath sounds suggests respiratory compromise needing ICD
  • BP 90 mmHg indicates a need for fluid resuscitation. This option follows the correct sequence of resuscitation:
    • Airway (A)
    • Breathing (B) - ICD placement
    • Circulation (C) - IV fluids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray:

 

  • Skips airway management in a patient with GCS 8/15
  • Atropine not indicated in this scenario
  • Imaging should not precede resuscitation

 

Option C. Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT:

 

  • Neglects immediate airway and breathing issues
  • CT scan inappropriate before stabilization
  • IV dextrose not indicated in acute trauma

 

Option D. Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery:

 

  • Ignores immediate airway and breathing concerns
  • Surgery evaluation premature before stabilization
  • Violates ATLS principles of prioritization

 

Educational Objective: 


In trauma, follow ABCDE sequence.

questions.text: A wound was left open initially, with debridement and cleaning performed for 5 days before it was closed by sutures. What type of wound healing is this? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tertiary intention

 

Tertiary intention (delayed primary healing):

 

  • Wound initially left open
  • Allowed to develop healthy granulation tissue
  • Closure performed after controlling infection/contamination
  • Also called delayed primary closure
  • Results in better healing than secondary intention
  • Common in contaminated wounds

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary intention:

 

  • Occurs when the wound is left open to heal on its own
  • No surgical closure is performed
  • Results in wider scar

 

Option C. Primary intention:

 

  • Immediate closure of clean wound edges
  • No period of open wound management
  • No delayed closure component
  • Results in thin linear scar

 

Option D. Quaternary: This is not a recognized type of wound healing

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tertiary intention (delayed primary healing) involves initial open wound management followed by surgical closure after the development of healthy granulation tissue.

questions.text: Earliest/most common symptom of CA esophagus? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysphagia more to solids

 

In carcinoma esophagus:

 

  • Progressive dysphagia first to solids, then to liquids is the earliest and most common symptom
  • Occurs due to mechanical obstruction from tumor growth
  • Liquids can initially pass through a narrowed lumen
  • Typically presents in elderly smoker males
  • By the time symptoms appear, the disease is usually advanced

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysphagia more to liquids:

 

  • Characteristic of motility disorders like achalasia
  • In mechanical obstruction, liquids can initially pass-through

 

Option C. Regurgitation:

 

  • Secondary symptom occurring after dysphagia
  • Not the earliest manifestation
  • Occurs when obstruction becomes significant

 

Option D. Lump:

 

  • Rare presentation in esophageal cancer
  • May occur in cervical esophageal tumors
  • Not an early symptom

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Progressive dysphagia, initially more to solids than liquids, is the earliest and most common symptom of carcinoma esophagus.

questions.text: A patient with oral cancer as shown. What is the T stage? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T4a

 

Based on TNM staging for oral cancer:

 

  • Invasion of the floor of the mouth is considered T4a as per AJCC staging
  • Tumor invading floor of mouth indicates local invasion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2:

 

  • T2 represents tumor 2-4 cm without deep invasion
  • Does not account for floor-of-mouth involvement

 

Option B. T3:

 

  • T3 represents tumor >4 cm without deep invasion
  • Does not account for local invasion

 

Option D. T4b:

 

  • Represents very advanced local disease
  • Involves masticator space, pterygoid plates, skull base
  • Involves encasement of internal carotid artery
  • These structures not involved in this case

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Invasion of floor of mouth in oral cancer represents T4a disease, indicating moderately advanced but resectable local disease.

choices.text: Pain occurs on walking a fixed distance and is relieved by rest
Pain occurs immediately on standing and improves on bending forward
Pain is worse at night in bed and at rest
Pain occurs on taking the first step

questions.text: Which of these is true about intermittent claudication? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain occurs on walking a fixed distance and is relieved by rest

 

Intermittent claudication characteristics:

 

  • Pain occurs after walking a predictable distance
  • Distance is relatively fixed for each patient
  • Pain is relieved by rest within minutes
  • Indicates chronic peripheral arterial disease
  • Due to inadequate blood flow during exercise

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pain occurs immediately on standing and improves on bending forward:

 

  • This describes neurogenic claudication
  • Characteristic of lumbar canal stenosis
  • Not related to vascular insufficiency

 

Option C. Pain is worse at night in bed and at rest:

 

  • This describes rest pain
  • Feature of critical limb ischemia
  • Advanced stage of peripheral arterial disease
  • Not intermittent claudication

 

Option D. Pain occurs on taking the first step:

 

  • Feature of neurogenic claudication
  • Seen in spinal canal stenosis
  • Not characteristic of vascular disease

 

Educational Objective: 


Intermittent claudication is characterized by pain occurring after walking a fixed distance and being relieved by rest, similar to angina of the legs.

questions.text: What is the angle between the laparoscopic working port and telescope called? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azimuth angle

 

In laparoscopic surgery:

 

  • Azimuth angle: Angle between working port and telescope (15-30 degrees)
  • Essential for ergonomic comfort during surgery
  • Prevents instrument clash with camera
  • Not possible to generate in single incision laparoscopic surgery
  • Inadequate angle leads to difficulty in surgery

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Elevation angle:

 

  • This is the angle between instrument and abdominal wall
  • Refers to vertical orientation of instruments
  • Not related to telescope-port relationship

 

Option C. Working angle:

 

  • Not a standard term in laparoscopic ergonomics
  • No specific angle is defined by this term

 

Option D. Manipulation angle:

 

  • This is the angle between two working ports
  • Refers to the angle between the surgeon's right and left-hand instruments
  • Different from telescope-port relationship

 

Educational Objective:

 

The angle between the laparoscopic working port and telescope is called the Azimuth angle, which should ideally be 15-30 degrees for optimal ergonomics.

questions.text: A patient who is suffering from a pressure sore on examination is found to have partially broken skin with a shallow ulcer. What is the grade of the sore? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

Pressure sore grading:

 

  • Grade 1: Non-blanching erythema with intact skin
  • Grade 2: Partial thickness skin loss involving epidermis/dermis, shallow ulcer
  • Grade 3: Full thickness skin loss with visible subcutaneous fat
  • Grade 4: Full thickness tissue loss with exposed bone/muscle/tendon In this case,  partial skin loss with shallow ulcer indicates Grade 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 1:

 

  • Only shows non-blanching erythema
  • Skin remains intact
  • No ulceration present

 

Option C. Grade 3:

 

  • Shows full-thickness skin loss
  • Subcutaneous fat visible
  • Deeper than described in question

 

Option D. Grade 4:

 

  • Represents full thickness tissue loss
  • Exposes deeper structures (bone/muscle/tendon)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade 2 pressure sore is characterized by partial thickness skin loss with shallow ulceration, without exposure of deeper tissues.

 

Stages:

 

  1. Non blanching erythema with intact skin
  2. Partial thickness skin loss (some skin intact)
  3. Full thickness loss (subcut, Fat seen)
  4. Subcut, Loss (deep fascia/muscles/bones tendons seen)

 

 

Management:

 

  • Avoid continuous supine position → frequent change in position 
  • Use of air mattress/water bed
  • Cover the pressure sore: fascia lata flap/ negative pressure wound therapy (VAC dressing)

choices.text: Lipase is more specific than amylase
Lipase requires 30 days to return to baseline
Lipase reflects the severity of pancreatitis
More than 75% of cases have hypercalcemia on admission

questions.text: Which of these is seen in acute pancreatitis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipase is more specific than amylase

 

Lipase is indeed more specific than amylase in diagnosing acute pancreatitis. Amylase can be elevated in multiple other acute GI emergencies, while lipase elevation is more specific to pancreatic pathology. Lipase typically returns to baseline within 1-2 weeks (usually 12-15 days), not 30 days as stated in option B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipase requires 30 days to return to baseline: Incorrect. Lipase returns to baseline in 1-2 weeks, not 30 days

 

Option C. Lipase reflects the severity of pancreatitis: Incorrect. Neither lipase nor amylase levels reflect disease severity. Severity is assessed using other parameters like:

 

  • Atlanta classification
  • BISAP score
  • Older scoring systems like Ranson's criteria
  • CT severity index

 

Option D. More than 75% of cases have hypercalcemia on admission: Incorrect. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically develop hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, due to saponification of calcium with free fatty acids. Hypercalcemia is very unusual in acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Lipase is more pancreas-specific than amylase and is the preferred diagnostic marker for acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase does NOT indicate severity.
  • Most patients have hypocalcemia, NOT hypercalcemia.
  • Severity is assessed using clinical scores (BISAP, Ranson’s, APACHE-II) and imaging.

 

1st Investigation:

 

  1. Pancreatic enzymes are elevated in blood
    • Serum amylase (non specific) → rises early (4-6 hours of attack)
    • Serum lipase → rises 12-24 hours later (sensitive and specific, test of choice)
  2. Imaging → no need for diagnosis, only when unsure of dx, rule out etiology like gall stone Imaging modality of choice → CECT abdomen (done after 72 hours of symptoms)

questions.text: During the separation of the spleen from the stomach while performing splenectomy, bleeding is likely to occur from which source? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Short gastric artery


During splenectomy, when separating the spleen from the stomach near the fundus, the short gastric vessels are most likely to bleed. These vessels are branches of the splenic artery that supply the fundus of the stomach. The short gastric vessels run in the gastrosplenic ligament connecting the fundus of the stomach to the splenic hilum. These vessels must be divided during splenectomy and can be a source of bleeding during or after the procedure.

 

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Left gastroepiploic artery: Incorrect. Left gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach and is not typically encountered during the fundal dissection of splenectomy.

 

Option C. Right gastroepiploic artery: Incorrect. Right gastroepiploic artery is on the right side of the greater curvature and is not involved in splenic dissection.

 

Option D. Splenic artery: Incorrect. The main splenic artery runs at a lower level on the superior border of the pancreas and is not encountered during the fundal dissection. It would only be encountered during posterior dissection or pancreatic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:


Short gastric vessels running in the gastrosplenic ligament between the splenic hilum and gastric fundus are the most likely source of bleeding during splenic dissection from stomach during splenectomy.

questions.text: A patient reports pain in the right upper abdomen. An ultrasound-guided FNAC of liver cysts reveals the presence of a parasitic organism. Which of the following is most likely to be the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

Echinococcus granulosus is the causative organism for hydatid cyst of the liver. The diagnosis is based on:

 

  • Location - Liver is the most common site for hydatid cysts
  • Imaging - Characteristic appearance on ultrasound
  • FNAC findings - Demonstrates scolices and hooklets of Echinococcus
  • Life cycle involves: 
    • Definitive host: Dog
    • Intermediate host: Sheep
    • Accidental host: Humans (dead end)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Taenia saginata : Incorrect. Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) does not typically cause liver cysts. It mainly affects the intestine.

 

Option C. Taenia solium: Incorrect. Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) is associated with neurocysticercosis affecting the brain and muscles, not liver cysts.

 

Option D. H. nana: Incorrect. Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is an intestinal parasite and does not cause liver cysts.

 

Educational Objective: 


Echinococcus granulosus is the causative organism for hydatid cysts of the liver, which is the most common site of hydatid disease.

choices.text: Insulinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Gastrinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Gastrinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Insulinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer shows increased gastrin levels upon pentagastrin stimulation. What is the probable diagnosis and its anatomical boundaries? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastrinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum


The clinical presentation and elevated gastrin levels indicate Gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). The anatomical area where gastrinomas are commonly found is called the Triangle of Passaro, which is bounded by:

 

  • Cystic duct superiorly
  • Second and third parts of duodenum medially
  • Head and neck of pancreas forming the third boundary.
  • Most common location within this triangle is the duodenum. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by:
    • Elevated fasting serum gastrin
    • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) shows 100% positivity

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Insulinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. Insulinoma presents with Whipple's triad and hypoglycemia, not elevated gastrin levels.

 

Option B. Gastrinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. While gastrinoma is correct, the CBD is not the correct anatomical boundary - it's the cystic duct.

 

Option D. Insulinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. Neither the diagnosis (insulinoma) nor the anatomical boundary (CBD) is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrinoma occurs within the Triangle of Passaro, bounded by the cystic duct, 2nd and 3rd parts of duodenum, and head/neck of pancreas, with duodenum being the most common location.

 

Gastrinoma

 

  • Malignant
  • Present in triangle of passaro
  • MC site: duodenum (D1)

 

 

Clinical feature: due to hypergastrinemia – Zollinger ellison syndrome

 

  1. Recurrent peptic ulcer
  2. Ulcer at abnormal location
  3. Acid induced diarrhea

choices.text: Scintigraphy (MIBG) followed by focused neck exploration for parathyroid removal
Perform a DEXA scan, and if normal, will rule out the need for surgery
Assess Creatinine clearance, if > 80 mandates need for surgery

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with findings of hypercalcemia of 12.8 mg% and elevated PTH levels is found to have a 1.5 cm mass below the thyroid. What is the next step? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scintigraphy (MIBG) followed by focused neck exploration for parathyroid removal

 

This is a case of primary hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid adenoma based on:

 

  • Elevated calcium (12.8 mg%)
  • Elevated PTH
  • Mass below thyroid 

 

Management involves:

 

  1. Localization of adenoma through scintigraphy
  2. Minimally invasive/focused neck exploration
  3. Removal of adenoma
  4. Intraoperative confirmation using Miami criteria (>50% fall in PTH level after 10 minutes of adenoma removal)

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Perform a DEXA scan, and if normal, will rule out the need for surgery: Incorrect. DEXA scan is used to assess bone density but does not alone determine the need for surgery in primary hyperparathyroidism with clear biochemical abnormalities.

 

Option C. Assess Creatinine clearance, if > 80 mandates need for surgery: Incorrect. Creatinine clearance is more relevant in secondary hyperparathyroidism associated with CKD. In primary hyperparathyroidism, the decision for surgery is based on calcium levels, symptoms, and the presence of adenoma.

 

Option D. No surgery, only surveillance needed: Incorrect. With significant hypercalcemia and a visible mass, surveillance alone is inadequate. Surgical removal is indicated.

 

Educational Objective: 


Primary hyperparathyroidism with elevated calcium, elevated PTH, and visible adenoma, the management involves localization through scintigraphy followed by focused surgical removal.

questions.text: Which of the following drug binds to CD4 receptors and is used for both CCR-5 as well as CXCR-4 tropic HIV? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ibalizumab

 

Explanation: 


Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors. After HIV attaches to CD4 via GP120, ibalizumab prevents the conformational change in the CD4 receptor that is necessary for viral entry. Since it acts directly on CD4 receptors, it is effective against both CCR5 and CXCR4-tropic HIV strains.


Entry Inhibitors

 

 

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Maraviroc: This is a CCR5 co-receptor antagonist. It only works against CCR5-tropic HIV and is ineffective against CXCR4-tropic strains.

 

Option C. Fostemsavir: This is an attachment inhibitor that binds to viral GP120, preventing initial attachment to CD4 receptors. It does not bind to CD4 receptors directly.

 

Option D. Tenofovir: This is a Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NRTI). It works after viral entry by inhibiting viral DNA synthesis. It does not affect viral entry or bind to CD4 receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 


Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors and prevents HIV from entering T-cells by inhibiting conformational changes required for interaction with CCR5 and CXCR4 co-receptors. It is useful in multidrug-resistant HIV cases where other entry inhibitors like Maraviroc (CCR5-specific) are ineffective.

questions.text: Match the correct antidote with the given drug toxicity: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzodiazepine: Flumazenil

 

Explanation: 


Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity. Mechanism - it acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor site on the GABA-A receptor complex. By competitively blocking these receptors, it can rapidly reverse benzodiazepine-induced sedation and respiratory depression.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Atropine: L-carnitine: Incorrect. Physostigmine is the antidote for atropine poisoning as it can reverse both peripheral and central anticholinergic effects. L-carnitine is used specifically for valproate-induced hepatotoxicity.

 

Option B. Barbiturate: Fomepizole: Incorrect. Barbiturates do not have a specific antidote - management involves alkalinization of urine to enhance excretion. Fomepizole is the antidote for methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning as it inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Desferrioxamine: Incorrect. British Anti-Lewisite (BAL/Dimercaprol) is the antidote for arsenic poisoning. Desferrioxamine is specifically used for iron poisoning (both acute poisoning and chronic overload).

 

Educational Objective: 


Antidotes

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drugs act at the site marked by the arrow? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tiagabine

 

Explanation: 


Tiagabine acts by inhibiting GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1), which is responsible for the reuptake of GABA from the synapse. By blocking this transporter, Tiagabine increases the synaptic concentration of GABA, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and providing antiepileptic effects. The name "Tiagabine" itself suggests its mechanism - Transport Inhibitor of GABA or GAT-1 inhibitor.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Vigabatrin: Incorrect. It inhibits GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for GABA breakdown, not the GABA transporter. This increases GABA levels through a different mechanism.

 

 

Option B. Valproate: Incorrect. It has multiple mechanisms of action, primarily involving sodium channel blockade and enhancement of GABA-mediated inhibition, but does not specifically target GAT-1.

 

Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist and enhances GABA-mediated inhibition through different mechanisms, not through GAT-1 inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:


Tiagabine inhibits GABA reuptake by blocking the GABA transporter (GAT-1), leading to increased extracellular GABA and enhanced inhibitory neurotransmission, making it an effective treatment for epilepsy.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug specifically enhances the inactivation phase of voltage-gated slow sodium channels, helping to stabilize hyperexcitable neurons? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lacosamide

 

Explanation:


Lacosamide has a unique mechanism of action among antiepileptic drugs. It selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels. While most sodium channel blocking antiepileptics (like phenytoin, carbamazepine) act on fast sodium channels, lacosamide specifically targets slow sodium channels. This mechanism helps stabilize hyperexcitable neuronal membranes and prevents repetitive neuronal firing.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Phenytoin: Incorrect. While it does act on sodium channels, it primarily blocks fast sodium channels, not slow sodium channels. It acts by promoting the inactive state of these channels.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Incorrect. Like phenytoin, it acts primarily on fast sodium channels and also affects calcium channels. It does not specifically target slow sodium channels.

 

Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It works primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist and has no significant effect on sodium channels, either fast or slow.

 

Educational Objective:


Lacosamide uniquely acts by enhancing the slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, distinguishing it from other sodium channel-blocking antiepileptics that act on fast sodium channels.

choices.text: It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration
It shows the phenomenon of redistribution
It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding thiopentone except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

 

Explanation: 


Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution, not rapid renal excretion. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly crosses the blood-brain barrier and enters the brain, causing quick onset of anesthesia. However, it then redistributes to other tissues (muscle and fat), leading to a rapid decrease in brain concentration and therefore a short duration of action. The drug remains in the body but is no longer in sufficient concentration in the brain to maintain anesthetic effects.

 

Other Options:


Option A. It is highly lipid-soluble drug : Correct. Thiopentone is highly lipid-soluble, which enables it to rapidly cross the blood-brain barrier.

 

Option B. It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration : Correct. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly enters the brain within seconds of IV administration.

 

Option C. It shows the phenomenon of redistribution : Correct. After initial brain concentration, thiopentone redistributes to other tissues, particularly muscle and fat.

 

Educational Objective: 


Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution to other tissues, not rapid renal excretion.

 

THIOPENTONE

 

  • T - Thiobarbiturates 
  • H - Hyperthyroidism 
  • I - Inadvertent intra-arterial injection causes vasospasm (treatment - flush with NS, heparin, lignocaine) 
  • O - pH 10.5 (alkaline) 
  • P - pH 
  • Porphyrias (C/I) 
  • Prolongation of QT interval 
  • E - Epilepsy
  • N - Neuroanesthesia (DOC) 
  • T - Termination of action- redistribution

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with metastatic breast cancer. She has previously undergone treatment with surgery, radiation, and multiple lines of chemotherapy, but her disease has progressed. Genetic testing reveals a BRCA1 mutation, indicating an impaired DNA repair mechanism. Her cancer is classified as HER2-negative and hormone receptor-positive. Given the genetic findings, her oncologist considers using a therapy that targets the PARP enzyme to exploit the DNA repair vulnerability of her cancer cells. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to prescribe as a PARP inhibitor in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rucaparib

 

Explanation: 


Rucaparib is a PARP (Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase) inhibitor. PARP inhibitors work by blocking DNA repair mechanisms in cancer cells. In patients with BRCA mutations (who already have impaired DNA repair), PARP inhibition leads to synthetic lethality and cell death. The name helps identify PARP inhibitors as they end in "parib" (from Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase inhibitor).

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Palbociclib: Incorrect. This is a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) 4/6 inhibitor used in hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. While it might be useful in this patient's case, it is not a PARP inhibitor.

 

Option C. Vorinostat: Incorrect. This is a histone deacetylase inhibitor used in certain hematologic malignancies, not a PARP inhibitor.

 

Option D. Ustekinumab: Incorrect. This is a monoclonal antibody against interleukins used in psoriasis and other autoimmune conditions, not a PARP inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:


PARP inhibitors (drugs ending in "parib") are particularly effective in cancers with BRCA mutations due to their mechanism of synthetic lethality in cells with impaired DNA repair.
 

Breast Cancer

questions.text:
A diabetic, hypertensive, and post-MI patient on atorvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin has lipid profile results of total cholesterol: 238 mg/dL, triglycerides: 125 mg/dL, HDL: 50 mg/dL, and LDL: 160 mg/dL. Which additional medications should be considered to optimize lipid management in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Bemepedoic acid
  2. Ezetimibe
  3. Gemfibrozil
  4. Evolocumab
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Explanation: 


The patient has elevated total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol with normal triglycerides and HDL. Therefore, drugs targeting cholesterol reduction would be most appropriate:

 

1. Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP citrate lyase, reducing cholesterol synthesis

 

2. Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption

 

4. Evolocumab (PCSK9 inhibitor) increases LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL clearance All these mechanisms would help lower the elevated LDL and total cholesterol levels.

 

Other Option: 
 

3. Gemfibrozil is incorrect as fibrates primarily target high triglycerides, which are normal in this patient (125 mg/dL).

 

Educational Objective: 
 

Lipid-lowering medications based on the specific lipid abnormality: statins, PCSK9 inhibitors, ezetimibe, and bempedoic acid for elevated cholesterol/LDL; fibrates primarily for elevated triglycerides.

choices.text: At high doses in elderly patients, it causes cardiotoxicity and in younger patients nephrotoxicity
Adverse effects can be avoided if the dose is kept less than 250 mg phenytoin sodium equivalents
It is given to all seizure patients in emergency irrespective of CNS adverse effects and hypotension
High oral dose can result in cerebellar degeneration

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding fosphenytoin? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adverse effects can be avoided if the dose is kept less than 250 mg phenytoin sodium equivalents

 

Explanation:


Fosphenytoin is a water-soluble prodrug of phenytoin used for IV administration. When the dose is kept below 250 mg phenytoin sodium equivalents, adverse effects can be minimized. This dosing guideline helps prevent complications while maintaining therapeutic efficacy. After administration, fosphenytoin is converted to phenytoin by phosphatases in blood and liver.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. At high doses in elderly patients, it causes cardiotoxicity and in younger patients nephrotoxicity - Incorrect. Cardiotoxicity can occur at high doses in all age groups, not just elderly. There is no specific age-related difference in nephrotoxicity.

 

Option C. It is given to all seizure patients in emergency irrespective of CNS adverse effects and hypotension - Incorrect. While it's useful in emergency situations, it's not given indiscriminately. CNS effects and hypotension need to be monitored and managed.

 

Option D. High oral dose can result in cerebellar degeneration - Incorrect. Fosphenytoin is given intravenously, not orally. While phenytoin can cause cerebellar degeneration, this statement is incorrect for fosphenytoin's route of administration.

 

Educational Objective:


Fosphenytoin's adverse effects can be minimized by keeping the dose below 250 mg phenytoin sodium equivalents, and it is specifically designed for IV administration.

questions.text: A young male weighing 46 kg was treated with a drug. It has a Vd of 6 L/kg and clearance of 4.6 L/hour. What is the approximate half-life of this drug? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 hours

 

Explanation: 


The half-life can be calculated using the formula:

 
t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance

 

  • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 × 46 = 276 L
  • Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 × 276/4.6 ≈ 0.693 × 60 ≈ 40 hours


Educational Objective: 


The formula for calculating half-life (t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance) and remember to account for total Vd when given in L/kg by multiplying with body weight.

choices.text: Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers
It can be used for resistant malaria
It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid
It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding pretomanid? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid

 

Explanation: 


Pretomanid is approved as part of the BPaL (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) regime for treating extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) and pre-XDR TB in India. This combination therapy represents a significant advancement in treating highly resistant forms of tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers: Incorrect. Pretomanid is metabolized by CYP3A4, not CYP2C9, and is contraindicated with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

 

Option B. It can be used for resistant malaria: Incorrect. Pretomanid is specifically approved for tuberculosis treatment, not malaria.

 

Option D. It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species: Incorrect. Pretomanid acts by releasing reactive nitrogen species (not oxygen), which inhibit mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria.

 

Educational Objective: 


Pretomanid is part of the BPaL regimen (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) approved for treating XDR-TB and pre-XDR TB, and works through the release of reactive nitrogen species to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis.

 

New Drugs:

 

  1. Bedaquiline: Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation
  2. Delamanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria, can result in QT prolongation
  3. Pretomanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the causes of fall in diastolic blood pressure is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in the lumbar region
  2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors
  3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors
  4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 3

 

Explanation: 


A fall in diastolic blood pressure primarily occurs due to vasodilation. Two mechanisms listed that cause vasodilation are:

 

1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in lumbar region: Sympathetic system causes vasoconstriction, so its loss leads to vasodilation

 

3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors: Alpha-1 receptors mediate vasoconstriction, so their blockade causes vasodilation

 

Other Options:


2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors: Incorrect. Beta-1 blockade primarily affects heart rate and contractility, leading to decreased systolic blood pressure, not diastolic pressure.

 

4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors: Incorrect. Beta-2 receptors mediate vasodilation, so their blockade would cause vasoconstriction and potentially increase diastolic pressure.

 

Educational Objective:


Diastolic blood pressure is primarily affected by vascular tone - vasodilation decreases it (through loss of sympathetic tone or alpha-1 blockade) while vasoconstriction increases it.

choices.text: It should not be given with erythropoietin
It is given by intravenous route
It is more immunogenic than iron dextran
A single bolus dose is enough for treatment of iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding iron isomaltoside? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is given by intravenous route

 

Explanation:

 

Iron isomaltoside is an intravenous iron preparation that can be given via IV route over approximately 30 minutes. It is characterized by having a very low risk of allergic reactions compared to other IV iron preparations. The drug can be administered in high doses, typically requiring 2-3 doses for complete treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with erythropoietin: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside can be safely given with erythropoietin. It's iron ferromoxitol that should be avoided with erythropoietin.

 

Option C. It is more immunogenic than iron dextran: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside has very low immunogenicity and is less immunogenic than iron dextran.

 

Option D. A single bolus dose is enough for treatment: Incorrect. Usually 2-3 doses are required for complete treatment, though occasionally one dose might be sufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron isomaltoside is an IV iron preparation characterized by low immunogenicity, compatibility with erythropoietin, and typically requires 2-3 doses for complete treatment.

 

 

Injectable Iron

  • Preparations of injectable iron are:
    • Iron Dextran-Can be given IV as well as IM
    • Iron Sorbital citrate (Used im olnly)
  • Intramuscular iron is given by Z-tract technique to avoid pigmentation

 

Indication of injectable iron:

  • Oral iron cannot be given e.g.
    • Malabsorption
    • Not tolerated (due to GI symptoms)
  • Given with erythropoietin
    • Erythropoietin will stinulate RBC formation and will unmask any iron deficiency 
  • Dose of injectable iron = 4.3 x Hb deficit (g/dl) x body weight (kg)
    • This formula includes the iron required for replenishment of stores also.

questions.text: Match the following pathological bodies with their associated condition: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

The correct pairing of pathological bodies with their associated conditions is:

 

  • Parkinson's Disease - Lewy body (A-3): Lewy bodies are intracellular inclusions found in neurons of substantia nigra in Parkinson's disease
  • Rabies - Negri body (B-2): Negri bodies are pathognomonic intracytoplasmic inclusions found in neurons infected with rabies virus
  • Multiple myeloma - Dutcher body (C-1): Dutcher bodies are intranuclear inclusions found in plasma cells in multiple myeloma
  • Malakoplakia - Michaelis-Gutmann body (D-4): These are pathognomonic intracellular calcified bodies found in macrophages in malakoplakia

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Lewy bodies → Parkinson's disease

 

 

  • Negri bodies → Rabies

 

 

  • Dutcher bodies → Multiple myeloma

 

 

  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies → Malakoplakia

questions.text: Which of the following is not an inherited cause of thrombosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Haemoglobinuria)

 

PNH is an acquired disorder, not inherited. It occurs due to acquired mutations in myeloid stem cells affecting the PIGA gene. This leads to deficiency of CD55 and CD59 proteins that normally protect cells from complement-mediated destruction. 

 

The condition is characterized by intravascular hemolysis, thrombosis (particularly in unusual sites like hepatic veins causing Budd-Chiari syndrome), and pancytopenia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Protein S deficiency: Incorrect because it is an inherited thrombophilic condition. Protein S acts as a cofactor for Protein C and helps prevent excessive clotting.

 

Option B. Homocystinuria: Incorrect because it is an inherited metabolic disorder that causes elevated homocysteine levels, leading to increased risk of thrombosis.

 

Option D. Antithrombin III deficiency: Incorrect because Antithrombin III deficiency is an inherited condition that increases risk of thrombosis by reducing the ability to inhibit activated clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PNH is an acquired disorder caused by somatic mutations, while Protein S deficiency, Homocystinuria, and AT III deficiency are inherited causes of thrombosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with a hypercoagulable state? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor V mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability. It should be suspected in young patients (<50 years) presenting with thrombotic manifestations.

 

  • It is caused by substitution in the Factor V gene (Factor V Leiden mutation)
  • Causes enhanced coagulability in patients
  • In heterozygous condition, increases risk of thrombus formation by 4-5 times
  • In homozygous condition, increases risk by 50 times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antithrombin III mutation

 

  • Although this can cause thrombosis, it is less common than Factor V Leiden mutation
  • Antithrombin III acts as a natural anticoagulant
  • Its deficiency is rarer compared to Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Option C. Factor XIII mutation

 

  • Factor XIII is involved in clot stabilization
  • Its deficiency causes bleeding rather than thrombosis
  • Characterized by umbilical cord bleeding in newborns

 

Option D. Factor XII mutation

 

  • Factor XII initiates intrinsic pathway of coagulation
  • Its deficiency does not cause significant bleeding
  • Not typically associated with hypercoagulable states

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulable states, increasing thrombosis risk 4-5 times in heterozygous and 50 times in homozygous individuals.

choices.text: T cell receptor and MHC II

questions.text: All of the following interactions between T cells and APC (Antigen-Presenting Cell) are required for T cell activation/differentiation except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PD-PDL1

 

PD-PDL1 interaction inhibits T cell activation and causes T cell exhaustion. It represents an immune checkpoint that suppresses T cell responses. This interaction is exploited by tumor cells to evade immune surveillance. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T cell receptor and MHC II 

 

  • This is a crucial first signal 1 (Antigen recognition) required for T cell activation
  • TCR recognize antigen presented by MHC molecules on APCs for initial activation
  • CD4+ T cells recognize MHC class II molecules, while CD8+ T cells recognize MHC class I molecules.

 

Option B. CD28 and CD80 

 

  • This acts as the essential co-stimulatory signal (Signal 2)
  • Without this second signal, T cells become anergic rather than activated
  • CD28 on T cells interacts with B7 molecules (CD80/86) on APCs

 

Option D. Cytokine secretion

 

  • Cytokine secretion is essential for T cell differentiation.
  • When there is interaction between CD40 of B cell with CD40 ligand of T cell, it leads to secretion of cytokines like IL-4 and IL-5 which are crucial for T cell differentiation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

PD-PDL1 interaction is an inhibitory checkpoint that causes T cell exhaustion rather than activation. This pathway is important in cancer immunotherapy where checkpoint inhibitors are used to prevent tumor immune evasion.

questions.text: Epithelial mesenchymal transcription is mediated by which transcription factors? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SNAIL/TWIST

 

Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a crucial process in cancer metastasis where epithelial cells lose their cell-cell adhesion and gain migratory properties. This process is primarily mediated by SNAIL and TWIST transcription factors. These factors cause:

 

  • Decreased expression of E-cadherin (epithelial marker)
  • Increased expression of mesenchymal markers like vimentin and smooth muscle actin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cathepsin D

 

  • This is incorrect as cathepsin D is a protease involved in protein degradation
  • While it may play a role in tissue invasion, it's not a transcription factor mediating EMT

 

Option C. MMP-9 (Matrix Metalloprotease-9)

 

  • This is incorrect as MMP-9 is an enzyme involved in degrading extracellular matrix
  • It's important for invasion but doesn't mediate EMT transcription

 

Option D. TTF-1 (Thyroid Transcription Factor-1)

 

  • This is incorrect as TTF-1 is a transcription factor specific to thyroid and lung tissue development
  • It's not involved in EMT

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SNAIL and TWIST are the key transcription factors responsible for mediating epithelial-mesenchymal transition, a crucial step in cancer metastasis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to you with neuropathy in his bilateral lower limbs and a positive Romberg sign. He has a history of gastrectomy for stomach cancer. He is likely deficient in which of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

The case presents a classic scenario of Vitamin B12 deficiency due to gastrectomy. When a patient undergoes gastric surgery, there is a decrease in parietal cell mass, which leads to reduced secretion of both hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor. Intrinsic factor is crucial for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the terminal ileum.

 

Its deficiency leads to malabsorption of vitamin B12, resulting in neurological manifestations and Haematological Manifestations.

 

 Neurological Manifestations:

 

  • Neuropathy in bilateral lower limbs: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to demyelination of the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts, resulting in sensory loss and weakness.
  • Positive Romberg sign: This indicates impaired proprioception, which is a hallmark of subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord.
  • Other neurological symptoms: Tingling, numbness, gait disturbances, and even cognitive impairment.

 

Hematological Manifestations:

 

  • Megaloblastic anemia: Due to impaired DNA synthesis, leading to macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine deficiency

 

  • Incorrect because thiamine absorption occurs in the duodenum and is not dependent on intrinsic factor
  • Does not typically present with peripheral neuropathy as the primary manifestation

 

Option B. Folate deficiency

 

  • Incorrect because folate absorption is not dependent on intrinsic factor
  • While it can cause megaloblastic anemia, it does not cause neurological manifestations

 

Option D. Transferrin deficiency

 

  • Incorrect because transferrin is related to iron transport and is not primarily affected by gastrectomy
  • Does not cause neurological manifestations

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-gastrectomy patients are at high risk for Vitamin B12 deficiency due to lack of intrinsic factor production, leading to neurological manifestations like peripheral neuropathy, positive Romberg sign and megaloblastic anemia. Lifelong vitamin B12 supplementation is essential in such patients to prevent neurological and hematological complications.

 

 

Causes of B12 Deficiency

 

  1. Vegans
  2. At stomach level - Elderly/ gastrectomy / Pernicious anemia
  3. At pancreas level - Pancreatitis, hypofunctioning pancreas
