  4.  At intestine level - Bacterial overgrowth syndrome, diverticulosis.
  5. At ileum level - Malabsorption disorders, GIT TB, Crohn's disease, fish tapeworm
  6. ↓ intake
  7. ↓ absorption - ↓ intrinsic factor – pernicious anemia
  8. ↑ requirement - Children, pregnancy, lactation

choices.text: Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the α -globin chain
Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the β-globin chain
Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain
Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the α-globin chain

questions.text: Which Mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene (HBB) located on chromosome 11. This mutation results in the substitution of glutamic acid with valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain. The replacement of glutamic acid with a valine causes polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS), leading to red blood cell sickling, increased rigidity, and vaso-occlusive crises. The sickled cells have reduced deformability and tend to aggregate, causing vascular obstruction, hemolysis, and ischemia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the α -globin chain: Incorrect. The mutation in sickle cell anemia affects the β-globin chain, not the α-globin chain. Additionally, while the amino acid substitution involves valine, it occurs at a specific position in the beta chain.

 

Option B. Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the β-globin chain: Incorrect. While the position (6th) and initial amino acid (glutamic acid) are correct, the substituting amino acid is valine, not leucine. When lysine replaces glutamic acid, it results in hemoglobin C disease.

 

Option D. Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the α-globin chain: Incorrect. This combines two errors - wrong chain (α instead of β) and wrong substituting amino acid (leucine instead of valine).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation resulting in substitution of glutamic acid by valine specifically at position 6 of the β-globin chain.

 

This results in polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS), sickling of red blood cells, and complications such as vaso-occlusive crises and hemolysis.

 

 

COMPLICATIONS:

 

  • Vaso-occlusive crisis: most common clinical complication
  • Aplastic crisis: BM overactivity due to compensatory mechanism → parvovirus infection
  • Sequestration crisis: ↑↑↑splenic size leading to hypovolemia
  • Hemolytic crisis- due to infection, splenic macrophage becomes overactive

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with gums bleeding, hepatosplenomegaly has a peripheral smear finding shown in the image. Flow cytometry was ordered for patient and CD19, CD22 and TdT came to be positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ALL B Lymphocyte Type

 

This is a case of B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B-ALL) based on:

 

1. Clinical presentation:

 

  • Young child (5 years old)
  • Gum bleeding (due to thrombocytopenia)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

 

2. Peripheral smear:

 

  • Shows lymphoblasts with: 
    • Scanty agranular cytoplasm
    • Condensed chromatin
    • No abnormal granules

 

3. Flow cytometry findings:

 

  • Positive for:
    • CD19 (B-cell marker)
    • CD22 (B-cell marker)
    • TdT (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase - immature lymphoid marker)

 

These markers are characteristic of B-cell ALL. Flow cytometry is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis and lineage assignment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ALL T Lymphocyte Type

 

  • Incorrect because T-ALL would be positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, CD7 markers
  • Usually presents with mediastinal mass
  • Flow cytometry shows different markers than presented here

 

Option C. AML

 

  • Incorrect because myeloblasts would show Auer rods and granular cytoplasm
  • Would be positive for MPO/NSE markers
  • Different flow cytometry pattern

 

Option D. CML

 

  • Incorrect because CML shows mature granulocytes with left shift
  • Presents typically in adults
  • Positive for Philadelphia chromosome
  • Different flow cytometry pattern

 

Educational Objective:

 

B-cell ALL is characterized by lymphoblasts on peripheral smear and positivity for B-cell markers (CD19, CD22) and TdT on flow cytometry.

questions.text: A newborn presents with umbilical cord stump bleeding and a history of recurrent bleeding episodes. Laboratory results reveal normal PT, APTT, and platelet count, but a positive clot solubility test. What coagulation factor deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XIII

 

Factor XIII is essential for stabilizing fibrin clots by cross-linking fibrin monomers. A deficiency in Factor XIII leads to an unstable clot that dissolves easily, causing excessive bleeding despite normal routine coagulation tests such as PT (Prothrombin Time) and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time).

 

  • Clinical presentation:
    • Umbilical stump bleeding is a hallmark feature of Factor XIII deficiency, occurring shortly after birth.
    •  Recurrent bleeding episodes, including delayed hemorrhage after trauma or surgery.
    •  Intracranial hemorrhage can occur even without trauma.
    • Poor wound healing due to defective clot stabilization.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Normal PT, APTT, and platelet count, as Factor XIII operates in the final step of clot formation and does not affect routine coagulation screening tests.
    • Positive clot solubility test: Clots dissolve in 5M urea or acetic acid within 24 hours due to the lack of cross-linking fibrin.

 

Thus, the positive clot solubility test in this patient strongly indicates Factor XIII deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XII (Incorrect)

 

  • Hageman factor deficiency typically doesn't cause clinical bleeding
  • Would show prolonged aPTT on testing
  • Not associated with umbilical stump bleeding

 

Option B. Factor XI (Incorrect)

 

  • Would show prolonged aPTT
  • Not characteristically associated with umbilical cord bleeding
  • Clinical bleeding is usually mild and post-traumatic

 

Option C. Factor VIII (Incorrect)

 

  • Hemophilia A would show prolonged aPTT
  • While it causes bleeding, umbilical stump bleeding is not a characteristic presentation
  • Would not have a positive clot solubility test

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XIII deficiency presents with umbilical cord bleeding and shows normal PT, aPTT, and platelet count but positive clot solubility test due to unstable clot formation.

questions.text: All blood products are separated by Centrifugation except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum albumin

 

Most blood components are separated using centrifugation, which involves different speeds:

 

  1. Low-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates Packed RBCs from platelet-rich plasma (PRP).
  2. High-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates platelets from plasma.
    • Plasma is further processed into Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP).
  3. Cryoprecipitate Preparation:
    • FFP is thawed at 1-6°C, allowing cryoprecipitate to form, which contains Factor VIII, fibrinogen, vWF, and Factor XIII.

 

Thus, platelets, RBCs and cryoprecipitate are all separated using centrifugation.

 

Serum albumin, however, is obtained through a process called fractionation, not centrifugation. This involves:

 

  • Cold ethanol precipitation (Cohn’s method)
  • Ultrafiltration and chromatography techniques

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centrifugation is used to separate RBCs, platelets, and plasma-derived components like cryoprecipitate. Serum albumin, however, is obtained through fractionation, making it the correct answer.

questions.text: For HbA1c sample, the vacutainer used contains which of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EDTA

 

Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) is measured to assess long-term glycemic control in diabetic patients. The preferred sample for HbA1c estimation is whole blood, and the anticoagulant used for this is EDTA.

 

  • EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is used because:
    • It prevents coagulation by chelating calcium.
    • It preserves RBC integrity, ensuring accurate measurement of glycosylated hemoglobin.
    • Lavender-top (Purple) vacutainers contain EDTA and are commonly used for HbA1c testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: 

 

  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant used therapeutically, not for blood collection.

 

Option B. Sodium Fluoride:

 

  • Used in gray-top vacutainers, primarily for glucose estimation, as it inhibits glycolysis.
  • Does not preserve RBCs well, so not used for HbA1c.

 

Option D. Heparin:

 

  • Used in green-top vacutainers, primarily for plasma-based tests (e.g., electrolytes, arterial blood gases).
  • Not used for HbA1c, as it does not preserve whole blood effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HbA1c estimation, EDTA (lavender-top vacutainer) is used because it prevents coagulation while preserving RBC integrity for accurate glycosylated hemoglobin measurement.

 

Vacutainer Vials and Their Uses

 

 

Sequence of blood Drawn - Chalo Bhai, Red yellow Green Light → Go

 

Culture Bottle – Blue – Red – Yellow – Green – Lavender – Grey

questions.text: Which vacutainer is commonly used to collect blood samples for serum electrolyte analysis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Green

 

The green-top vacutainer contains heparin (specifically lithium heparin), which is an anticoagulant that prevents blood from clotting while allowing for accurate electrolyte analysis, especially for sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), and chloride (Cl-) levels. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Blue: Incorrect. Blue top vacutainer contains sodium citrate and is used for coagulation studies like PT, aPTT. It would not be appropriate for electrolyte analysis.

 

Option B. Yellow: Incorrect. Yellow top vacutainer is used for bacterial culture and HLA typing. It's not suitable for electrolyte analysis.

 

Option D. Purple: Incorrect. Purple/Lavender top vacutainer contains EDTA and is used for complete blood count (CBC), immunohistochemistry studies and ESR testing using the Westergren method. EDTA can interfere with electrolyte measurements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For serum electrolyte analysis, green-top vacutainers (containing lithium heparin) are the preferred choice as they prevent clotting without interfering with the electrolyte measurement.

 

 

Sequence of blood Drawn - Chalo Bhai, Red yellow Green Light → Go

 

Culture Bottle – Blue – Red – Yellow – Green – Lavender – Grey

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of TTP? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thrombosis

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a life-threatening condition caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the ADAMTS13 enzyme, which leads to widespread platelet aggregation and microvascular occlusions. The classic pentad of TTP includes:

 

1. Thrombocytopenia – Due to platelet consumption in small vessel thrombi.

 

2. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia – Formation of schistocytes due to red blood cell destruction in small vessels.

 

 

3. Neurological symptoms – Ranging from confusion, headaches, and seizures to strokes.

 

4. Renal dysfunction – Present in some cases due to microvascular damage.

 

5. Fever – A non-specific symptom due to systemic inflammation.

 

While platelet-rich thrombi are characteristic of TTP, clinical thrombosis (macrovascular thrombosis like DVT or pulmonary embolism) is not a typical feature. The pathogenesis involves microvascular platelet thrombi rather than large-vessel thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The classical pentad of TTP:

 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Fever
  • Neurological manifestations

questions.text: Features of MEN2B are all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PTH carcinoma

 

MEN2B includes "Medullary thyroid cancer, Pheochromocytoma, Other extra features → Marfanoid habitus, Mucosal neuromas." Parathyroid involvement (PTH carcinoma) is not a component of MEN2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

 The correct matching is:

 

  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a major tumor marker for hepatocellular carcinoma. It's an oncofetal protein that is normally produced during fetal development but can be elevated in certain cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Beta-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is the primary tumor marker for choriocarcinoma. This marker is normally produced during pregnancy but is pathologically elevated in choriocarcinoma, a malignant trophoblastic tumor.
  • Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine) are elevated in pheochromocytoma, which is a tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes excessive amounts of these hormones.
  • Calcitonin is the characteristic tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma, which arises from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland that produce this hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor Markers

questions.text: Match the column: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

Peutz-Jeghers polyp (A): It is associated with STK11 (serine/threonine kinase 11) gene mutation (3). Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract along with mucocutaneous pigmentation. These polyps are typically found in the jejunum and can cause intussusception and bleeding.

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (B): It is linked to APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) gene mutation (1). FAP is characterized by the development of hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon, with 100% lifetime risk of colorectal cancer if untreated.

 

Juvenile polyposis (C): It is associated with SMAD4 gene mutation (4). Juvenile polyposis is characterized by hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, with increased risk of GI malignancies.

 

Tuberous sclerosis (D): It is linked to TSC2 gene mutations (2). Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder characterized by hamartomas in multiple organ systems, including the brain, skin, kidneys, and heart.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the structures shown in the images: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpora amylacea

 

The image shows corpora amylacea, which are spherical laminated hyaline structures commonly seen in elderly males in the prostate and represent a normal aging change. These are glycoprotein deposits that appear as round, concentrically laminated, eosinophilic (pink) structures with a glassy appearance. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus callosum: Incorrect. Corpus callosum is a broad band of nerve fibers that connects the two cerebral hemispheres in the brain. It would appear as white matter tracts in histological sections of brain tissue, not as concentric laminated structures seen in the image.

 

Option B. Psammoma body: Incorrect. Psammoma bodies are concentrically laminated calcifications that appear as round, basophilic (blue) structures, typically found in certain neoplasms like meningiomas, papillary thyroid carcinoma, and serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary. 

 

 

Option C. Corpus luteum: Incorrect. Corpus luteum is a temporary endocrine structure formed in the ovary after ovulation. Histologically, it would appear as a follicular structure with luteinized granulosa cells having abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The histological appearance of corpora amylacea, which are eosinophilic, concentrically laminated glycoprotein deposits that commonly occur in the prostate gland of elderly males as part of the normal aging process.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as a germ cell tumor of the ovary? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Granulosa cell tumor

 

Granulosa cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor, not a germ cell tumor of the ovary.

 

Granulosa cell tumors are derived from the sex cord-stromal cells of the ovary. These tumors are characterized by the presence of Call-Exner bodies and coffee bean-shaped nuclei. They are estrogen-secreting functional tumors that may present as precocious puberty, endometrial hyperplasia, or post-menopausal bleeding. The marker for granulosa cell tumors is Inhibin B, and they are associated with FOXL2 mutation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yolk sac tumor: This is incorrect because yolk sac tumor, also known as endodermal sinus tumor, is a germ cell tumor of the ovary. 

 

Yolk sac tumor (Endodermal sinus tumor)

 

  • 2nd MC malignant GCT
  • MC malignant ovarian tumor presenting in <4years
  • Histology: presence of Schiller Duval Body/Glomeruloid body
  • Tumor markers: AFP +, α1 AT +ve

 

 

Option B. Dysgerminoma: This is incorrect because dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor of the ovary. It is the ovarian counterpart of testicular seminoma. 

  • Ovarian counterpart of seminoma
  • MC malignant GCT
  • Radiosensitive, chemo-sensitive tumor
  • Unilateral involvement mostly (85%)
  • Non-Functional tumor: hormones not secreted
  • Markers include transcription factors (OCT 3/4, NANOG, KiT) and enzymes (PLAP +, LDH, ß HCG but Normal AFP)

 

Option C. Choriocarcinoma: This is incorrect because choriocarcinoma can coexist with other germ cell tumors, as it can arise from either the ovary (germ cell origin) or the placenta (gestational trophoblastic disease)

 

  • It secretes beta-hCG, which serves as a tumor marker.
  • If it has ovarian origin: non- responsive to chemotherapy → poor prognosis 
  • If it has placenta origin excellent responsive to chemotherapy → good prognosis
  • Choriocarcinoma is known for early hematogenous spread and "cannon-ball" metastases to the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulosa cell tumor is classified as a sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary, not a germ cell tumor.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the best investigation for aneuploidy? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. In Situ Hybridization
  2. Conventional cytogenetics 
  3. PCR
  4. Sanger sequencing
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A & B

 

For the detection of aneuploidy, both In Situ Hybridization (specifically FISH - Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization) and conventional cytogenetics are the best investigations. "FISH technique is an important technique which not only helps to detect the presence of microdeletions or an excess number of certain types of genes being expressed it also helps to detect the presence of specific chromosomal translocations.

 

Conventional cytogenetics, though more time-consuming than FISH, is still an effective method for aneuploidy detection. It involves visualizing the chromosomes under a microscope during cell division to count them and look for gross abnormalities.

 

Both techniques allow direct visualization of chromosomal material and can detect numerical abnormalities like aneuploidy. FISH is particularly valuable because it can rapidly detect common aneuploidies like trisomy 21, 18, 13 within 24-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C & D (PCR and Sanger sequencing): These techniques are not the best for detecting aneuploidy. PCR and Sanger sequencing are used for analyzing specific DNA sequences and mutations, but they cannot effectively detect changes in chromosome number.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH (Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization) and conventional cytogenetics are the best techniques for detecting aneuploidy (abnormal chromosome numbers), while PCR and Sanger sequencing are used for specific sequence analysis but not aneuploidy detection.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Mitochondrial inheritance (A) is associated with Leber's disease (3). Mitochondrial inheritance, also called maternal inheritance, occurs when DNA in the mitochondria is passed from mother to offspring. Leber's optic neuropathy is a classic example of a mitochondrial disease transmitted through maternal inheritance. This is because mitochondrial DNA is present in the ovum but not in sperm.

 

 

X-linked recessive inheritance (B) is linked to Duchene's muscular dystrophy (4). In XLR inheritance, the disease is more common in males since they only have one X chromosome. Duchene's muscular dystrophy is specifically listed as an example of X-linked recessive disorders.

 

Autosomal recessive inheritance (C) corresponds to cystic fibrosis (2). AR disorders require two copies of the mutated gene to manifest the disease and are common in consanguineous marriages. Cystic fibrosis is a classic example of an autosomal recessive disorder affecting enzymatic proteins.

 

Trinucleotide repeat disorders (D) include spinobulbar dystrophy (1). These disorders are characterized by expansion of nucleotide repeats during gametogenesis, leading to neurological diseases. The unstable expansion of trinucleotide repeats (CAG) causes spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Genetic Disorders and Their Inheritance Patterns

IgG deamidated Gliadin antibodies are present

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain, acute diarrhea, and is diagnosed with celiac disease. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Associated with HLA DQ6/DQ11

 

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. It is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. 

 

Associated with HLA DQ6/DQ11 because celiac disease is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8, not HLA DQ6/DQ11.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IgA Tissue Transglutaminase antibodies are present: This statement is correct. The patients are going to be having the presence of IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies " These antibodies have high sensitivity and specificity for celiac disease diagnosis and are used as primary serological tests.

 

Option C. Marsh Criteria used for diagnosis: This statement is correct. " Modified MARSH criteria is useful for making a diagnosis." The Marsh criteria classify the histopathological findings in small intestinal biopsies, ranging from normal mucosa to complete villous atrophy.

 

Option D. IgG deamidated Gliadin antibodies are present: This statement is correct. " IgG deamidated gliadin antibodies are used in celiac disease diagnosis, especially in IgA-deficient patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8, not HLA-DQ6/DQ11, and diagnosis involves IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies, deamidated gliadin antibodies, and application of the Marsh criteria.

 

Important disease associated with HLA

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of NAME syndrome? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ebstein's anomaly

 

NAME syndrome stands for Nevus, Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibroma, and Ephelides (freckles) or Endocrine overactivity (such as pheochromocytoma). 

 

Ebstein's anomaly, which is a congenital heart defect characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, is not a component of NAME syndrome. 

 

Ebstein's anomaly is associated with maternal lithium use during pregnancy rather than being a component of NAME syndrome. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Components of NAME Syndrome

 

 

Ebstein's anomaly is not part of this syndrome but is associated with maternal lithium exposure during pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the forearm. Microscopic examination reveals the following features. Which of the following statements is wrong regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malignant tumor with frequent metastasis

 

The image shows the characteristic microscopic appearance of a schwannoma, which shows hypercellular areas (Antoni A) and hypocellular areas (Antoni B) with Verocay bodies (nuclear palisading). 

 

Schwannomas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from Schwann cells. 

 

Schwannomas are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and show nuclear palisading. 

 

The statement that it is a "malignant tumor with frequent metastasis" is incorrect because schwannomas are benign tumors with excellent prognosis and do not typically metastasize. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SCHWANNOMA

 

  • Peripheral Nerve sheath tumor
  • Benign
  • Arises from Schwann cells of Peripheral nerves or Cranial nerves (8th CN > 5th CN)

 

Risk factor:

 

  • NF2 gene mutation causes reduced merlin expression and increased cell multiplication
  • B/L schwannoma due to NF-2 gene mutation
  • Schwannoma arising from 8th CN was earlier called acoustic neuroma
  • Now called as vestibular schwannoma
  • C/F: SNHL, tinnitus, decreased corneal reflex
  • Diagnosed with MRI

 

Histology shows

 

  1. Hypercellular Antony 'A' area and hypocellular Antony 'B' area
    • Antony 'A' area: tumor cells arranged in fence-like pattern → nuclear-free zones called verocay bodies
  2. Verocay body: Nuclear free area
  3. Presence of true palisading
  4. IHC shows S100+

questions.text: Sodium benzoate is given for urea cycle defects for scavenging ammonia. Which amino acid donates amino group to the scavengers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine

 

Sodium benzoate acts as an ammonia scavenger in urea cycle disorders. It works by conjugating with glycine to form hippurate (or hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine. This process provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion when the urea cycle is impaired. The reaction occurs without requiring the urea cycle, thus helping to reduce ammonia levels in patients with urea cycle disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine: Arginine is actually a component of the urea cycle itself and is often supplemented in some urea cycle disorders (except arginase deficiency). It does not directly conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia removal.

 

Option C. Glutamine: Glutamine is involved with another ammonia scavenger, phenyl butyrate, which is converted to phenyl acetate and then conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine. However, glutamine does not conjugate with sodium benzoate.

 

Option D. Aspartate: Aspartate is an amino acid that participates in the urea cycle by providing one of the nitrogen atoms for urea formation. It does not conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urea cycle disorders, sodium benzoate is used as an ammonia scavenger that conjugates specifically with glycine to form hippurate (hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Match the following Amino acid products: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-1, C-2, D-4

 

  • Tyrosine (A) → Norepinephrine (3): Tyrosine is a precursor for catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. It's also used for melanin and thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Tryptophan (B) → Melatonin (1): Tryptophan is metabolized to serotonin, which is then converted to melatonin. Tryptophan is also a precursor for niacin (vitamin B3).
  • Glycine (C) → Glutathione (2): Glycine is one of the three amino acids that make up glutathione (along with glutamate and cysteine). Glycine is also used in heme synthesis, creatine synthesis, and bile acid conjugation.
  • Histidine (D) → Histamine (4): Histidine undergoes decarboxylation (removal of the carboxyl group) to form histamine, which is an important inflammatory mediator and neurotransmitter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amino Acid Conversions

questions.text: A Patient had dietary Cu deficiency, which is required by lysyl oxidase to cross link the collagen. What is the diagnosis of the patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Menke's Disease


Menkes disease is caused by copper deficiency. Copper is required as a cofactor for lysyl oxidase, an enzyme necessary for collagen cross-linking. In Menkes disease, there is a defect in the ATP7A protein which is responsible for copper absorption. This leads to copper deficiency despite adequate dietary intake. In Menkes disease, copper deficiency is seen and lysyl oxidase is affected which results in defective and weak collagen synthesis leading to brittle hair.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Scoliosis: This is an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine, not directly related to copper deficiency or lysyl oxidase function. Scoliosis can have various causes including congenital, neuromuscular, or idiopathic factors.

 

Option C. Ehlers Danlos syndrome: This is a group of connective tissue disorders caused by defects in collagen synthesis or structure. In Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, the defect is in lysyl hydroxylase, particularly in the kyphoscoliotic type, not in lysyl oxidase.

 

Option D. Scurvy: This is caused by vitamin C deficiency, not copper deficiency. Vitamin C is required for collagen maturation through hydroxylation of proline and lysine, but this is a different process from the cross-linking function performed by lysyl oxidase that requires copper.

 

Educational Objective: 


Menkes disease is caused by copper deficiency which affects lysyl oxidase activity, an enzyme required for collagen cross-linking, resulting in weak collagen formation and characteristic symptoms including brittle hair.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cytochrome C oxidase inhibitor? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nitric oxide


Nitric oxide is not an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV of electron transport chain). NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme NO synthase and causes vasodilation. It has a role in physiological processes like erection and is inhibited by smoking, which can lead to erectile dysfunction.

 

Inhibitors of ETC Complexes

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Carbon monoxide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Carbon monoxide is part of the mnemonic "i'd" which includes carbon monoxide, cyanide, hydrogen sulfide, and sodium azide as inhibitors of complex IV.

 

Option C. Hydrogen sulfide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Hydrogen sulfide is listed among the substances that inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.

 

Option D. Cyanide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Cyanide is included in the list of substances that inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:


Nitric oxide (NO) is not an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV), while carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulfide, and cyanide are inhibitors of this complex IV  in the electron transport chain.

choices.text: Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased
Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with diabetes has high increased LDL and VLDL because of? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased


In diabetes, there is either a deficiency of insulin or insulin resistance. Insulin normally inhibits hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). When insulin is deficient or not working properly, HSL activity increases while LPL activity decreases. HSL breaks down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue, releasing fatty acids into circulation. Increased HSL activity leads to more triglycerides being broken down. Meanwhile, decreased LPL activity reduces the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins from the bloodstream. This combined effect results in elevated levels of VLDL and subsequently LDL in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, these two enzymes are regulated in opposite directions. While HSL is increased, LPL is decreased due to the lack of insulin's regulatory effect.

 

Option C. Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased: This is the opposite of what occurs in diabetes. This pattern would be seen in a fed state with normal insulin action, not in diabetes.

 

Option D. Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, HSL is increased, not decreased. While LPL is indeed decreased in diabetes, both enzymes are not decreased.

 

Educational Objective: 


Diabetes, hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) activity is increased while lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity is decreased due to insulin deficiency or resistance, leading to elevated levels of VLDL and LDL.

questions.text: All are used in recombinant DNA technology (genetic engineering) except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isomerases

 

Isomerases are not used in recombinant DNA technology. Isomerases are enzymes that catalyze structural rearrangements within a molecule, converting one isomer to another. They don't have applications in genetic engineering techniques where cutting, joining, or modifying DNA sequences is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatases: These are used in recombinant DNA technology. Alkaline phosphatase removes terminal phosphate groups from DNA, which is useful in preventing unwanted ligation reactions in DNA cloning.

 

Option B. CRISPR Cas9:
 

CRISPR/CAS 9 System:

  • Causes double strand break
  • CROSPR- Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats
  • Cas-9: CRISPR associated endonuclease
    • This endonuclease is guided by CRISPR for cutting site
  • It is an immune system in bacteria against bacteriophages
    • Memory of bacteriophage infection and immunity is transferred to future generation also. So protect may future generations from viruses

Uses

  • Can be adopted to be used in eukaryotes for purposes like
    • Gene deletion
    • Exogenous gene insertion
    • Multigene editing possible
    • Altering gene transcription and regulation 

 

Option D. Terminal transferase: This enzyme is used in recombinant DNA technology to add nucleotides to the 3' OH end of DNA, which is useful in various molecular biology applications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isomerases, which catalyze structural rearrangements within molecules, are not used in recombinant DNA technology or genetic engineering, while phosphatases, CRISPR Cas9, and terminal transferase are utilized in these techniques.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true for hemolytic anemia ? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Indirect Ban den Bergh test positive
  2. Direct Van den Bergh test positive
  3. Increased urine urobilonogen
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a and c


In hemolytic anemia, there is increased breakdown of red blood cells, which leads to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood. The indirect Vandenbergh test detects unconjugated bilirubin, which is increased in hemolytic anemia. Additionally, the increased breakdown of hemoglobin leads to greater production of urobilinogen, which is then excreted in urine in higher amounts. Therefore, both indirect Vandenbergh test positivity and increased urinary urobilinogen are characteristic findings in hemolytic anemia.



Direct Van den Bergh Test


Conjugated Bilirubin + Ehrlich’s Diazo Reagent → Reddish purple Azo compound(Gives colour immediately)

 

Indirect Van den Bergh Test (Doesn’t give colour immediately)
Unconjugated Bilirubin → Extraction with Alcohol → Gives colour (Water Insoluble)

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hemolytic anemia is characterized by a positive indirect Vandenbergh test (due to increased unconjugated bilirubin) and increased urine urobilinogen (due to increased hemoglobin breakdown).

questions.text: Match the Following hormones to receptors: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  1. Insulin - Tyrosine Kinase Pathway: Insulin uses a tyrosine kinase receptor. This is a cell surface receptor that, when activated, phosphorylates tyrosine residues on target proteins, triggering intracellular signaling cascades.
  2. Growth Hormone - JAK-STAT Pathway: Growth hormone, along with prolactin and leptin, uses the JAK-STAT (Janus Kinase-Signal Transducer and Activator of Transcription) pathway. This is a cytokine receptor-mediated signaling mechanism.
  3. Acetylcholine - Ligand-gated Channel: At the neuromuscular junction, acetylcholine operates through ligand-gated sodium channels. When acetylcholine binds, these channels open, allowing sodium ions to flow and triggering muscle contraction.
  4. Levothyroxine (Thyroid Hormone) - Nuclear Receptor: Thyroid hormones act through nuclear receptors, which means they enter the cell and directly interact with DNA in the nucleus to regulate gene expression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classification of Receptors

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in an inner segment of the photoreceptor? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Disc 

 

Disc membranes are specifically located in the outer segment of the photoreceptor, not the inner segment. The inner segment contains most cellular organelles, including:

 

  • Mitochondria
  • Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
  • Golgi apparatus
  • Nucleus

 

The outer segment is characterized by the presence of disc membranes, which are crucial for phototransduction. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in Static Two-point discrimination? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Merkel disk

 

Static two-point discrimination requires a receptor that adapts very slowly to maintain sensation over a prolonged period. Merkel cells are crucial for this function.

 

Merkel cells:

 

  • They are slow-adapting receptors
  • Excellent for 2-point discrimination
  • Have a less receptive field
  • Critical for detecting edges and points
  • Particularly important for tasks like Braille reading

 

The key characteristics that make Merkel cells ideal for static two-point discrimination are:

 

  1. Slow adaptation rate
  2. Ability to detect steady stimuli
  3. Precise localization of sensory input

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Meissner's corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors, making them unsuitable for static discrimination. They are best for fine touch sensations.

 

Option C. Pacinian corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors present at Deep dermis, joint capsule that sense high-frequency vibration and pressure, not static stimuli.

 

Option D. Ruffini ending: Incorrect. While these are slow-adapting mechanoreceptors, they primarily sense stretch and sustained pressure, not precise point discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which one of the following curves shows oxygen Hb dissociation after transfusion of stored blood: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve after transfusion of stored blood is characterized by two key factors:

 

  1. Low 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) levels
  2. Lower temperature of stored blood

 

These factors cause a left shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, which is represented by curve B. The left shift means hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen, making it more difficult to release oxygen to tissues.

 

Educational Objective:
