choices.text: Blunt object with high force doesn’t stimulate nociceptors
Pinching with serrated object stimulate mechanoceptors but doesn’t cause pain
Sharp pain sensation is carried by type C nerve fiber

questions.text: Mechanical nociceptors and its response to a probe with blunt object, pin prick and tooth forceps with serration is recorded as a output of a force transducer coupled to the stimulator. What will you infer from a given diagram? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blunt object with high force doesn't stimulate nociceptors

 

Blunt Object:

 

  • Does not produce action potentials in nociceptors
  • Activates mechanoreceptors without triggering pain sensation
  • High force does not necessarily stimulate nociceptive receptors

 

Pin Prick:

 

  • Produces clear action potentials
  • Stimulates nociceptors
  • Sharp stimuli trigger pain receptors

 

Serrated Forceps:

 

  • Produces multiple action potentials
  • Stimulates both mechanoreceptors and nociceptors
  • Causes significant pain response

 

Sharp pain is typically carried by A-delta fibers

 

Slower, diffuse pain is carried by C fibers

 

Nociceptors respond to potentially tissue-damaging stimuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nociceptors (pain receptors) respond differentially to various mechanical stimuli - they are activated by sharp objects and pinching/pressure that can potentially damage tissue, but not by blunt pressure even with high force. Fast, sharp pain is transmitted via A-delta fibers, while slow, dull pain is transmitted via C fibers.

questions.text: All of the following Decreases GFR except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased Bowman Oncotic Pressure

 

The GFR is calculated using the formula: GFR = Kf × Net Filtration Pressure (NFP).

 

Net Filtration Pressure is determined by the balance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures in the glomerular and Bowman's capsule. 

 

The Net Filtration Pressure (NFP) is calculated using the formula: NFP = (HPG - OPG) - (HPB - OPB) Where:

 

  • HPG = Hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries (pushing force, ~60 mmHg)
  • OPG = Oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries (pulling force, ~32 mmHg)
  • HPB = Hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule (opposing force, ~18 mmHg)
  • OPB = Oncotic pressure in Bowman's capsule (normally negligible, ~0 mmHg)

 

Normally, NFP = (60-32) - (18-0) = 10 mmHg

 

When Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases, it pulls more water molecules from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space. This increases filtration, resulting in increased GFR. Proteins in Bowman's capsule would pull more water molecules towards them, which constitutes the filtration process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased glomerular coefficient Kf: Incorrect because a decrease in Kf directly reduces GFR according to the formula GFR = Kf × NFP. The glomerular coefficient represents the permeability of the filtration membrane and its surface area.

 

Option B. Increase glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect because glomerular oncotic pressure is a pulling force that opposes filtration. When oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries increases, it holds water within the capillaries, reducing the amount of filtrate formed, thereby decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Reduced Glomerular Hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect because glomerular hydrostatic pressure is the primary driving force for filtration. A reduction in this pressure means less force is available to push water and solutes across the filtration membrane, resulting in decreased GFR.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases, it pulls more water molecules from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space. This increases filtration, resulting in increased GFR. Proteins in Bowman's capsule would pull more water molecules towards them, which constitutes the filtration process.

questions.text: Which of the following transport mechanism doesn’t require ATP: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

The image shows four different transport mechanisms across cell membranes:

 

1. Simple diffusion through membrane: This shows direct diffusion of molecules through the lipid bilayer from high concentration to low concentration. This is also passive transport that doesn't require ATP.

 

2. Simple diffusion through channels: This shows molecules moving through a protein channel from high concentration to low concentration. This is passive transport that follows the concentration gradient without requiring ATP. Channels have gates that simply open or close without configurational changes, allowing molecules to pass according to their concentration gradient.

 

3. Paracellular transport: This shows molecules moving between cells through the spaces between adjacent cells, not through the cells themselves. This is passive movement along the concentration gradient and doesn't require ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Active transport: This shows fewer molecules on one side and more on the other side, indicating movement against the concentration gradient (from low to high concentration). This requires energy in the form of ATP to power the transport proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple diffusion through membrane, Simple diffusion through channels, Paracellular transport do not require ATP as they represent forms of passive transport, while Active transport requiring ATP

questions.text: In Decompression sickness, which one of the following is not seen? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemodilution

 

Decompression sickness (DCS) occurs when a rapid decrease in ambient pressure causes dissolved nitrogen to form bubbles in the tissues and blood vessels. When divers ascend too quickly from deep water, the dissolved nitrogen doesn't have time to be eliminated through normal respiration and forms bubbles in various body tissues.

 

These nitrogen bubbles cause vascular damage and endothelial injury, leading to several pathophysiological changes. One significant effect is capillary leak syndrome, where the plasma extravasates (leaks out of blood vessels into surrounding tissues). This extravasation of plasma causes hemoconcentration (increased concentration of blood cells) as the fluid component of blood leaves the vessels while the cellular components remain. 

 

This is precisely why hemodilution (the dilution of blood) is NOT seen in decompression sickness

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hearing loss: This is seen in decompression sickness. Nitrogen bubbles can damage the inner ear structures, leading to hearing impairment. The bubbles can affect the cochlea and vestibular apparatus, resulting in hearing loss and balance disturbances.

 

Option C. Thrombosis/Coagulopathy: This is seen in decompression sickness. The endothelial injury caused by nitrogen bubbles activates the coagulation cascade. Additionally, the hemoconcentration leads to stasis of blood flow (Virchow's triad: endothelial injury, stasis, and hypercoagulability), promoting thrombus formation.

 

Option D. Visual disturbances: This is seen in decompression sickness. Nitrogen bubbles can damage the retina or affect the rods and cones, leading to various visual impairments. Bubbles can also form in the cerebral circulation affecting visual pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decompression sickness causes hemoconcentration (not hemodilution) due to plasma extravasation resulting from vascular damage caused by nitrogen bubbles.

questions.text: Catecholamine secretion is increased by all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperglycemia

 

Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine) are released from the adrenal medulla and sympathetic nerve terminals in response to various physiological stressors. Their secretion is typically increased during situations that trigger the "fight or flight" response.

 

Hyperglycemia does not stimulate catecholamine release because high blood glucose levels don't represent a threat to the body that requires mobilization of energy resources. Catecholamines work to increase blood glucose through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Once glucose levels are already elevated, there's no physiological need for additional catecholamine release.

 

Catecholamine release occurs during hypoglycemia, quiet standing, surgery, smoking, exercise, and is highest in conditions like pheochromocytoma, myocardial infarction, and ketoacidosis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglycemia: Incorrect. Hypoglycemia is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release. When blood glucose levels fall below normal, catecholamines are released to mobilize glucose stores and increase blood glucose through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. This is an essential protective mechanism to ensure adequate glucose supply to the brain and other vital organs during periods of low blood glucose.

 

Option C. Smoking: Incorrect. Smoking causes nicotine to enter the bloodstream, which stimulates the adrenal medulla to release catecholamines. The nicotine in cigarettes acts on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia, triggering the release of epinephrine and norepinephrine. This is part of the physiological response that leads to increased heart rate and blood pressure observed in smokers.

 

Option D. Exercise: Incorrect. Exercise is a significant stimulus for catecholamine release. During physical activity, there's an increased demand for energy and oxygen delivery to working muscles. The sympathetic nervous system is activated, leading to the release of epinephrine and norepinephrine. These catecholamines help in increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate, and they mobilize energy sources to support the increased metabolic demands of exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catecholamine secretion increases during stress conditions like hypoglycemia, smoking, and exercise, but not during hyperglycemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following contributes to the latent period in a single muscle twitch? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Excitation-contraction coupling
  2. Opening of sodium channels on NMJ
  3. Transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to NMJ
  4. Pumping of calcium back to the sarcoplasmic reticulum
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c

 

The latent period in a single muscle twitch refers to the time delay between the application of stimulus and the beginning of muscle contraction. This period represents several physiological processes that must occur sequentially before the muscle begins to contract.

 

a) Excitation-contraction coupling is a major component of the latent period. It involves the process by which an electrical stimulus (action potential) is converted into a mechanical response (muscle contraction). This includes the action potential reaching T-tubules, activation of dihydropyridine (DHP) receptors, mechanical attachment of T-tubule with L-tubule, opening of ryanodine receptor (RyR) channels, release of Ca²⁺ from sarcoplasmic reticulum, formation of calcium-troponin complex, and displacement of tropomyosin to allow actin-myosin cross-bridge formation.

 

b) Opening of sodium channels at the neuromuscular junction is also part of the latent period. When acetylcholine binds to nicotinic receptors at the motor end plate, it leads to the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, which generates an action potential in the muscle fiber.

 

c) Transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to the neuromuscular junction contributes to the latent period as well. This involves the time taken for the action potential to propagate along the nerve fiber from the point of stimulation to the neuromuscular junction.

 

Other Option:

 

d) Pumping of calcium back to the sarcoplasmic reticulum is part of the relaxation phase of muscle contraction, not the latent period. This process occurs after the contraction has already begun and is responsible for muscle relaxation when Ca²⁺ is removed from the sarcoplasm by the SERCA pump (Sarco/Endoplasmic Reticulum Ca²⁺-ATPase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The latent period in a single muscle twitch includes excitation-contraction coupling, opening of sodium channels at the neuromuscular junction, and transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to the neuromuscular junction, but does not include calcium reuptake which is part of the relaxation phase.

choices.text: It is less than anatomical dead space
It can be measured by spirometry
It is because of inadequate perfusion
It is because of inadequate ventilation

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about physiological dead space? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is because of inadequate perfusion

 

Physiological dead space refers to the total volume of air that does not participate in gas exchange. It is composed of two components: anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space.

 

Anatomical dead space refers to the volume of air in the conducting airways (from the nose to the terminal bronchioles) that doesn't participate in gas exchange due to the structural anatomy of the respiratory system. The alveolar dead space refers to the volume of air that reaches the alveoli but doesn't participate in gas exchange due to inadequate perfusion of those alveoli.

 

When there is inadequate perfusion (blood flow) to normally ventilated alveoli, a ventilation-perfusion mismatch occurs. This is known as "wasted ventilation" - air reaches the alveoli but since there is insufficient blood flow, the gases cannot be exchanged effectively. This contributes to the physiological dead space.

 

"If there is inadequate perfusion, the alveoli are fine but the problem is in the capillaries. If there is obstruction in the capillaries, fewer molecules of hemoglobin are available to transport oxygen. The remaining oxygen molecules will stay in the alveoli, becoming unexchanged air. This wasted ventilation due to inadequate perfusion adds to physiological dead space."

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is less than anatomical dead space: This is incorrect because physiological dead space equals anatomical dead space in healthy individuals (where alveolar dead space is zero) or exceeds it in pathological conditions (where alveolar dead space is greater than zero). It cannot be less than anatomical dead space because anatomical dead space is determined by the fixed structure of the conducting airways.

 

Option B. It can be measured by spirometry: This is incorrect because spirometry only measures lung volumes and flow rates; it cannot differentiate between exchanged and unexchanged air. Physiological dead space is measured using Bohr's equation, which requires measuring partial pressures of CO2 in exhaled air and arterial blood.

 

Option D. It is because of inadequate ventilation: This is incorrect because inadequate ventilation does not increase dead space. When ventilation is reduced but perfusion is normal, whatever air does reach the alveoli will be completely exchanged due to the preserved perfusion. Inadequate ventilation creates a different type of ventilation-perfusion mismatch called "wasted perfusion" rather than increasing dead space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological dead space is the sum of anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space, with alveolar dead space occurring primarily due to inadequate perfusion of ventilated alveoli, resulting in wasted ventilation.

questions.text:
Which of the following about the enteric nervous regulation system is false? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Interstitial cells of Cajal are pacemakers
  2. It can function independently of the brain and spinal cord
  3. All the afferents are from the vagus nerve
  4. Myenteric plexus is in the Lamina propria
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

The enteric nervous system (ENS) is often referred to as the "brain of the GIT". This complex network of neurons can function autonomously but also communicates with the central nervous system.

 

3. All the afferents are from the vagus nerve: This is FALSE. While the vagus nerve (parasympathetic) does provide afferent innervation to the GIT, it is not the only source. Both the vagus nerve (parasympathetic) and sympathetic nerves provide afferent innervation to the GIT. 

 

4. Myenteric plexus is in the Lamina propria: This is FALSE. The myenteric plexus (also known as Auerbach's plexus) is located between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers of the muscularis, not in the lamina propria which is part of the mucosa. 

 

Correct statements: 

 

1. Interstitial cells of Cajal are pacemakers: This is TRUE. Interstitial cells of Cajal serve as pacemaker cells in the gastrointestinal tract. They produce Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER), which is defined as cyclic fluctuations in the resting membrane potential ranging from -40 to -60 mV. These cells are critical in establishing the intrinsic electrical rhythmicity of the GIT.

 

2. It can function independently of the brain and spinal cord: This is TRUE. The enteric nervous system is capable of functioning independently of the brain and spinal cord. The enteric nervous system is the "brain of GIT," and enteric nervous system connects with the autonomic nervous system, it can work independently through its own neural circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enteric nervous system is anatomically organized into two major plexuses - the myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus located between longitudinal and circular muscle layers that controls motility, and the submucosal (Meissner's) plexus that regulates secretion. The enteric nervous system receives dual innervation from both sympathetic and parasympathetic (vagal) sources while maintaining the ability to function independently.

questions.text:
LMN (Lower Motor Neuron) lesion is associated with which one of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Reduced muscle tone
  2. Spastic paralysis
  3. Babinski sign positive
  4. Fasciculation
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4

 

Lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions affect the motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord or their axons in the peripheral nerves. These lesions cause two key features: reduced muscle tone and fasciculation.

 

When there is LMN damage, both alpha and gamma motor neurons are affected. Alpha motor neurons control voluntary muscle contractions, while gamma motor neurons maintain muscle tone. When both are damaged, the patient loses voluntary control of muscles (causing paralysis) and has reduced muscle tone, resulting in flaccid paralysis.

 

Fasciculation is another hallmark of LMN lesions. These are visible, involuntary twitches that occur due to spontaneous discharges from denervated muscle fibers. This phenomenon occurs because of "denervation hypersensitivity" where muscle fibers become hypersensitive after losing their nerve supply.

 

1. Reduced muscle tone: Correct. LMN lesions cause loss of gamma motor neuron activity, which is responsible for maintaining muscle tone. Without this input, muscles become flaccid.

 

4. Fasciculation: Correct. Fasciculations are random, spontaneous contractions of a group of muscle fibers innervated by a single motor unit. They are characteristic of LMN disorders due to denervation hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Spastic paralysis: Incorrect. Spastic paralysis is characteristic of upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions, not LMN lesions. UMN lesions result in the removal of inhibitory control from higher centers, leading to hyperexcitability of the spinal motor neurons and increased muscle tone. 

 

3. Babinski sign positive: Incorrect. Babinski sign (dorsiflexion of the great toe with fanning of other toes in response to stroking the lateral aspect of the sole) is a pathological reflex seen in UMN lesions, not LMN lesions. It occurs due to the release of the normal flexor plantar response from cortical inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to which one of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoxia

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors, located in the carotid bodies (innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve/9th cranial nerve) and aortic bodies (innervated by the vagus nerve/10th cranial nerve), are primarily sensitive to changes in blood oxygen levels. While they do respond to multiple stimuli, they are most sensitive to decreases in PO₂ (hypoxia).

 

The peripheral chemoreceptors respond to:

 

  • Decreased PO₂ (less than 60 mmHg) - primary stimulus
  • Increased PCO₂
  • Increased H⁺ (acidosis)

 

"oxygen sensitive potassium channels" in the glomus cells of peripheral chemoreceptors make them highly responsive to decreases in oxygen. When comparing sensitivity, if you increase carbon dioxide by 1% or decrease oxygen by 1%, the hypoxic response will be much stronger than the hypercapnic response.

 

While CO₂ is the main overall stimulus for respiration (as it affects both central and peripheral chemoreceptors), when specifically discussing peripheral chemoreceptors alone, hypoxia is the stimulus to which they are most sensitive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO₂: While peripheral chemoreceptors do respond to increases in PCO₂, they are less sensitive to CO₂ than to hypoxia. CO₂ primarily stimulates central chemoreceptors in the ventral medulla which respond to changes in H⁺ ion concentration in the CSF. CO₂ is the main stimulus for respiration overall, but not the most sensitive stimulus for peripheral chemoreceptors specifically.

 

Option C. Alkalosis: Peripheral chemoreceptors are not significantly stimulated by alkalosis (increased pH or decreased H⁺ concentration). Alkalosis tends to decrease respiratory drive rather than stimulate it.

 

Option D. Acidosis: Although peripheral chemoreceptors do respond to acidosis (decreased pH, increased H⁺), they are still more sensitive to hypoxia. Acidosis is a secondary stimulus for peripheral chemoreceptors compared to hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid and aortic bodies) are most sensitive to hypoxia (decreased PO₂ less than 60 mmHg), despite also responding to increases in PCO₂ and H⁺ (acidosis).

questions.text: Nail lacquer used in treatment of Onychomycosis among the given options: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tavaborole

 

Tavaborole is a topical nail lacquer used for treating onychomycosis (fungal nail infection). Nail lacquers are specially formulated topical medications that act like nail polish and are designed to penetrate the nail plate. 

 

The common nail lacquers used in onychomycosis can be remembered by the mnemonic "CEAT":

 

 

  • Ciclopirox-olamine (8%)
  • Efinaconazole (10%)
  • Amorolfine (5%)
  • Tavaborole (5%)
  • Terbinafine

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Griseofulvin: It is an oral antifungal medication, not a nail lacquer. It is primarily used for treating tinea capitis and is the drug of choice for dermatophyte infections of the scalp.

 

Option C. Caspofungin: It is an Echinocandin antifungal used for treating systemic fungal infections, not as a topical nail lacquer.

 

Option D. Itraconazole: It is an oral antifungal agent used in systemic therapy of onychomycosis. It is given as pulse therapy: 200mg BD/week for 2 months in fingernail infection and 3 months in toenail infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tavaborole (5%) is one of the approved nail lacquers used as topical therapy in onychomycosis, along with other agents like Amorolfine, Ciclopirox-olamine and Efinaconazole.

questions.text: A farmer from Himachal Pradesh presented with nodulo ulcerative lesions with axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sporothrix

 

This is a classic presentation of Sporotrichosis, also known as "Rose Gardner's Disease." 

 

  • Occupation and location: Farmers in Himachal Pradesh are at risk due to frequent contact with thorny plants
  • Clinical presentation: Noduloulcerative lesions that spread along lymphatics (Sporotrichoid pattern)

 

 

  • Axillary lymphadenopathy: Characteristic of lymphocutaneous spread The causative organism is Sporothrix schenckii, which enters through traumatic inoculation. 
  • Histopathology shows characteristic "asteroid bodies."

 

 

  • Treatment includes saturated solution of potassium iodide (SSKI) and itraconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histoplasma: Histoplasma capsulatum is primarily a respiratory pathogen that causes systemic infection through inhalation. It doesn't typically cause primary cutaneous lesions with lymphatic spread.

 

Option C. Coccidioides: Coccidioides immitis is also primarily a respiratory pathogen causing pulmonary infection through inhalation. It's endemic to southwestern United States, not Himachal Pradesh.

 

Option D. Blastomycosis: Blastomyces dermatitidis typically causes pulmonary infection with secondary cutaneous manifestations. It doesn't show the characteristic lymphocutaneous spread seen in sporotrichosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sporotrichosis (Rose Gardener’s Disease) is caused by Sporothrix schenckii and presents with noduloulcerative lesions following a Sporotrichoid pattern along lymphatics.
  • It is common in farmers, gardeners, and those handling plants or soil.

questions.text: In males, urethritis is caused by all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gardnerella

 

Male urethritis can be classified into:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis: Caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis: Caused by: 
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Mycoplasma hominis
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Gardnerella vaginalis is not associated with male urethritis. It is instead associated with bacterial vaginosis in females, causing a characteristic homogeneous white adherent discharge with fishy odor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neisseria: N. gonorrhoeae is a major cause of urethritis in males, presenting with purulent urethral discharge 2-5 days after exposure.

 

Option B. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma hominis is a recognized cause of non-gonococcal urethritis in males.

 

Option C. Trichomonas: T. vaginalis can cause non-gonococcal urethritis in males in addition to vaginal discharge in females.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gardnerella vaginalis is not a causative organism of male urethritis, while recognizing the common bacterial and protozoal causes of both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis in males.

questions.text: A Himachal gardener man walks barefoot. Which infection is he prone to develop? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Madurella Mycetomatis

 

Madurella mycetomatis causes mycetoma (madura foot), a chronic granulomatous infection that typically occurs through direct inoculation via barefoot walking. 
The condition presents with the classic triad (GST):

 

  • Grains/Granules:  Coming out through sinus tracts
  • Sinuses:  Multiple draining sinuses
  • Tumefaction:  Swelling of the affected area.

 

Mycetoma can be:

 

Eumycetoma: Caused by fungi like Madurella mycetomatis

 

Actinomycetoma: Caused by bacteria.

 

Treatment includes antifungals for eumycetoma and the modified Welsh regimen (Cotrimoxazole, Amikacin, Rifampicin) for Actinomycetoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryptococcosis: It's primarily acquired through inhalation of Cryptococcus neoformns and typically causes pulmonary or CNS infection, not through barefoot walking.

 

Option C. Toxocara canis: Helminthic infection is acquired through ingestion of contaminated soil or feces, not through barefoot walking.

 

Option D. Coccidioides immitis: It causes coccidioidomycosis through inhalation of fungal spores, primarily affecting the respiratory system, not through barefoot walking.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barefoot walking predisposes to mycetoma caused by Madurella mycetomatis, presenting with the classic triad of grains, sinuses, and tumefaction.

questions.text: All of the following methods of cold sterilization except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autoclave

 

Cold sterilization refers to sterilization methods that do not involve heat application. Autoclave operates at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, making it a hot sterilization method rather than a cold sterilization technique.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Plasma sterilization: 

 

  • This is a valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses gases in plasma state without temperature increase
  • Effective for heat-sensitive materials

 

Option B. Gamma rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses ionizing radiation
  • Does not increase temperature
  • Commonly used for medical devices and supplies

 

Option C. UV rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses non-ionizing radiation
  • Does not generate heat
  • Effective for surface sterilization

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autoclave is a hot sterilization method operating at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, while plasma sterilization, gamma rays, and UV rays are cold sterilization methods that do not involve heat application.

choices.text: Heat till it become red hot

questions.text: Inoculation loops are commonly sterilized by which method? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heat till it becomes red hot

 

Inoculation loops are typically made of nichrome wire with a circular structure at one end and a wooden handle. The most appropriate method for sterilizing these loops is heating them until they become red hot, which is a type of physical heat method. This method ensures complete sterilization of the metal portion of the loop that comes in contact with microorganisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoclaving:

 

  • Incorrect because autoclaving is not suitable for inoculation loops as it would be impractical and unnecessary
  • Autoclaving is primarily used for bulk sterilization of media, equipment, and materials at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI

 

Option B. Microwave:

 

  • Incorrect because microwave sterilization is not appropriate for metal objects like inoculation loops
  • Microwaves can cause arcing with metal objects and potentially damage the equipment

 

Option C. Passing over flame 3 times:

 

  • Incorrect because this method is specifically used for degreasing glass slides
  • This technique would not provide sufficient heat to ensure complete sterilization of the inoculation loop

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Inoculation loops must be sterilized by heating till red hot to ensure complete elimination of microorganisms, as this is the most effective and practical physical heat method for these instruments.

questions.text: Which of the following test is used for antibiotic sensitivity? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E-test (Epsilometer test)

 

The E-test or Epsilometer test is specifically designed for antibiotic sensitivity testing. It involves:

 

  • Using a Muller-Hinton agar (MHA) plate as the culture medium
  • Streaking the test organism on the plate
  • Applying an E-strip containing gradients of antibiotic concentrations
  • The strip has increasing antibiotic concentration going up and decreasing concentration going down
  • Where the zone of inhibition intersects the strip indicates the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of the antibiotic
  • Formation of an elliptical zone of inhibition around the strip indicates susceptibility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elek's test

 

  • This is used for detecting diphtheria toxin production by Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • It's a gel precipitation test where antitoxin strips are used to detect toxin production
  • Not related to antibiotic sensitivity testing

 

Option C. Latex agglutination test

 

  • This is an agglutination-based test used for various diagnostic purposes
  • Used for detecting antigens or antibodies in clinical specimens
  • Not used for determining antibiotic sensitivity

 

Option D. CAMP test

 

  • Used to detect beta-hemolysis
  • Primarily used for identifying Group B Streptococcus (S. agalactiae) and Listeria
  • Not related to antibiotic susceptibility testing

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E-test (Epsilometer test) is the standard method for determining the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of antibiotics against bacteria using an antibiotic gradient strip.

questions.text: A 20- year male had a pustule which rapidly progressed to necrotizing fascitis. On microscopy findings were seen. What is the most likely organism involved in this case? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

The diagnosis of Streptococcus pyogenes is supported by:

 

  1. Clinical presentation: Pustule rapidly progressing to necrotizing fasciitis
  2. Microscopy findings: Gram-positive cocci arranged in chains
  3. Necrotizing fasciitis is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), followed by Staphylococcus aureus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus:

 

  • While it can cause necrotizing fasciitis, it appears as gram-positive cocci in clusters
  • Not consistent with the chain arrangement seen in the microscopy image

 

Option C. Enterococcus:

 

  • Appears as gram-positive cocci in pairs
  • Not typically associated with necrotizing fasciitis
  • More commonly causes urinary tract infections and endocarditis

 

Option D. Micrococcus:

 

  • Appears as gram-positive cocci in tetrads
  • Not a common pathogen
  • Rarely causes human infections
  • Usually a contaminant

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus):

 

  1. Is the most common cause of necrotizing fasciitis
  2. Appears microscopically as gram-positive cocci in chains
  3. Can progress rapidly from a superficial infection to deep tissue involvement

questions.text: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is typically cultured in which medium? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lowenstein-Jensen medium

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis requires a special medium for growth and cannot grow on routine culture media. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the standard and most commonly used medium for culturing M. tuberculosis. This medium contains:

 

  • Coagulated egg proteins
  • Glycerol
  • Asparagine
  • Potato flour
  • Mineral salts: The medium provides essential nutrients and supports the slow growth of mycobacteria over 3-8 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macconkey agar: Incorrect 

 

  • This medium is used for growing and differentiating Gram-negative enteric bacteria
  • It contains bile salts and crystal violet which inhibit Gram-positive bacteria
  • M. tuberculosis cannot grow on this medium

 

Option C. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Incorrect

 

  • This is a selective medium used for isolating fungi
  • Its acidic pH and high glucose concentration make it unsuitable for bacterial growth
  • M. tuberculosis requires more complex nutrients not present in this medium

 

Option D. Mueller-Hinton agar: Incorrect

 

  • This is a non-selective medium primarily used for antibiotic susceptibility testing
  • It lacks the specific nutrients required for mycobacterial growth
  • The growth time required by M. tuberculosis is too long for this medium

 

Educational Objective: 

 

M. tuberculosis requires specific growth conditions and must be cultured on Lowenstein-Jensen medium, which provides the necessary nutrients for its slow growth over several weeks.

choices.text: Heavy infection is associated with Rectal prolapse
Fertilised unembronated egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil
Can spread to lungs and cause Asthma like symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following options is wrong about ascaris lumbricoides? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heavy infection is associated with Rectal prolapse

 

Heavy infection with rectal prolapse is NOT associated with Ascaris lumbricoides infection. This clinical manifestation is actually characteristic of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Most infections are asymptomatic: Most Ascaris infections are indeed asymptomatic, particularly in immunocompetent individuals. This is an important clinical feature of ascariasis.

 

Option C. Fertilised unembronated egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil: Ascaris eggs can be either embryonated or unembryonated. The unembryonated eggs require time in soil to develop and become infective. 

 

Option D. Can spread to lungs and cause Asthma like symptoms: Ascaris larvae migrate through the lungs as part of their life cycle (pulmonary phase). During this migration, they can cause respiratory symptoms including cough, wheezing, and asthma-like symptoms, known as Löffler's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rectal prolapse is a characteristic complication of heavy Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection, not Ascaris lumbricoides infection. Ascaris causes pulmonary symptoms during its larval migration phase and is often asymptomatic in its intestinal phase.

questions.text: A farmer presents with history of blunt trauma to the chest. There is formation of pus from the wound. Microscopy showed mildly acid fast bacteria with branching. What is the most likely organism? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nocardia species

 

The diagnosis of Nocardia is suggested by:

 

  1. Clinical presentation - History of trauma in a farmer (occupational exposure)
  2. Microscopic features: 
    • Mildly acid-fast (1% acid-fast positive)
    • Branching filamentous bacteria
    • Gram-positive staining pattern
  3. Formation of pus indicating suppurative infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

 

  • While acid-fast positive, does not show branching morphology
  • Primarily causes pulmonary TB through inhalation, not through trauma
  • Strongly acid-fast, not mildly acid-fast

 

Option C. Listeria:

 

  • Not acid-fast
  • Appears as small gram-positive rods
  • Does not show branching morphology

 

Option D. Anthrax:

 

  • Not acid-fast
  • Appears as gram-positive rods with square ends
  • Does not show branching pattern
  • Though associated with occupational exposure, presents differently

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nocardia is characterized by being:

 

  1. Mildly acid-fast (1% acid-fast positive)
  2. Shows branching filamentous morphology
  3. Common in traumatic injuries with soil contamination
  4. Important occupational pathogen

questions.text: DOC for fasciola hepatica: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triclabendazole

 

Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for treating Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infections because:

 

  • It is the latest and most effective drug available
  • Has excellent activity against both immature and mature flukes
  • Single dose treatment is often effective
  • Well-tolerated with minimal side effects
  • WHO recommended first-line treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Albendazole:

 

  • More effective against nematodes
  • Limited efficacy against liver flukes
  • Not recommended as first-line therapy for fascioliasis

 

Option C. Mebendazole:

 

  • Primarily used for treating intestinal nematodes
  • Poor absorption and bioavailability
  • Not effective against liver flukes

 

Option D. Praziquantel:

 

  • While effective against most trematodes
  • Has poor efficacy against Fasciola species
  • Used mainly for schistosomiasis and other fluke infections

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for treating Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of passive immunity? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoid

 

Passive immunity occurs when antibodies are transferred to an individual without stimulating their immune system. The key characteristic of passive immunity is that it provides immediate but temporary protection, as it doesn't involve the host's immune system actively producing antibodies. Passive immunity can be acquired naturally (through maternal transfer) or artificially (through immunoglobulin administration).

 

A toxoid, being a modified form of bacterial toxin, actually stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies, making it a form of active immunity rather than passive immunity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Antitoxin: Incorrect because antitoxins are preformed antibodies against specific toxins. When administered, they provide immediate protection without stimulating the immune system, making them a true example of passive immunity.

 

Option C. IgA: Incorrect because maternal IgA transferred through breast milk is a classic example of naturally acquired passive immunity, providing immediate protection to infants.

 

Option D. Monoclonal antibodies: Incorrect because these are laboratory-produced antibodies that provide immediate protection without stimulating the immune system, representing artificial passive immunity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Passive immunity involves direct antibody transfer without immune system stimulation, while active immunity (like toxoids) involves stimulating the immune system to produce its own antibodies.

questions.text: Most common cause of diarrhoea in children: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotavirus

 

Rotavirus is consistently recognized as the most common cause of severe diarrheal disease in children worldwide. It is particularly significant in infants and young children, causing acute gastroenteritis. The virus primarily affects the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to malabsorption and secretory diarrhea. Rotavirus infection is characterized by:

 

  • Severe watery diarrhea
  • Vomiting
  • Fever
  • Abdominal pain
  • Rapid dehydration, especially in young children

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Escherichia coli: Incorrect because while E. coli (particularly ETEC and EHEC strains) is an important cause of diarrhea in children, it is not the most common causative agent. E. coli typically causes traveler's diarrhea and some specific syndromes like hemolytic uremic syndrome.

 

Option C. Ascaris: Incorrect because although Ascaris lumbricoides can cause various gastrointestinal symptoms, it is primarily a helminthic infection that doesn't typically present with diarrhea as the main symptom. Most Ascaris infections are actually asymptomatic.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect because while Shigella is an important cause of dysentery in children, it typically causes bloody diarrhea with mucus and is not the most common overall cause of childhood diarrhea. It is more associated with poor sanitation and hygiene conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the leading cause of severe diarrheal disease in infants and young children worldwide.

 

Agents causing Traveler's diarrhea

questions.text: A pus swab should be discarded in which of the following waste containers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow bag

 

Pus swabs are considered soiled or infected waste materials. As per biomedical waste management guidelines, any material that is soiled, infected, or contaminated with blood or body fluids should be discarded in yellow bags. The yellow bag is specifically designated for:

 

  • Soiled waste
  • Items contaminated with blood
  • Body fluid contaminated items
  • Laboratory waste
  • Microbiological waste
  • Other infected materials

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Red bag: Incorrect because red bags are specifically meant for plastic waste materials such as IV sets, syringes (without needles), catheters, and other plastic medical items.

 

Option C. Black bag: Incorrect because black bags are designated for non-infectious general waste from hospitals such as papers, packaging materials, cartons, and food waste. These materials pose no infection risk.

 

Option D. Blue bag: Incorrect because blue bags/containers are meant for broken or discarded glass items, including:

 

  • Broken glassware
  • Medicine vials
  • Ampoules
  • Other glass materials used in healthcare settings

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Yellow bags are designated for soiled and infected waste materials in biomedical waste management, including pus swabs and other contaminated materials.

questions.text: Match each disease with the correct causative agent from the options provided: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1

 

The correct matching is:

 

  • Donovanosis - Klebsiella granulomatis (A-2)
  • Oroya fever - Bartonella bacilliformis (B-3)
  • Rat bite fever - Streptobacillus moniliformis (C-4)
  • Pinta - Treponema carateum (D-1)

 

For each disease:

 

  1. Donovanosis is a sexually transmitted infection that causes ulcerative lesions, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  2. Oroya fever, also known as Carrion's disease, is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis and is transmitted by sandflies.
  3. Rat bite fever is an infection caused by Streptobacillus moniliformis, typically transmitted through rat bites or contact with rat excreta.
  4. Pinta is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by Treponema carateum, characterized by skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The specific causative organisms for these bacterial diseases:

 

  • Donovanosis → Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Oroya fever → Bartonella bacilliformis
  • Rat bite fever → Streptobacillus moniliformis
  • Pinta → Treponema carateum

choices.text: Cryptococcus gatti is Associated with bird droppings
All pathogenic strains are urease positive

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Cryptococcus, except? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD4 count greater than 500

 

Cryptococcus infection occurs when CD4 counts fall below 100 cells/microliter. This makes option d incorrect as Cryptococcus infections do not occur at CD4 counts greater than 500. The infection is strongly associated with severe immunocompromise, particularly in AIDS patients with very low CD4 counts (<100 cells/μL).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extrapulmonary cryptococcus is AIDS defining: Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis is considered an AIDS-defining illness. When Cryptococcus spreads beyond the lungs in HIV patients, it signifies advanced immunosuppression and meets criteria for AIDS diagnosis.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus gatti is Associated with bird droppings: While Cryptococcus neoformans is the more commonly known species, Cryptococcus gatti is also associated with bird droppings, particularly pigeon excreta. Both species can be found in soil contaminated with bird droppings.

 

Option C. All pathogenic strains are urease positive: All pathogenic strains of Cryptococcus are urease positive. This is an important diagnostic feature used to identify Cryptococcus species in laboratory testing. The urease test helps differentiate Cryptococcus from other yeasts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cryptococcal infections occur at CD4 counts less than 100 cells/microliter, not at counts greater than 500. This is a crucial diagnostic criterion for suspecting cryptococcal infection in HIV/AIDS patients.

questions.text: IV anesthetic agent that causes adrenocortical suppression is: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Etomidate

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting the 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex. This enzyme is responsible for steroid production in the body. When etomidate inhibits this enzyme, it reduces steroid production, which can lead to adrenocortical suppression. Due to this effect, etomidate should be avoided in critically ill or septic patients where maintaining adequate steroid levels is important for hemodynamic stability.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Propofol: Does not cause adrenocortical suppression. It acts mainly through GABA receptors and affects the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: A barbiturate that acts on GABA receptors but does not affect adrenal function or steroid synthesis.

 

Option D. Ketamine: An NMDA receptor antagonist that actually stimulates the sympathetic system and may increase steroid levels rather than suppress them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex, making it unsuitable for use in critically ill or septic patients who require normal steroid function.

questions.text: A person has suffered from chest trauma resulting in fracture of 2-6th ribs. He is being given pain relief by IV analgesic agents. Which of these blocks will be helpful in pain relief? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thoracic epidural

 

For multiple rib fractures (2nd-6th ribs), thoracic epidural is the most appropriate choice  because:

 

  • It provides effective pain relief by blocking multiple spinal nerve roots at once through a single catheter
  • The epidural can be placed at T4-T5 level to cover the affected dermatomes
  • It allows continuous analgesia through catheter placement
  • It provides stable hemodynamics
  • The epidural catheter can be used for repeated administration of local anesthetic for prolonged pain relief

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical plexus block: Only supplies the neck and shoulder region. Not suitable for rib fractures as it does not cover the thoracic dermatomes.

 

Option B. Supraclavicular block: This is a brachial plexus block that provides anesthesia to the upper limb. It does not cover the thoracic area or ribs.

 

Option D. Lumbar epidural: Provides analgesia below the umbilicus. Not suitable for upper thoracic dermatomes where the fractured ribs are located.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Thoracic epidural is the optimal choice for pain management in multiple rib fractures as it provides effective analgesia through continuous blockade of multiple thoracic dermatomes.

choices.text: It achieves maximum concentration in brain after IV infusion
Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen
The rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

questions.text: Which of these statements is incorrect about Thiopentone? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

 

The rapid decline in thiopentone's effect is due to redistribution, not renal excretion. Thiopentone's ultra-short acting nature is due to:

 

  • Initial high concentration in brain due to high lipid solubility
  • Subsequent redistribution from brain to less perfused tissues like muscle and fat
  • This redistribution causes rapid decline in brain concentration leading to awakening
  • Continuous redistribution between highly perfused and less perfused lipid-soluble areas maintains this pattern
  • The process is independent of renal excretion

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is highly lipid soluble: Correct statement. This property allows rapid crossing of blood-brain barrier.

 

Option B. It achieves maximum concentration in brain after IV infusion: Correct statement. Due to brain being highly perfused and thiopentone's lipid solubility.

 

Option C. Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen: Correct statement. This is the key mechanism for its short duration of action.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The rapid decline in thiopentone's anesthetic effect is due to redistribution to less perfused tissues, not renal excretion, explaining its ultra-short acting nature.

 

THIOPENTONE

 

  • T - Thiobarbiturates
  • H - Hyperthyroidism
  • I - Inadvertent intra-arterial Injection causes vasospasm (treatment - flush with NS, heparin, lignocaine)
  • O - pH 10.5 (alkaline)
  • P - pH
  • Porphyrias (C/I)
  • Prolongation of QT interval
  • E - Epilepsy
  • N - Neuroanesthesia (DOC)
  • T - Termination of action - redistribution

questions.text: Jackson Rees circuit is used in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pediatric controlled ventilation

 

Jackson Rees circuit (also known as Mapleson F circuit) is specifically designed for:

 

  • Pediatric patients
  • Can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation in children
  • It's a modification of the Ayre's T-piece with an open-ended bag
  • This circuit is ideal for pediatric anesthesia due to its low resistance and minimal dead space

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Adult controlled ventilation: Not appropriate as Jackson Rees circuit is designed for pediatric patients. Adults require circuits with larger volumes and different configurations.

 

Option C. Obstetric ventilation: Obstetric patients require specialized circuits that can deliver high flow rates and manage rapid changes in ventilation demands.

 

Option D. Cardiac patients: Cardiac patients typically require precise control over ventilation parameters, which is better achieved with more sophisticated circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jackson Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is specifically designed and used for pediatric anesthesia, suitable for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

questions.text: AMBU AURA40 is what generation LMA? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First

 

AMBU AURA40 is a first-generation LMA because:

 

  • It has only one tube (the airway tube)
  • No separate gastric drainage channel
  • It is essentially a modified version of the classic LMA
  • The number "40" in its name indicates it can be used up to 40 times
  • It is unlike second-generation LMAs like Ambu AuraGain which have two tubes (airway and gastric drainage)

 



Educational Objective:

 

AMBU AURA40 is a first-generation LMA characterized by having only one tube for airway management without a separate gastric drainage channel.

 

Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) Generations

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of frequent episodes of red, painful eyes, stiffness, and back pain. He has sacroiliitis and anterior uveitis, according to the examination. Which HLA is frequently involved among the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HLA B27

 

The patient's symptoms of red painful eyes, stiffness, back pain, sacroiliitis, and anterior uveitis strongly indicates ankylosing spondylitis. 

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS (AS)

 

  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton (sacroiliac joint and spine) with variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints. 
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy. 
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Males are affected more frequently than females (2:1 to 10:1)
    • Age of onset is between 15–25 years (late adolescence and early adulthood).
    • The initial symptom is usually dull pain, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, accompanied by low back morning stiffness of few hours that improves with activity and returns following rest.
    • Question mark (?) posture can occur due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis. 
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late.
    • The most common extra-articular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis) occurring in 30%. Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
  • Diagnostic Criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria must be one of the 3:
      1. Inflammatory back pain
      2. Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) 
      3. Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).
    • Inflammatory back pain is classified if 4/5 are present
      1. Pain for > 3 months
      2. <40 years of age
      3. Insidious onset
      4. Pain improves with exercise
      5. Pain at night
  • Etiology and Pathogenesis:
    • > 90% of AS patients are HLA-B27 positive. 
    • The enthesis is the primary site of pathology particularly in pelvis and spine.
    • It is associated with prominent edema of adjacent bone marrow and is characterized by erosive lesions that eventually undergo ossification.
    • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA DR4: HLA DR4 is associated with autoimmune diseases. It is more strongly linked to rheumatoid arthritis and type 1 diabetes.

 

Option B. HLA DR3: HLA DR3 is associated with autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes, Graves' disease, and celiac disease.

 

Option C. HLA DQB1: HLA DQB1 is also linked to autoimmune diseases, particularly type 1 diabetes and celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The patient's symptoms of red painful eyes, stiffness, back pain, sacroiliitis, and anterior uveitis strongly indicates ankylosing spondylitis. 
  • HLA-B27 is strongly associated with this condition. 
  • Other HLA types are linked to various autoimmune diseases, HLA-B27 is the most strongly associated with this specific presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was taken to a trauma centre after suffering an accident. An X-ray of her pelvis was taken, and the image below demonstrates an intracapsular fracture neck of femur. In this instance, what is the management?  (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed reduction + internal fixation 

 

  • Intracapsular neck of femur fractures (# NOF) occur within the capsule of the hip joint.

  • The blood supply to femoral head travels in a retrograde direction via the capsule. So, any fracture within the capsule could likely damage the blood supply.  

  • Closed reduction and internal fixation method is favored in younger patients to preserve their natural hip joint.

  • In younger, active patients, the primary aim is always to save their own femoral head and avoid the need for joint replacement if possible. CRIF allows the fracture to heal, maintaining the patient's natural anatomy and biomechanics.

  • Intracapsular femoral neck fractures increases the risk of AVN of the femoral head. While the initial injury itself can compromise blood supply, a precise and anatomical reduction of the fracture fragments is crucial to potentially restore or optimize blood flow to the femoral head, thereby reducing the risk of AVN. CRIF, if successful, can achieve this without further disturbing the soft tissues and remaining blood supply around the fracture.

  • CRIF involves smaller incisions compared to ORIF, potentially leading to less soft tissue disruption, less blood loss, and a quicker initial recovery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemiarthroplasty: This is recommended in patients > 65 years of age with displaced fractures, lower functional demands, or pre-existing hip arthritis.

 

Option B. ORIF: ORIF is often preferred for younger and more active individuals where preserving the femoral head is a priority. While ORIF is also a valid treatment, closed reduction is often attempted first to minimize surgical trauma. If a closed reduction is not possible, then an open reduction may be necessary. Open reduction involves a larger incision and more disruption of the soft tissues around the hip joint which can potentially compromise the precarious blood supply to the femoral head, which is already at risk in an intracapsular fracture. ORIF is usually reserved for cases where closed reduction attempts fail. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a young patient, usually < 65 years of age, the ideal treatment method for intracapsular femoral neck fractures is closed reduction and internal fixation using cancellous screws. 

  • CRIF saves the femoral head by providing stable fixation after reduction, minimizing additional trauma to the already compromised blood supply, and avoiding the long-term complications. 

  • ORIF is usually an option if CRIF fails, and hemiarthroplasty is reserved for older, less active individuals.

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with fracture following a trivial fall. X-ray is shown below. Determine the reason of fracture in the patient. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bone Metastasis

 

  • The skeleton is the third most common site of metastasis after lung and liver.
  • Bone metastases cause bone destruction increasing the patient’s risk for atraumatic fracture. 
  • The presentation is dependent on the site of the disease however; constant pain is a prevalent symptom. 
  • Fractures of the thoracic and lumbar spine present with pain characteristically worse with sitting or standing. 
  • Pathologic fractures result in significant morbidities resulting from pain, radiculopathy (e.g., sciatica with pelvic fracture), deformities, and immobility. 
  • Plain radiography detects osteolytic lesions, but they may not be apparent until they are > 1-2 cm with loss of 50% of the bone mineral content at the site of disease. 
  • Osteolytic lesions are seen as thinning of trabeculae and ill-defined margins on radiographs, while sclerotic lesions appear nodular and well-circumscribed as a result of thickened trabeculae. 
  • Plain films tend to be insensitive, especially in detecting bone metastases and with asymptomatic and subtle lesions. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubercular Hip: Tuberculosis of the hip typically presents with insidious pain and limited range of motion, often over a prolonged period. A fracture due to a trivial fall is less characteristic.

 

Option B. Brown Tumour: Brown tumors are a consequence of hyperparathyroidism. They typically present with pathological fractures, but the X-ray appearance would usually show distinct radiolucent areas. The pattern of the fracture and appearance of the lesion in the provided X-ray are not suggestive of brown tumor.

 

Option D. Eosinophilic Granuloma: This condition often affects children or young adults and manifests as a localized bone lesion. It is usually a benign lytic lesion. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most likely diagnosis for the provided x-ray and patient’s history of fracture following a fall is bone metastasis. 
  • Metastatic bone disease, common in elderly patients, often weakens the bone, making it prone to fracture, even with minimal trauma. 
  • The X-ray might show subtle changes suggestive of bone loss and/or a lesion, which could indicate the presence of metastatic disease.

questions.text: Which muscle on the other supporting side is problematic when standing on one leg? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gluteus Medius

 

  • Normally, when the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei (medius and minimus) of the supported side contract and raise the opposite and unsupported side of pelvis. 

 

 

  • If the abductor mechanism is defective, the unsupported side of pelvis drops and this is known as positive Trendelenburg's test.

 

 

  • Trendelenburg's test is done to assess the integrity of abductor mechanism. 
  • It is positive in the conditions in which any of the three — fulcrum (Femoral Head), lever arm (neck length) or power (muscles/nerve) is affected.
  • Causes of Positive Trendelenburg Test:
    1. Paralysis of abductor muscles:
      • Superior gluteal nerve palsy (supply gluteus medius and minimus)
      • Polio
      • Iliotibial tract palsy
    2. Decreased lever arm: Fracture neck femur
    3. Absence of stable fulcrum about which the abductor muscles can act: Dislocation of hip, destruction of femoral head as in Perthes disease, AVN, late stages of TB hip (stage 4 and 5) and septic arthritis.
    4. Tuberculosis of Hip: Trendelenberg's test may be positive in TB hip only in late stages (stage 4 and 5) when the head of femur is destroyed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliacus: This muscle is primarily a hip flexor and doesn't play as significant a role in single-leg stance.

 

Option C. Gluteus Maximus: While important for hip extension, it's not the primary muscle responsible for stabilizing the pelvis during single-leg stance.

 

Option D. Quadratus Lumborum: This muscle helps with lateral flexion of the spine, but its role in single-leg balance is less direct compared to the gluteus medius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gluteus medius muscle is crucial for hip abduction and pelvic stability. 
  • When standing on one leg, the gluteus medius on the supporting side works hard to prevent your pelvis from dropping towards the non-supporting side. 
  • Weakness in this muscle can lead to a Trendelenburg gait, where the pelvis dips excessively on the unsupported side.

questions.text: Which action will be impacted in PIN Palsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extension of fingers

 

  • PIN palsy can occur from repetitive pronation-supination movements, fracture/dislocation (e.g., monteggia fracture, radial head fracture, etc.), ganglion, rheumatoid synovitis of radiocapitellar joint.
  • PIN is a branch of the radial nerve that provides motor innervation to the extensor compartment of the forearm. 
  • Course:
    • Passes between the two heads of origin of the supinator muscle 
    • Direct contact with the radial neck 
    • Passes over abductor pollicis longus muscle origin to reach interosseous membrane
    • Transverses along the posterior interosseous membrane
  • Innervation:
    • Common extensors: ECRB, Extensor digitorum communis, Extensor digiti minimi, Extensor carpi ulnaris 
    • Deep extensors: Supinator, Abductor pollicis longus, Extensor pollicus brevis, Extensor pollicus longus 
  • The symptoms of PIN palsy are often insidious in onset, usually goes undiagnosed.
  • The patient complaints of pain in the forearm and wrist, and weakness of finger, wrist and thumb movements 
  • On examination, there is forearm extensor compartment muscle atrophy, weakness of finger metacarpal extension, wrist extension, and an inability to extend wrist in ulnar deviation. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supination of forearm: This movement is facilitated by the supinator, biceps brachii and brachioradialis muscles. The supinator muscle is supplied by the PIN, but it has some innervation from the radial nerve before the PIN branches off, so supination is usually not completely lost. The bicep brachii is supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve while the brachioradialis is supplied by the radial nerve.

 

Option C. Extension of elbow: The primary elbow extensor muscles are triceps brachii and anconeus. It is supplied by the radial nerve, thus it remains unaffected in PIN palsy. 

 

Option D. Wrist drop: Wrist drop is a disorder caused by radial nerve palsy. Because of the radial nerve's innervation of the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits, those whose radial nerve function has been compromised cannot actively extend them. As such, the hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PIN palsy is a neuropathic compression of the posterior interosseous nerve where it passes through the radial tunnel.
  • This may result in paresis or paralysis of the digital and thumb extensor muscles, resulting in an inability to extend the thumb and fingers at their MCP joints.
  • Wrist extension is preserved due to the action of the extensor carpi radialis longus innervated by the radial nerve.

questions.text: FRAX is related to: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture risk assessment 

 

  • FRAX or Fracture Risk Assessment Tool, is a screening tool that provides country-specific algorithms for estimating individualized 10-year probability of hip and major osteoporotic fracture and to target anti-osteoporosis treatments. 
  • It was created in 2008 at the University of Sheffield in the United Kingdom by the WHO Collaborating Centre for Metabolic Bone Diseases.
  • Many risk factors for fractures were identified and added to the tool through a series of comprehensive meta-analyses from 12 prospective population-based studies from North America, Europe, Asia, and Australia. 
  • FRAX uses 7 easily accessible clinical risk factors, which are entered into the calculation as yes or no. 
  • These factors include smoking, systemic glucocorticoid usage, excessive alcohol consumption, rheumatoid arthritis, parental hip fractures, past fragility fractures, and other causes of secondary osteoporosis. 
  • FRAX also takes into account body mass index (BMI), sex, and age. 
  • FRAX may calculate the fracture probability with or without femoral neck BMD, accommodating different situations.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fracture rehabilitation assessment: Rehabilitation focuses on restoring function and movement after a fracture has occurred. FRAX is used before a fracture, to predict the likelihood of one happening in the future.

 

Option C. Fracture repair assessment: Repair refers to the medical procedures (like surgery) used to fix a broken bone. FRAX is about predicting the risk of a fracture, not how it will be treated.

 

Option D. Fracture reduction assessment: Reduction is the process of setting a broken bone back into its proper alignment. FRAX doesn't assess the need for reduction, but rather the overall risk of a fracture occurring in the first place.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FRAX is a tool for prevention by identifying those at risk of fractures.
